PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m. and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, left on 20 November on Government business overseas. He will return to Australia on 6 December and in his absence the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, is the Acting Minister for Industrial Relations.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the soon to be signed human contacts treaty with the Soviet Union and, in particular, those provisions that will streamline Australian visas for Soviet visitors allowing a wide range of Soviet contacts with Australian institutions. Will the Prime Minister give an assurance that these provisions will not assist the Soviet strategy of acquiring Western technology and placing agents of influence in Western institutions? In view of the recent expulsion of an east European diplomat's son from Australia for illegal technology transfers, does the proposed treaty have the support of all of our relevant security and intelligence agencies? Finally, is the Prime Minister aware that human contacts is an area handled by the active measures program administered by the directorate of the KGB, otherwise known as the disinformation department?

—I am confident that those matters of concern which were raised in the first part of the Leader of the Opposition's question will be appropriately covered and that we would not, in any of those respects, be disadvantaged by what will be done in the agreement to which he referred. I have no recollection of any indication that what we are proposing in this area is being opposed by any of the intelligence agencies. Therefore, this part of what will be fairly comprehensive discussions with the leadership in the Soviet Union will be part of a package which will be of benefit to this country as a whole.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of concerns expressed by sole parent organisations about sole parents with disabled children losing pension entitlement? Can the Minister inform the House what the position is for these pensioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Phillip for her question. I am aware of the concern that sole parents who have a disabled child who is a full time student have as of 1 September been losing their entitlement to a pension when the youngest child turns 16 years. The Government does not believe that having a full time student and a child over 16 years of age, by itself, stops anybody from working. However, where a child is disabled and needs special care from his or her parent, that can stop the parent working. It is also a qualifying condition for the payment of the handicapped child allowance, now called the child disability allowance, that the child needs constant care and attention. This could not be guaranteed if the parent were to enter the work force or to seek work. Accordingly, it has been decided to restore the eligibility of such parents for a pension for as long as the child remains a dependent student and attracts the disabled child allowance.

ANSWER.PARA: Amending legislation with retrospective cover will be included in the next social security Bill to come before the Parliament. This means that a sole parent with a disabled child can continue to receive the pension until the child turns 25. Sole parents with such children, whose pension has already been cancelled, will have their pension reinstated from the date of cancellation. The Department is already aware of a few individual cases which will be assisted by this initiative and will be making every effort to identify others. However, I would strongly urge sole parents in these circumstances who are not promptly contacted by the Department to contact their local office as quickly as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to a report in this morning's Australian Financial Review concerning the consideration of a plan to sell 30 per cent of the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). The report mentions:

QUESTION.PARA: The aim of the proposed float of 30 per cent is to raise, as quickly as possible, about $40 million in new capital to allow the corporation to boost its investment in less commercial development projects.

I ask the Treasurer: How can the AIDC successfully float equity in the market-place if the additional equity is to be used to finance less commercial development projects, which would presumably yield a rate of return below that of the market? Is the Government proposing to subsidise the undertaking of additional less commercial projects in order to generate a competitive rate of return?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a submission about in respect of the AIDC's capital requirements, but it has not gone to the Cabinet at this stage.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask whether he is aware of recent statements by the President of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) branch of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), Dr McNicol, that the Government had capitulated to the AMA's demands in the settlement of the ACT doctors dispute.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of those statements, and I thank the honourable member for his question. He has been one of the community leaders in the forefront of demanding a settlement of the strike and I am pleased to advise the House that it has been settled on reasonable terms. Earlier this year the ACT branch of the Australian Medical Association put a remarkable claim before the Government. This was to be the basis of new contracts with private medical practitioners for the treatment of public patients in public hospitals. This claim, if accepted, would have raised the annual cost from $4m to around $7.5m, a rise of almost 90 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The claim was based on a few very notable components: first of all, the use of the AMA fee schedule as the basis of modified fee for service payments in lieu of the Government's Medicare benefits schedule, with which, of course, this Government has complied strictly while demanding that the States do likewise; secondly, the annual indexation of fee schedule on the basis of movements in average weekly earnings; thirdly, on-call contract payments of $180 per day for anaesthetists and $120 a day for other specialists; fourthly, a loading of 50 per cent on the fee for services provided outside normal working hours; and, finally, compensation for normal operating theatre time cancelled by a hospital without reasonable notice. This claim, demanding as it was, was later extended to include sessional remuneration equivalent to that offered in New South Wales public hospitals.

The Government has rejected from the outset any notion of the AMA fee schedule being the basis of remuneration for private medical practitioners, and I would hope that all members of the House would support that proposition. It has also rejected the idea of a fee loading for services provided outside normal hours. Further, the Government has not been prepared to accept a sessional remuneration package based on the excessive rates which apply under the Macken determination in New South Wales. Rather, the Government has approved a fair and responsible package which relies on the Government's medical fee schedule. It provides indexation at a rate which will ensure that the medical profession shares fully the income restraint that has been experienced by the general community. It includes provision for a modest on-call contract payment of $60 per day for specialists rostered on call by a hospital. It allows reasonable compensation for operating theatre time cancelled at short notice and offers sessional remuneration equivalent to that which is offered by the Commonwealth in New South Wales repatriation hospitals. This arrangement provides for a maximum hourly payment of $94 compared with the $119 offered in New South Wales public hospitals.

For the information of honourable members, I point out that during the dispute the doctors made a song and dance about providing emergency work on a voluntary basis. However, as part of their determination they demanded payment for these services, cancelling all that nonsense about voluntary work. The settlement package which I have outlined obviously is not as the AMA claimed in the last few days. It is substantially different in style and content and the annual cost will be less than $6m, a saving of over $1.5m on the original AMA claim and up to $2m on its revised claim. I hope that now the doctors have agreed to go back to work they will stay at work, that they will take advantage of the settlement procedures which are now in place and that in future the people of Canberra can look forward to services from doctors, who are in a very privileged position, of the style that Canberra people are entitled to from people who have taken the Hippocratic oath.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of criticism by the National Farmers Federation and other farmer organisations that they were not consulted before the Prime Minister left for New Zealand to discuss with the New Zealand Prime Minister changes to the closer economic relations (CER) agreement? What new commitments, if any, were made at that meeting on agricultural trade with New Zealand, especially in relation to meat, dairying and horticulture? Will the Prime Minister give an assurance that there will be discussions with the respective producer organisations before committing Australia to any further changes to the closer economic relations agreement including the existing industry arrangements under the memorandum of understanding?

—I can say that I am not aware of any such criticism by the National Farmers Federation. I must say that these days I am getting used to being congratulated by that organisation. I would have been surprised if on this occasion it had changed its better ways of recent times. After Question Time, with the leave of the House, I will be making a detailed statement on the visit to New Zealand including the discussions with regard to CER. Essentially in this area we have agreed that officials will have discussions now and at the beginning of next year, that Ministers will meet in June of next year and that Prime Minister Lange and me will be meeting about August next year to review the work of officials and of Ministers. Of course, as those discussions proceed it will be my clear expectation that interested groups will be involved in consultations with our officials and that there will be every opportunity for an appropriate input from the National Farmers Federation to the discussions. On the particular question of dairying, let me say that the position we have put to the New Zealanders, to which they are agreeable, is that that is covered, as was indicated by the honourable member, by a memorandum of understanding. We regard it as appropriate that the discussions on the issue of dairying should be conducted between the two industry associations.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to a story in this morning's Press outlining the view of Senator Stone and Senator Sheil of the National Party of Australia that the Government should stop non-English speaking migrants from coming to Australia? Can the Minister outline to the House the implications of such a proposal, were it to be taken seriously by the Government, for Australia's migration program? Is the Minister aware that had this attitude been Australia's policy after World War II Australia would never have realised the massive benefits of the post-war migration which occurred and that, in fact, I would not be standing here today asking this question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I am aware of the comments that have been made by Senator Sheil and Senator Stone. This is the second time Senator Sheil, in his very illustrious career in Parliament, has made the newspapers, basically on the same issue. I am also aware of the position the honourable member may have been placed in had their policy been retrospective. In the honourable member's case, as I understand from reading newspapers, there may have been some other factors.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also pleased to acknowledge the statements made by the shadow Minister in the Opposition, the honourable member for Mitchell, and the Leader of the Opposition dissociating themselves and saying that the statements made by the two senators are quite contrary to the policy and the bipartisan attitude that this Parliament has had on the question of a non-discriminatory migration program to this country.

We are not too sure, and I do not think the people who made these statements are quite sure, whether they made them in the light of their views about people who come from non-English speaking backgrounds, or whether in fact they believe there is another program that can be adopted that would be better than teaching English in Australia and that perhaps we could have these programs operating overseas. In both cases they are wrong. Until 1977 we did have quite an extensive provision for English language instruction before the arrival of migrants in Australia. Almost every program that was conducted, by both governments, was singularly unsuccessful. One of the reasons we have a backlog of about 200,000 people now waiting to learn English is the unsatisfactory administration of those programs. This Government and the previous government recognised that learning English is central to every aspect of life in this country. If we want people to have equality, equity and access to all the provisions that Australia has to offer, the English language is central to all of them.

Senator Stone and Senator Sheil seem to belie and belittle the contribution that has been made to this country by people who have come from non-English speaking backgrounds. I think we should reiterate what has happened in this country since 1947. In addition to the 1.8 million people who have come from the United Kingdom and Ireland, 382,000 have come from Italy, 227,000 have come from Greece, 186,000 have come from Yugoslavia, 166,000 have come from the Netherlands, 144,000 have come from Germany, 105,000 have come from Poland, and 91,000 have come from Vietnam, together with people from almost every country on the globe.

The two gentlemen in the Senate ought to take into account some of the significant figures who have played a role in this country who would not have been here under the policy now being espoused by them. Sir John Monash's parents were German. Ferdinand Mueller, our greatest botanist, was a German. Carboni, a participant in and the historian of the Eureka Stockade, was, of course, Italian. Von Guerard, one of our leading nineteenth century artists; Leichhardt, one of the great explorers of this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —He could speak English.

—The honourable member should go to the college on the Darling Downs and it will explain this to him. Even today, at 86 years of age, a person visits the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to make his contribution on behalf of this Parliament and this country-I refer to Sir Otto Frankel, our leading plant geneticist. Bernard Neumann is our leading mathematician. Then there is Sir Arvi Parbo, and in this Parliament are several members, not only the honourable member for Bowman, but the honourable member for Prospect, the honourable member for Hotham and the honourable member for Calwell, and other members of this Parliament-the honourable member for Kennedy puts up his hand--
—What about Joh?

—I am leaving Joh until last. I also acknowledge, Mr Acting Speaker, that it was the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants which very much focused the attention of the Fraser Government on the need to boost spending on English language courses in this country. If you look at the record, you will find that the Fraser Government was the government that gave great stimulation to English language courses in this country, which we have followed. I do not know what the Secretary to the Treasury at that time had to say about these programs. But one is dismayed to think that a person who is now making these comments was in charge of the most important government department.

ANSWER.PARA: It is rumoured that he is to run as Leader of the National Party. He wants to come down to the lower House and has bought a house in the electorate of Fairfax. He should have a yarn to the honourable member for Fairfax who can tell him that there are 7,000 migrants in that electorate from non-English speaking backgrounds. They come from Austria, Chile, China, Cyprus, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, France, Germany, Greece, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Italy, Latvia, Lebanon, Malaysia and the list goes on and on, as it does for every electorate in this country. The contribution of these people has been enormous and should be acknowledged.

The one great thing about this Parliament is that we have had a bipartisan view on this subject. There may be arguments about the extent of the resources that can be put at the disposal of these various programs, but we have never argued that the programs are unnecessary or as to whether they are in the best interests of this country. Everybody in this Parliament and people outside who observe the mutterings of the Stones and the Sheils should condemn them for what they stand for.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he agrees with the view of the Minister for Transport and Communications that there is:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . a quite major Budgetary problem looming ahead for the Government: for three enterprises alone-Qantas, Australian Airlines and . . . the Commonwealth Bank-and that the Budgetary outlay required will be, over the next few years, of the order of $1 billion.
Does the Prime Minister also agree that if these outlays are to be provided by the private sector, partial or full privatisation of the enterprises concerned needs to proceed promptly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have observed the comments in speeches by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans. It will come as no surprise to the honourable member for Casey that I have considerable sympathy with the views expressed by Senator Evans. As for what will happen to government policy in this area, it is no secret that what is about to transpire is a considered discussion and debate within my Party on the question of the future operation of a range of publicly owned enterprises. I take this opportunity to say what I said to this House relatively recently. There is a great distinction between honourable members on the Government benches and Opposition members on the way we approach this issue.
—Oh!

—Here goes the giggler again. Among Opposition members there is a view which replicates the attitude of the United Kingdom Government that there is something intrinsically bad about the public sector and something intrinsically better in the operation of an enterprise by the private sector. Speaking for myself, Senator Evans and all Labor members, we have no such ideological mania. My concern, which will be the area of discussion within the Party and the Government on this side of the House, is the question of priorities and how the needs of the Australian people in the various priorities that we have in those areas will best be served. None of us, and neither Senator Evans nor myself, will be driven by the ideological hangup which affects Opposition members.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said the other day, the other comparison is that on this side of the House I have encouraged-and I am glad to see that there has been virtually a unanimous response on this side-such a discussion within our Party. I contrasted our approach with what happens in the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition has a view that all wisdom in matters economic, social and otherwise resides with him, and that if other members, whether it be the honourable member for Boothby, the honourable member for Goldstein or Senator Peter Baume, take a different view from the Leader of the Opposition, they are not encouraged to have a debate properly within their party forum. They get booted out from the front bench and put up the back. That is one of the very obvious distinguishing characteristics between the two sides of the House. We will address the issues and have a healthy debate on them. While the Leader of the Opposition is the leader of the Liberal Party-and I pray earnestly that he will stay there-the Liberals will continue to stay in opposition. Debate is stifled in the Opposition ranks and honourable members opposite flounder around without any idea of a sensible way of trying to address themselves to the real issues of concern to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns the possibility of more disarray and distress in Queensland. Is the Minister aware of moves by the Queensland Government to slash the living standards of poor families in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Director-General of the Queensland Department of Family and Youth Services recently wrote to families receiving emergency relief payments for children informing them that the Queensland Government had terminated the payment. The allowance was worth $16.95 a week. To many members that may not sound like a great deal of money, but I am sure it will make a considerable difference to those very low income families concerned. It is interesting that that should happen in Queensland, whereas in Victoria, under its social justice strategy, the Government is redirecting State finances to achieve a fairer and equitable distribution of resources. Under that strategy the Victorian Government is introducing the educational maintenance allowance for school students of very low income families.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, all governments have to exercise greater financial stringency. The Commonwealth Government has done so. It has balanced the Budget and has also delivered the family assistance package with major improvements in income security for low income families. The Victorian Government-as I suggested-has delivered complementary, but nevertheless significant, income support for low income families with children at school. At this time the Queensland Government has slashed income support for those families and has the hide to blame the Commonwealth. Queensland was treated the same way as the other States in terms of Commonwealth assistance for 1987-88. In any case, at the 1987 Premiers Conference the Queensland Premier called for an even greater real cut than was actually made in Commonwealth funding to the States. At a time in which the Federal Government has sought to focus attention and has contributed very real and significant resources in support of low income families, the Queensland Government has not found even sufficient priority to maintain emergency relief payments to student children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs give an assurance that worthy migrants will not be prevented from entering this country by any language barrier? Will he further give an assurance that non-English speaking migrants will be given every encouragement and improved facilities to learn English as urgently as possible? Will he also give an assurance that worthy migrants from countries such as Lebanon, where there is a high degree of genocide, will have their access to this country made a little easier than it is at the moment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Firstly, in relation to Lebanon, it is a very sad story as far as many Australian citizens are concerned. We have quite a big Lebanese community in this country and I meet delegations from various communities regularly to talk about the problems. At various times in both the previous Government and in this Government we have had special humanitarian programs to deal with specific episodes that have dislocated the lives of a lot of people in Lebanon and which have facilitated the entry into this country of a higher number of Lebanese people than otherwise would be the case. At the moment frustration is being experienced by people in the Lebanon because of security problems. We are unable to open an office in Beirut. People have to travel to Damascus, which causes them a great deal of inconvenience, to be interviewed and place their applications for entry into this country. The Prime Minister has made it clear that as soon as we receive word that security can be restored in Beirut we will be re-opening our office there.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that the honourable member talks about the benefits that might flow to people who come from non-English speaking backgrounds, Australia has provided, not just to migrants of non-English speaking backgrounds but to all migrants, a great environment for them to rebuild their lives, in many cases, an education second to none for their children and opportunities that would not be available in many other countries. The retention of their languages and cultures is second to none in this country. Many people who travel to this country are absolutely astounded at the way in which communities have been able to retain their cultures as very much part of the environment which Australia has provided.

At the moment we are inundated with applications from people who would like to live here. We estimate that we get 1.2 million serious inquiries a year from people who would like to migrate to Australia. As we stipulate an intake, of all categories, of 120,000 it means that we are saying no to nine out of 10 people. Australia can be proud of what has happened here since World War II, in particular, in regard to the settlement of migrants. We have learnt a lot. Many of the settlement services we now have in place were not in place in those early years. We no longer see migrants as just being fodder for the factories or in terms of the work they might be able to do but also for the contributions they can make. Almost every walk of life, whether it be academia, politics, trade unions or business has been affected by the fact that people have come from all over the world to live in this country. It is a lesson for all to observe: we can go on building this country in the way we have done with the continuation of these programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order. With respect, I ask the Minister to answer the first part of my question. I asked him to give an assurance that people who are unable to speak English will be permitted to enter this country.
—The Minister does not have to answer that question.
—I can give a better assurance than that. There will be no moving away from the absolutely non-discriminatory policy which both parties have observed for the last 15 years.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services and Health and relates to an issue of great public importance. Has the Minister noted the recent recommendation of the National Health and Medical Research Council that vitamin B1, thiamine, be added to a number of staple foods in order to prevent the emergence of the Wernicke Korsakoff syndrome? Is it the case that each year in Australia some 300 people are admitted to hospital, at great social and economic cost, with this largely preventable disease? What action will the Government be taking to allow the addition of thiamine to staple foods, such as beer, wine and bread, as a proven prophylactic public health measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and note that he has made persistent representations on this matter over the past 18 months. I have noted that the National Health and Medical Research Council has recommended the addition of thiamine to certain alcoholic beverages as a means of reducing the incidence of Wernicke Korsakoff syndrome. This is a serious and potentially fatal brain disorder which has been shown to be associated with a deficiency of vitamin B1, thiamine. We have an estimated 500 to 600 cases a year in this country of this disease. If it is untreated, or is unsuccessfully treated, the condition progresses to a further stage of mental illness which usually requires permanent institutional care.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been many years of debate on this issue within the National Health and Medical Research Council, and the Council has now concluded that there is sufficient evidence that the addition of thiamine to certain alcoholic beverages would be likely to prevent a significant number of cases of this disease. It has therefore recommended that that practice be adopted because it represents an effective public health illness prevention measure. The Council has further recommended that thiamine be added to beer, cask and flagon wines and fortified wines as the most significant beverages affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you tasted it?

—In response to the query from the honourable member for Barker, I am advised by the National Health and Medical Research Council that, if thiamine were added at the rate suggested, it would have no effect on taste or colour.

ANSWER.PARA: This recommendation of the National Health and Medical Research Council has been passed to the Australian Health Ministers Conference and to the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy for endorsement, and I shall be discussing this matter with my colleagues on both of those bodies as soon as possible with a view to seeking implementation of the suggestion. I have also arranged for early consultations between the alcohol sub-committee of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy and the industry itself, provided that my colleagues in the States agree to that proposal, so that we can work with the industry to implement this policy.

Finally, the other recommendation from the National Health and Medical Research Council that thiamine should also be included in flour and bread is being treated as a separate issue and is dealt with in the national dietary survey soon to be released.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister recall saying shortly after the election that, if some Government bodies were privatised and freed from Government restraints, those enterprises may become more efficient and more viable, an outcome which could only benefit consumers, taxpayers and the employees of the enterprises concerned? Does he also recall saying before the election that privatisation was a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century of your assets? Given the Prime Minister's panic meetings last night and today with the Centre Left faction, what is his current view of privatisation; or, more to the point, what are the factions telling him his view is?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Corangamite for his profound question. I can assure the honourable gentlemen that the meetings I had last night were not panic meetings. They were very congenial and produced an outcome of a consensus kind, which I am accustomed to being associated with; and I appreciate the good efforts of everyone involved to produce such a sensible and consensual outcome. No one tells me what my views on anything will be, whether it be privatisation or anything else-with the possible exception that sometimes my wife makes very strong recommendations as to how I should think about certain things, but not privatisation.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the honourable gentleman of what I said before. What will happen is that there will be within my Party and its various processes here within the Parliament and elsewhere a discussion about these matters. A very sensible decision has been taken which will mean that the Ministers involved, in collaboration with representative bodies from the Caucus, will examine what would be involved in ensuring that existing enterprises were viable and kept in effective public ownership. That is a sensible approach so that there will be exposed what is necessary to achieve those objectives. Within that process of exposure of the facts, various people will have different views, not necessarily generally about all enterprises; some will have different views about one from another. I believe that, at the end of this process, we will have on this side of the House a sensible appreciation of what is necessary, as I have said before, to advance the interests of the people of this country.

I simply reiterate what I said before: That process of healthy discussion and debate on this side of the House stands in stark and healthy contrast with the way members on the Opposition side of the House muddle through; and as they continue to do that they will remain on the left hand side of the Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of the recent announcement by Bridgestone Australia Ltd on the recall of many faulty tyres? Are more products being recalled now than in the past? Does the Government consider this to be a problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bridgestone Australia Ltd has notified me that a safety-related defect has been identified with tyres manufactured in its factory between 14 and 26 September of this year. I understand that officers of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs and the Federal Office of Road Safety recently met with representatives from Bridgestone Australia concerning this recall. As the suspect tyres have been supplied to retail outlets and also to major car manufacturers as original equipment, Bridgestone will be conducting a national recall on 25 November in conjunction with action to be taken by major car manufacturers.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of that part of the question concerning the increase in the number of recalls, the number of voluntary recalls of products notified since the introduction of the recall provisions of the Trade Practices Act in July 1986 has now reached 225. From July to November 1986 the number of recalls was 60; and from July to November 1987 the number was 86. Therefore, there has been a significant increase in the number of recalls undertaken by companies in Australia over the past five months compared with the same period last year. This increase could be attributed to the greater awareness among Australian companies: firstly, of the need to ensure that their products do not pose a risk to the user; and secondly, of the requirement now under the Trade Practices Act to notify the voluntary recall action.

The voluntary recall system does appear to be working well overall. I commend manufacturers such as Bridgestone Australia Ltd for their generally responsible attitude to the Trade Practices Act and the safety of consumers. While on this question of recalls, I should bring to the attention of the House again the issue of quality generally and a need in Australian manufacturing to ensure not just that recalls work effectively but also that quality is built into more on-line production in design engineering, materials and manufacture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister agree with the statement from the parliamentary Left of the Australian Labor Party that today's Caucus decision on privatisation was an important and vital victory which would enhance authorities in full public ownership? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, they seem to be tigers for punishment on the other side of the House. I have answered the question about what is happening on this side of the House on this issue twice already, and I will, therefore, as I am asked to do, go to it a third time. A position has been reached where there will be the process of discussion and debate within the parliamentary Labor Party. It will be an exposure of the facts with regard to what is necessary to maintain viable and effective ownership of existing public enterprises.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know what statements may have been made to this point other than the ones that I have made myself. If there has been any victory, it has been a victory for sanity and for those who want a serious, sensible exposure of the facts and a debate and discussion within the Government on the basis of those exposed facts. I regard that as a victory for nothing other than sanity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy: Has his attention been drawn to yesterday's announcement by Austen and Butta Ltd giving details of the closure of the Invincible colliery? Did Austen and Butta seek rail freight reductions in the order of $5.50 a tonne, or about a 50 per cent reduction, to alleviate the company's problems? Can the Minister confirm whether it was stated in the company's media release that even if such concessions were granted further management and operating savings in excess of $7 a tonne would be required to keep the mine viable? In view of the obvious concern in the Lithgow region about the future of the coal industry, what action is being formulated by the Federal Government to develop a long term strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member seems to have the picture of this most unfortunate closure pretty well in his mind. Of course the mine is in his electorate and he takes a close interest in this industry. Austen and Butta Ltd announced its intention yesterday to close the Invincible colliery located near Lithgow. ANSWER.PARA: The Chairman of Austen and Butta has stated that closure of the mine will result in a loss of export income of $50m and a loss of State government revenue of $26m. The Commonwealth and New South Wales assistance package announced recently, which amounts to some $40m over two years and is equally funded by the Commonwealth and the State, is designed to finance a reduction in State government charges on export coal mines in the form of agreed reductions in State Rail Authority charges for eligible mines. The figures I gave a moment ago should indicate the level of charges on that one mine. In determining eligibility the Commonwealth Government is requiring that progress should be made in reducing mine site costs.

The prospective wind-down of the Invincible colliery is of particular concern to the Government as this mine is one at which some changes in work practices have occurred, although the mine operators claim that there is room for further changes. Earlier the company had taken decisions to invest in longwall mining equipment but it had a problem at one time with a large roof failure. Another factor adding to its problems was the national seven-day shutdown in September which cost us 140,000 tonnes of production and also made the negotiation of contracts after March next year more difficult.

Regarding the short term and long term strategies we are developing, it could have been expected that a mine such as Invincible would have had a good case for seeking to be included in the program. It is unfortunate that that will not take place. I emphasise that the assistance program which is being put in place is designed to assist those mines with the prospect of long term viability in the export industry. It might well be that not all of the mines affected by the current restructuring of the industry will find the level of assistance available sufficient to justify their continued operations. DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER'S VISIT TO NEW ZEALAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to report to the Parliament on the visit I paid to New Zealand from 19 to 23 November. As I said at the state luncheon hosted by Prime Minister David Lange in Wellington on 20 November, Australia and New Zealand have a unique relationship. We are next door neighbours. We share long historical ties and deep liberal democratic traditions. Australians and New Zealanders have fought together in two world wars, we have co-operated and collaborated in time of peace and we are, enduringly, the closest of friends. The strength of the relationship consists of much more than connections between the two governments and its vitality resides in the daily exchanges between our peoples across the widest range of business, family, sporting, cultural and political activities.

SPEECH.PARA: My visit in every way reflected this special warmth, openness and friendship. My extensive discussions with Prime Minister Lange and his Ministers over four days were characterised by these qualities. But while good will abounded this was not merely a symbolic and good will visit. It was also a very business-like one concerned with the further development of Australia-New Zealand relations. While the close ties established in the past formed the backdrop for my talks, their focus was on the contemporary scene and on how we might co-operate more closely in the future.

It serves the interest of neither country for us to regard the relationship as fixed in time and bound by the limits of the past. The relationship must remain relevant to current needs and have flexibility to adapt to changing circumstances. For a start, the political and economic situation in the South Pacific, a region of direct and immediate interest to both countries, is not immutable. Indeed, as I said to Mr Lange in our discussion of foreign policy topics, the region is somewhat more troubled that it was five or 10 years ago. I stress that this is by no means an alarmist comment. The overall situation in the South Pacific continues to be one of stability and the relationship between Australia and New Zealand and our friends in the region remains extremely close and friendly. But clearly some significant new difficulties have emerged.

We discussed the situation in Fiji and found a close proximity of views. This was true in respect of both the analysis of the situation and our policies in response to it. Australia and New Zealand both deplore the overturning of civilian democratic government by the military in Fiji. We are acutely conscious of the disruptive impact which this has had on the political fabric of Fiji, its economic circumstances and prospects and Fiji's international standing. We each take the view that our friendship for the people of Fiji is undiminished and we each have a strong interest in the restoration in Fiji of political and constitutional arrangements, achieved by the people of Fiji themselves, which will provide for political stability, social harmony, economic recovery and human rights. We will each be taking a close interest in the situation as it evolves.

Mr Lange and I agreed that the position taken by the South Pacific Forum at its meeting in Apia, and more recently by the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver, constituted a realistic approach to the Fiji problem and one which clearly enjoys widespread international support. I expressed to Mr Lange my very deep appreciation for the way in which we had been able to work closely and actively together at these important meetings. We shall continue to do so.

Another regional problem which, as Mr Lange said, has sent ripples through the region is New Caledonia. Australia's wish remains to help ensure that a long term, viable, peaceful political solution can be found to the problems of New Caledonia. We do not seek to confront France over New Caledonia or to drive it from the South Pacific region. Such suggestions are completely without foundation. Our concern is to encourage France to engage all the people of New Caledonia, including the Kanaks, in a genuine process of deciding future arrangements for New Caledonia. Like New Zealand and other South Pacific Forum countries, we wish France to follow the well-established decolonisation procedures of the United Nations in arranging an authentic process of self-determination in the Territory. And, as I said in Wellington, the changes we seek are, whatever may be said in some quarters, designed to achieve precisely the stability which is vital to Australia, New Zealand and the region as a whole.

The consultations on foreign policy during my visit extended beyond such immediate regional issues to a range of other matters. We talked about positive developments in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly noting the remarkable growth performance of many countries in the Pacific Rim. There is a concurrence of view that Australia and New Zealand are not only geographically a part of this region but that our economies must increasingly draw their vitality from the region. We discussed the importance of the course on which China has embarked, reaffirmed at the recent Party Congress, towards economic modernisation and the continuation of openings to other countries. We each welcomed the direction China has taken and attach the highest importance to it. The effort my own Government has made to develop the extremely close relationship with China which Australia now enjoys has already brought very significant benefits. We discussed, too, the situation in the Philippines where our two countries each firmly support the Government of President Aquino.

Our discussions covered the changes taking place in the Soviet Union, which I will shortly have the opportunity to assess first hand during my visit to that country. Prime Minister Lange and I were at one in commending the improvement which has taken place in East-West relations and, in particular, the importance of the impending agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union for the elimination of intermediate nuclear weapons. We hope that this will provide impetus for progress in the area of strategic nuclear weapons and other fields of disarmament and arms control. As I said in Wellington, Australia and New Zealand have worked together in the cause of disarmament and my Government has valued co-operation with New Zealand in the search for a comprehensive test ban agreement and in the conclusion of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, a significant and creative regional arms control arrangement by the countries of the South Pacific Forum.

Notwithstanding all these areas in which my discussions again showed that Australia and New Zealand hold such close views, our positions do not always coincide. We are sovereign, independent countries; as Mr Lange put it, one Australasian family we may be, we are nevertheless two nations. Moreover, it is exactly because of the extremely close friendship between the two countries to which I earlier referred that we owe it to each other to speak plainly when there is a significant policy difference.

As all honourable members know, there is a serious difference between the Australian and New Zealand governments over the issue of access of allied warships to our ports. My visit in no way sought to disguise this difference or sweep it under the carpet. I reaffirmed clearly, both in my private talks and publicly in New Zealand, that Australia adheres firmly to our policy on welcoming ship visits by our United States ally. We accept the need for strategic deterrence. Australia will not resile from its firm support for the Western Alliance, with the corollary that the global nuclear balance can be maintained only through a credible United States nuclear deterrent. We believe that, although a nuclear balance of power is not an ideal state of affairs, it does exist and it has maintained world peace. We consider that a realistic policy is to recognise this while, at the same time, encouraging balanced reductions in nuclear forces which maintain the credibility of the deterrent at the lowest possible level.

We believe too that part of Australia's contribution to the Western Alliance system is to allow access to ports and airfields in Australia by the United States. We continue firmly to believe that such access is essential to the full effectiveness of the ANZUS alliance. Clearly New Zealand takes a different view and this disagreement is not therefore in any sense behind us. But I believe that it is a sign of the maturity of our relationship that we can have this important disagreement without allowing it to corrode our overall friendship. This includes the area of bilateral defence relations where Australia, New Zealand and indeed the United States regard it as important that co-operation and collaboration continue. My Government's approach to Australia's defence relationship with New Zealand continues to be governed by the basic importance of the defence relationship to the security of Australia and New Zealand alike, as acknowledged in the White Papers published by both governments in 1987. The ability of Australian and New Zealand forces to operate together, and to support and sustain each other, adds significantly to the joint defence capability of the two countries. What this means in practical terms is that my Government has sought to consolidate the defence relationship in well defined activities such as training, co-operative procurement, combined exercises, ship visits and effective consultations on the South West Pacific and other regional interests. I wish in particular to mention here the Anzac ship project, to construct the new surface combatant ships, which represents a milestone in Australia-New Zealand defence co-operation. This project will promote inter-operability between our navies and make a major contribution to our strategic needs.

For New Zealand's part, Mr Lange noted that our common security interests are indeed extensive. He signified that New Zealand valued its defence alliance with Australia. He, too, noted the practical value of combining our efforts in such areas as procurement. He correctly said that there is a solid pragmatic basis for our commitment to each other. My discussions in New Zealand also covered the challenges facing our respective economies and the management of them. Our situations differ in important respects and our policies are not, of course, identical. But it was valuable to compare experiences and approaches and, moreover, we do have two important things in common. First, both New Zealand and Australia are engaged in the task of economic restructuring. We recognise that this is the only route by which our nations can ensure their prosperity and growth in the contemporary world economy. Secondly, both my Government and the New Zealand Government accept that restructuring involves decisions which are seldom easy or comfortable. It requires economic management which is realistic, credible and resolute.

I need not leave it unsaid that my visit to New Zealand was, to some extent, a fraternal visit. The Labor parties on both sides of the Tasman have this year achieved historic re-elections. And it is noteworthy that in the task of economic restructuring and economic management both countries are being led through the present very testing economic circumstances by Labor governments committed to policies which are realistic and creative. I do not doubt from my discussions the determination of the New Zealand Government to confront the problems facing the New Zealand economy and I wish Mr Lange and his colleagues well. Given the importance of the trans-Tasman economic connection and its potential to become still more important, the growth and development to both economies is clearly and very strongly in our mutual interests; not just in the interests of the citizens of Australia and New Zealand considered separately. Mr Lange rightly described the closer economic relations (CER) agreement as a central strand in the fabric of our relationship. I am happy to pay tribute here, as I did in New Zealand, to the hard work and imagination of our predecessors in government in developing the CER. It is an initiative which the present governments both in Australia and New Zealand fully endorse.

Progress under CER has without question exceeded expectations. It is the most comprehensive bilateral agreement entered into by either country in the trade field. Its success is indicated by the extent of the increase in two-way trade, from $1.8 billion in 1982-83 to $3.2 billion in 1986-87. This has been a function of the strides made in reducing or eliminating barriers to trade, often far in advance of the timetable set out in the agreement. For example, tariffs on most goods have been removed and duty-free trade has increased remarkably from 75 per cent to 92 per cent of total trans-Tasman trade in the course of the agreement. In addition, trade which is free of quantitative import restrictions has increased since the agreement commenced in 1983. Pleasing progress has been made in eliminating export subsidies and incentives on goods traded between Australia and New Zealand and in the work that has been done on harmonisation of standards in relation to such areas as food, industrial products and industrial property legislation.

However, the value of CER to Australia has gone beyond just the quantitative impact on our bilateral trade. For many, exporting to New Zealand has been the first experience with the export market and has provided an invaluable opportunity to develop an export culture. And indeed, it is that recognition of the wider benefits of CER that has informed our joint approach to the review of CER which will take place in 1988. My discussions with Mr Lange and his Ministers have set the agenda for the detailed discussions which will now get under way.

We agreed that a new chapter should be opened in the economic relationship, one in which we advance the economic relationship more rapidly and on a more comprehensive basis. In setting the agenda for the CER review, Mr Lange and I agreed on three areas for consideration. First, the two governments will examine the scope for bringing forward to the early 1990s the implementation of free trade in goods across the Tasman, previously scheduled for completion in 1995. Secondly, our governments will explore the extension of CER beyond trade in goods to the growing area of trade in services. Thirdly, we are ready to consider the extension of CER to regulatory policies and practices outside the present provisions of CER, which bear on trade and investment. Officials will begin discussions early in the New Year, ahead of a meeting of Ministers around June. Mr Lange and I intend to meet and compare notes on progress made in August or shortly thereafter.

Our intention is to approach the Review positively to get a framework, objectives and time scale for implementation of decisions which will significantly deepen and widen the economic relationship across the Tasman over the next five years. This task is one which the business communities of both countries have called on us to undertake. The aim, as I said earlier, is not just to boost bilateral trade. It is to help to prepare each of our countries to compete on world markets, especially those of our region.

The New Zealand Government, like the Australian Government, is acutely conscious of the fact that whatever progress we make in bilateral trade relations there is no substitute for liberalisation of international trade on a global basis. This is a fundamental interest which we share and for which we will continue to work together internationally. Mr Lange and I recognised the value of the Cairns group of fair traders as a much needed third force in the Uruguay round of trade negotiations. As efficient agricultural exporters, Australia and New Zealand have been hard hit by the distortion and disruption of international trade in agricultural products. We are determined to exert our influence to move the Uruguay round ahead in an effort to bring down protectionist barriers and reverse the corruption of international trade in agricultural products. Mr Lange described this as `an identity of interest' and I agree.

The closeness of relations between Australia and New Zealand will find very special expression next year through New Zealand's generous contribution to our bicentennial celebrations. New Zealand has responded enthusiastically to our invitation to join us in this celebration and the New Zealand-Australia Bicentennial Committee has developed a fine program of projects in both countries in 1988. I am particularly grateful that New Zealand has chosen to mark the Bicentenary by restoring and presenting to Australia the historic yacht Akarana, an inspired contribution to the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney which will, I am sure, be one of the institution's most popular attractions. The visit of Mr Lange to Australia in 1988 will be most welcome as a symbol of the closeness of Australia-New Zealand relations. I am sure I speak for all honourable members in reiterating here the thanks which I expressed to Mr Lange and through him to the people of New Zealand for the contribution New Zealand will make in 1988.

The point I wish to make, however, is that long after 1988 has passed, Australia and New Zealand will enjoy a deep closeness and affinity. It is not a relationship for one particular year, but an abiding relationship. It is not a relationship of mutual interest in one particular sector of activity, but a relationship of closeness across an extraordinarily wide range. My visit to New Zealand fully reflected and confirmed this fact. It leaves me not merely with a sense of deep satisfaction about what Australia and New Zealand are already doing together but also with a sense of great optimism about what we will yet do together in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes the statement which has been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). There is much in the Prime Minister's speech that will find bipartisan support in this Parliament. The relationship between Australia and New Zealand is very deep and is strongly supported by both sides of this Parliament and both sides of politics in Australia. The Liberal and National parties welcome the review of the closer economic relations (CER) announced by the Prime Minister and the New Zealand Prime Minister, Mr Lange. It is appropriate, as the Prime Minister acknowledged, to recognise the contribution that was made by the former coalition Government in bringing CER about. CER will stand as a permanent monument to the former Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, Doug Anthony, who, more than any other politician in recent Australian political history, sought to lay a practical as well as a sentimental and emotional basis for the relationship between Australia and New Zealand. Therefore, we in the Liberal and National parties are happy to join the Prime Minister and the Australian Labor Party in welcoming this review.

SPEECH.PARA: One would have to have a very shortsighted attitude towards the future of Australia and New Zealand to pretend that our joint interests do not lie in removing any remaining barriers that exist between our two countries. To the extent that the review of the closer economic relations agreement can bring about a dissolution of those barriers it is a development which honourable members on both sides of this House should welcome. However, I sound a note of caution that in the process of bringing about this review it is incumbent on both governments to ensure that there is total and adequate consultation with representatives of Australian industry, that there is a keen appreciation of the impact on some of the more struggling primary industries in Australia which may be affected by CER and that those changes should be brought about.

There are only two other matters I want to mention. The first matter relates to what I detected as a complacent note in the Prime Minister's speech regarding the overall situation in the South Pacific. The Prime Minister said:
The overall situation in the South Pacific continues to be one of stability and the relationship between Australia and New Zealand and our friends in the region remains extremely close and friendly.

I put it to the House that that is the kind of statement that could have been made by this Government six or nine months ago when we thought democracy still reigned in Fiji. It is the kind of statement that could have been made to this Parliament by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) when he initially embraced the recommendations of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities. It is the kind of statement that could have been made to this Parliament before the Prime Minister and his Government recognised the extent to which Libya was up to no good as far as our interests were concerned in the South Pacific.

I say again, notwithstanding my wish to sound, as far as possible, a bipartisan note on matters affecting the relationship with New Zealand, that the Prime Minister again evinces a note of complacency about the atmosphere as it prevails in the South Pacific. It will be no secret or surprise to this Parliament for the Liberal and National parties to say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we share none of the enthusiasm for the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty to which Australia is an adherent. We do not share the rather misty-eyed view of the Government about the value of this Treaty. We note that, in a sweeping review of the stability of the region and a reference to changes in the Soviet Union and attitudes towards China, there is no reference at all to the military significance of the Soviet presence in Cam Ranh Bay. How can a Prime Minister of Australia report to this Parliament about the state of stability in this part of the world without making any reference to that? I was pleased to hear his reference to the stability and viability of the Government in the Philippines. I hope that, within the bowels of those sections of the Government that are advising the Prime Minister on these matters, there is a contingency plan available about the strategic position of the Western alliance in this part of the world if events in the Philippines do not move in the direction we would like them to move.

Although I welcome the reaffirmation of the importance of the Western alliance and of the United States deterrent in the Prime Minister's remarks, I repeat the criticisms that were made by my predecessor, the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and by the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), at the time of the crisis in relations between New Zealand and the United States. We on this side of the House do not believe that the Hawke Government did nearly enough to dissuade the Lange Government from breaking the ANZUS Treaty. It remains one of the very serious strikes against this Government that insufficient was done at that time.

In conclusion, the Opposition welcomes any work done by the Government, however belated in terms of the timing of the visit by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), to build relations between Australia and New Zealand. It goes without contradiction that our destinies are linked, not only by history, but by the strategic circumstances in which we find ourselves in this part of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Jenkins,Mr Kent,Mr Peacock and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that food irradiation be not introduced as a method of food preservation. It is respectfully suggested in this regard that:
Food irradiation has been tested and abandoned in Europe and the USA;
Japan does not allow the importation of irradiated foodstuffs;
Food irradiation results in a loss of vitamins, an effect which enhances obesity;
Nearly all research shows a high degree of uncertainty about the dangerous effects of food irradiation;

Food irradiation is not only ineffective against the dangerous bacterial toxins, it also represents a further consumer expense and can produce in food colour changes and undesirable odours and flavours.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Dobie,Mr Rocher and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experimentations on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Bans on Smoking
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the Government's discriminatory Anti-Smoking legislation in the workplace bans and on Domestic Airline travel.
2. Note that so called Environmental Tobacco smoke has not been proved as a major pollutant either in the workplace or on aircraft.
3. This legislation will discriminate against thirty per cent of the citizens of Australia, and
4. Call upon the Government to lift all bans and not proceed with any discriminatory smoking legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Opportunities for the Young
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
We are concerned that-
(a) the proposed changes in legislation to Unemployment Benefit for young people adds to the already ill-conceived and over-bureaucratic welfare system and
(b) the abolition of CEP and the inadequacy of other training programs and
(c) cuts in funding for education, public housing and other welfare areas
mean that young people's needs are being neglected by the Government.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-the Commonwealth Government immediately takes steps to

(a) establish an anti-poverty level of income for all young people regardless of whether they are in training, retraining, education, employment or unemployment.
