(b) increase educational opportunities for all young people. The first step in achieving this would be to create 120 000 new places in higher and further education. This would make up for the 100 000 people turned away from TAFE courses and 20 000 people from universities and CAEs this year.
(c) establish a long term job creation program. The creation of 53 100 jobs for those young people who have been unemployed over 12 months is required immediately.
Your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-

We, the undersigned citizens, object to the proposal of Telecom to charge for each three minutes of a local call, as we feel this would disadvantage the elderly and people who are unable to leave their homes.

The telephone is sometimes the only contact relatives can have to check on the safety and well-being of those they care for. Also, when making business calls, you are quite often asked to hold the line or are transferred from one Department to another and this all takes time. We sincerely feel that the charges Telecom makes at the moment are quite adequate.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Telecom will not introduce a time charge on local telephone calls.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 kms away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle tax and social security fraud in the most cost-efficient and effective manner.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
About the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your Petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
Your petitioners respectfully showeth:

That the introduction of an Identity Card, to be called the Australia Card, and a National Identification Numbering System, is not in keeping with the established rights, privileges and customs of the Australian people:
It is, therefore, the will and desire of the said petitioners that the proposed legislation be neither introduced in its original form, nor amended in any way, but totally withdrawn.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBOs) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. We believe the public should be able to make telephone bill payments, applications for new services, selection of telephones and complaints, in person at a convenient and easily accessible location. Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating tax evasion, illegal immigration or social security fraud;

That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax evasion and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: 1988 Jack High Bowling Tournament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation not to televise the Jack High Bowling Tournament in 1988 is cause for distress to the 500,000 bowlers and many non bowlers who, for years, have enjoyed this interesting programme on television.

2. The unilateral decision was taken after verbal assurances had been given that the 1988 event would be televised. This action is deplored and we feel should be reversed by the parliament in the interests of your many constituents.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's Veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of Veterans and their families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to privatise some publicly owned enterprises to make them more efficient and effective and thus benefit consumers, taxpayers and the employees of the enterprises themselves.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the best known statements of the English language is: `As ye sow, so shall ye reap'; and if ever a statement were a candidate to be the epitaph of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on privatisation, it will be that one when the Centre Left and the Left of the Australian Labor Party finally bury the Prime Minister at the national conference of the Labor Party on this particular subject. The Labor Party is convulsed in a fight over privatisation. We have the humiliating spectacle of the Prime Minister of this country twice in one evening pleading with the self-identified Centre Left of his Party to save him from humiliation at the hands of his Caucus this morning on the issue of privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister is pleading with them to exercise a bit of economic common sense. He is pleading with them to recognise that the national need requires the Labor Party to reverse its historic opposition to privatisation. Why is he finding it so difficult? Why does the Prime Minister have to address the Centre Left twice? Why does he have to plead with his Party to change its attitude? It is because he and nobody else has taught the Labor Party the dangerous nonsense that its Centre Left and Left are now mouthing.

The Prime Minister is pleading with his Party for a rational debate on privatisation and he is not getting that rational debate. The Prime Minister had to be saved last night by the casting vote of Senator Peter Cook. Fancy that! The Prime Minister of this country had to be saved from the humiliation of being publicly deprivatised by none other than Senator Cook, the leader of the Centre Left, who has not forgotten, incidentally, that the Prime Minister did him out of a Ministry in the reshuffle that went on immediately after the last Federal election.

The reason why the Prime Minister is making such heavy going of it, the reason why he had to send his mate from Melbourne, Senator Gareth Evans, along to that privatisation conference last week and get him to spell out in clear terms the economic case for privatising bodies such as Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines is that the Prime Minister himself, more than anybody else, was guilty of leading a shrill, reckless and dishonest campaign in this country against the principle of privatisation.

Every single time the Prime Minister gets up in this Parliament or gets up on to a public platform anywhere in Australia, he pleads with his Party and the Australian people for a reasoned, sensible and rational debate. Honourable members heard him again at Question Time today saying, `What we do on this side of the House is to have a reasoned, sensible debate'. The Labor Party was not having a reasoned, sensible debate in May 1985 when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:

No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.

That was the Treasurer. The Prime Minister waxed even more lyrical on the subject when he addressed the Ben Chifley memorial inaugural lecture at Bathurst in September 1985. What the Prime Minister had to say then bears very interesting reading against the arguments that are now being advanced by the members of the Left and Centre Left of the Party. What those people are now doing-what Senator Bolkus is doing, what Senator Childs is doing, what the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) is doing and what, no doubt, in Cabinet the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is doing-is flinging back in Bob Hawke's teeth the very argument that he so emotionally used against the Liberal and National parties less than one year ago. This is what the Prime Minister had to say in the Chifley memorial lecture:

What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national assets, like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas. But as the people of Australia come to realise the extent of the economic and social vandalism proposed by our opponents-and indeed as part of the process of promoting that awareness-it will be necessary for us-Ben Chifley's heirs and successors-to keep fresh and green the memory, the example and the experience of this great Australian.

In other words, it is the left wing and, to some extent, the Centre Left of the Labor Party that are still following the Prime Minister towards what they see as `the light on the hill' of preserving public ownership of these bodies. If at the end of this long process, as I believe, the Prime Minister is defeated, and his colleagues are defeated, he will have nobody to blame but himself. It is he who sowed the seeds of prejudiced argument; it is he who flung rhetoric around like confetti; it is he who misled and deceived the Australian people about the privatisation policies, their meaning and their intent when they were advanced by the Liberal and National parties over the last two or three years.

The arguments for privatisation in Australia in 1987 are quite overwhelming. They have been significant and substantial arguments for some time but the case for privatisation grows stronger every month. Let me go through the arguments in favour of privatisation. Let us put to one side the nonsense that the Prime Minister peddles that the commitment of honourable members on this side of the House to privatisation is some kind of ideological binge. We have never said that we should privatise for its own sake. We have always said that we sell a public asset only if there is a clear public benefit in doing so. We have always said that we have to run the test of public and consumer benefit over the proposed sale before making an affirmative decision.

Does anybody seriously argue in Australia now that the public interest would not be served by the sale of Australian Airlines? Does anybody seriously imagine that we can rationally complete the deregulation of the Australian airlines industry without passing Australian Airlines from public into private ownership? The only way we can provide the voracious capital needs of Australian Airlines in the future is to privatise it. There is no other way, unless we are prepared to stand up to the Australian people and say, `We will not reduce your taxes. We will not provide essential social services. In other words, we will give priority over and above reducing the taxpayers' burden in this country to providing injections of public money into the capital of bodies such as Australian Airlines'. The argument does not stop at Australian Airlines; it runs on to bodies such as Qantas Airways Ltd, Aussat Pty Ltd, and so the list goes on.

Let me take the opportunity of saying to the House that we in the Liberal and National parties are committed to a policy of privatisation which is based upon the principle of first inquiring whether there would be a public benefit and whether consumers would benefit. Do we believe in minimising political interference in output pricing and investment decisions? Do we believe in giving management the freedom to manage? Do we believe in improving the operational efficiency of these bodies? Do we want to make them open? Do we want to put into their hands the range of capital funding services that are available to private companies operating commercially?

Let us remember the enormous budgetary problem that is looming if this Government does not undertake a policy of major privatisation. Over the next few years alone there will be demands of $1 billion to $2 billion on the Budget of this country unless bodies such as Qantas and Australian Airlines are privatised. If honourable members do not take my word on that matter, they should take the word of Senator Gareth Evans. This matter was self-evident 12 months ago; it was self-evident 18 months ago. The criminal blame in this argument lies with the Prime Minister for having poisoned the debate for so long that we have lost two or three years in gearing up for privatisation. We will now have to wait almost another year before the Australian Labor Party finally makes up its mind. If the Labor Party decides to go down the path of privatisation, history will record that it wasted two to three years in making up its mind on this very important issue.

The advantages of privatisation are to be found not only in the fact that privatisation removes the call on Budgets for injections of large amounts of capital. The advantage of privatisation, as has been demonstrated in other countries-and will, no doubt, be demonstrated in Australia if this Government has the political and economic courage to embark upon such a policy-is that the greater competition it brings about benefits consumers of services that are provided by the privatised body. It is only through exposing so many of these bodies to the rigors of the market-place and to competition that greater benefits for Australian consumers will ensue.

That is why the Liberal and National parties support a policy of privatising Australian Airlines, and of selling at least 49 per cent of Qantas-and we are currently reviewing whether that 49 per cent ought not be extended to 100 per cent. We support the privatisation of domestic airport terminals. We support the privatisation of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, 49 per cent of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia), 100 per cent of Aussat, and the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, Medibank Private and the Australian Pipeline Authority. As my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Peacock) has announced, we are also undertaking a review of whether we should add to that list the privatisation of whole or part of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation.

There is no ambiguity; there is no squeamishness; there is no going to water; there is no backflipping or double standards from the Liberal and National parties on the issue of privatisation. We understand the economic need of the country. We have nailed our colours to the mast and we are saying to the Prime Minister: `Where do you and those who follow you stand on this issue?'. It is pretty clear where the left wing of the Labor Party stands on this issue because after today's Caucus meeting a statement was issued by the Executive of the parliamentary Left and it was signed by 10 left wing members of parliament, including Nick Bolkus, Bruce Childs, Lewis Kent, John Saunderson and former Minister, Arthur Gietzelt. This is what the statement of that terrific 10--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was Gerry?
—Gerry was there in spirit. Gerry is constrained by his ministerial responsibilities, which he takes very seriously. This is what those 10 had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It was an important victory which called on Ministers to prepare proposals which would strengthen and enhance authorities in full public ownership.

The statement went on to urge the trade union movement and the Party's rank and file to step up their opposition to privatisation. There is no doubt in the Left's mind what today's Caucus meeting meant. It meant that the Prime Minister has been comprehensively rolled. His Party had thrown him a lifebuoy that was full of holes. He is floundering around and the factions are at war on this issue. The reason they are at war-this should never be forgotten by anybody in this House or any member of the rank and file of the Australian Labor party-is that the Labor Party believed its Prime Minister 12 months ago when he said that privatisation was economic vandalism. He sold them the argument, and now when he gets down on his knees and pleads with them to change their attitude, they are turning deaf ears. They are saying, `Bob, 12 months ago it was economic vandalism. Now you are saying it is economic nirvana. Twelve months ago you said that it would destroy our political faith; you are now saying that it is necessary for the modernisation of the Australian economy. Why should we believe you now when we believed you 12 months ago and you have turned your back on us?'.

The Prime Minister's deceit of a year ago has caught up with him. If he loses this argument and Australia is the loser, if our Budget goes back into deficit and we are denied the tax cuts to which we are entitled, he and he alone will carry the blame for that deception.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition's time has expired. I call the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer.
—Where is the senior Minister? Why doesn't he come in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is entitled to hear senior Ministers when it has senior arguments that are worth answering. This Opposition continually makes a mockery of this House because the reality is that this matter of public importance is a rehash of a privatisation argument that was put by a shadow Minister less than a week ago.

SPEECH.PARA: We have listened with some interest to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) telling us that he and the Opposition-let me quote his own words-`understand the economic needs of this country'. Let me repeat that: he understands the economic needs of this country. One does not have to be an economic wizard or whiz kid to realise that what we got from the Leader of the Opposition today was precisely the same arguments that were trotted out to the people of Australia less than four months ago. He does not even have the decency to update them. All that has happened is that his speech writer got to work yesterday before the Caucus meeting--before the Leader of the Opposition knew either the quality or the nature of the debate that took place within the parliamentary Labor Party. The Leader of the Opposition trotted out the same old remedies and the same old arguments. Let me quote back to him his own biblical reference: `As ye sow, so shall ye reap'. Nothing could be truer in respect of this Leader of the Opposition, who showed today that he has not learned a single thing from when he was Treasurer or from the last election. As Treasurer in the discredited Fraser Government, this man who says he understands the economic needs of Australia left a legacy of double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and a prospective Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion. That is the legacy of the gentleman who now parades around this House trying to convince this motley group of backbenchers that he understands the economic needs of Australia.

In the July election campaign, just four months ago, he offered the people of Australia a tax bribe of $6 billion. He promised massive unspecified expenditure cuts and a massive privatisation program. Even then, the man who now says `I understand the economic needs of Australia' could not get his sums right. Do honourable members believe him now? They could not believe him then and they cannot believe him now. It is not surprising that the people of Australia less than four months ago overwhelmingly rejected these sleazy policies. After the election, the new shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), undertook to take the Opposition's economic policies in a new direction. But this has now been abandoned. The Deputy Leader and former Leader of the Opposition understood that there was no way that the people of Australia would accept the kind of pap that had been dished out to them by the Leader of the Opposition in the election campaign. Four months later, less than three weeks ago, in this Parliament the Opposition is still arguing the same old rhetoric about privatisation.

The Opposition is still saying that the solution to our problem is to have massive expenditure cuts. But it will not tell us, as it would not tell us during the election campaign, where those cuts are to be made. Oh no, honourable members opposite would not want to upset or excite anybody. They thought: `We will just talk in the same kinds of glib generalities and say that there have to be more expenditure cuts'. I would have hoped-and I think in the interests of the people of Australia we all would have hoped-that honourable members opposite would have learned something from their election defeat. I would have hoped that they would have gone back to the drawing board, because this Parliament needs an Opposition that is able to come through with policies that have been thought through-policies which will make a positive contribution to meeting the economic needs of Australia. But what have we received? Week after week, month after month, we have seen a recycling of the same old material. The new shadow Treasurer, the former Leader of the Opposition, has been rolled by the New Right.

Let us talk about divisions. There is no Opposition in Australia that is as divided as this Opposition. If one does not agree with this Leader of the Opposition one has no place in the shadow Ministry. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee and Finance and Public Administration, I present the report of the Committee on the Australian iron and steel industry, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure began in early 1987 to examine the efficiency of Government expenditure into the Australian iron and steel industry. This expenditure was encapsulated in the steel industry plan which was designed to create a long term viable steel industry, one which would provide job security for its employees and become internationally competitive. Given the steel industry's importance to Australia's industrial base and to the economy, the recovery of the steel industry should be important to every Australian, not just those in the steel regions who are directly affected by the industry. The election was called before the Expenditure Committee could table its report. The newly constituted Finance and Public Administration Committee realised the importance of the information and decided to complete the inquiry as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of these factors, some of the information in this report is rapidly becoming outdated by events. Although the report has been updated as much as possible, the last formal hearing was held on 29 May 1987. Nevertheless, both committees realised the value of such an inquiry, and we have tried to table the report as early as possible in the new Parliament. We feel that it will assist the Steel Industry Authority (SIA) in its current review of the plan and sincerely hope it will assist the industry in overcoming its major problems.

The Committee has found that the plan has indeed stimulated the steel industry's return to profitability from its poor economic base in 1982-83 prior to the plan. We are convinced that, without the security and incentive provided by the plan, the industry would not have had the confidence to embark on its investment program and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) would probably have closed at least one of its integrated plants. I note with interest recent comments by BHP senior management on this particular issue and I shall address that matter later in my remarks.

The major part of the Commonwealth's expenditure into the steel industry has been in the form of bounties. These bounty payments have helped to contain steel prices and have provided significant benefits to downstream steel users. So far, bounty payments have cost the Government less than half the amount originally envisaged-$117m compared to a possible maximum of $250m. The lower expenditure on bounty payments, combined with the fact that the level of government assistance to Australian industry is far less than the level of assistance that overseas Governments give to their steel industries, led the Committee to conclude that the industry's recovery has been stimulated efficiently and effectively.

We also found, however, that factors outside the plan have been a significant force in the industry's recovery. In financial terms, these other factors may have contributed more to the industry's recovery than the bounty payments. The benefits derived from the sustained depreciation of the Australian dollar, the investment allowance and accelerated depreciation provisions have been considerable. The industry has also benefited from the worldwide steel industry recovery and signs of improvement in the industry's domestic performance were already evident before the plan started. The Australian economy, manufacturing production and domestic steel production all moved back into growth in the September quarter of 1983. Nevertheless, the plan provided market security and incentive, enabling BHP's $1.4 billion investment program and the corresponding investment by other sectors of the steel industry. More importantly from the Committee's viewpoint, the recovery has been stimulated efficiently.

Despite the industry's recovery, we found that a number of problems still confront it, the most serious and pressing of these being the unacceptable level of industrial disputation. Although the unions' performance was excellent during 1984 and 1985, their actions in 1986 and the first half of 1987 led the Committee to conclude that the unions were no longer meeting their commitments and were in breach of dispute settling procedures under the plan. This view has been highlighted recently in the Steel Industry Authority's annual report and in statements made by BHP.

Port Kembla, I am particularly sad to say, is the area of most concern. At Port Kembla, the level of industrial disputation reached pre-plan levels. During April, May and June this year, Port Kembla alone was responsible for over 90 per cent of the total man-hours lost at BHP, which in turn has prompted BHP to announce that it will not proceed with the $160m rebuild of its No. 4 blast furnace at Port Kembla and would not invest any more money in the steel industry unless the industrial climate improved. Whilst acknowledging that there has been such an improvement in the second half of 1987, nevertheless concern must be expressed at statements last week by the management that BHP might close its operation at Port Kembla. Threats of this type do not assist in facilitating an improved industrial relations climate. As I have indicated previously in debate on this issue, I hope that both management and the trade union movement associated with the steel industry can come to terms with this problem.

There is now just over 12 months of the steel industry plan remaining, after which there will be no security net for the industry. The future of the plan and the future of the industry lie largely in the hands of the unions. The Steel Industry Authority, which is responsible for monitoring each party's adherence to the plan and encouraging co-operation and dialogue between each of the parties, has been relatively ineffective in alleviating the industrial situation. We have recommended that the Australian Council of Trade Unions accept overall responsibility for the unions' commitment to the plan and take whatever action it can to get greater commitment at shop floor level. The Committee hopes that this will overcome some of the sectional interests that are currently threatening the plan.

It concerns the Committee that the SIA has decided to stop monitoring the unions' adherence to the wage settling commitment, with no real explanation. Unless there is an agreement between the SIA and the Minister, of which the Committee is unaware, to cease monitoring this aspect of the plan, the SIA should perform its role and resume monitoring this aspect of the plan.

Yet the process of industrial relations is not a one-way street. The SIA has said that the Australian steel industry has the potential to be- come the world's lowest cost steel producer and potentially a competitive exporter. However, the realisation of the potential is almost entirely within the hands of the industry. The world steel market is extremely competitive and, in many cases, heavily assisted and protected by governments. The future of the Australian steel industry lies with its management of capital and manpower. Further productivity gains are essential for the industry and totally dependent on its labor force. Failing commitment can easily jeopardise the hard-won gains made so far, and at worst jeopardise the industry's existence. This is still the most important step the industry must take.

The Committee has made a number of recommendations to assist the domestic steel industry, which I will briefly outline. We are concerned with the inadequacy of the existing anti-dumping mechanism. One of the Government's commitments under the plan was the establishment of an effective fast-track, anti-dumping system, responsibility for which was given to both the Steel Industry Authority and the Australian Customs Service (ACS). We found that all sectors of the industry were dissatisfied with the system; that an efficient mechanism was never put into place; and that neither body was accepting responsibility for the mechanism. To ensure that an efficient mechanism is in place we have recommended that the roles of the SIA and ACS in this area are clearly delineated; that a clear set of policy guidelines are developed by the ACS to ensure systematic investigation procedures and to help the industry to prepare its case; and that recommendations of the Gruen Report on the Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, tabled in March 1986, are acted upon.

Professor Gruen made a number of recommendations on anti-dumping measures and, although the Government has accepted most of the recommendations, as yet not one has been implemented. Most recommendations are still awaiting legislation to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. Also in relation to anti-dumping, the Committee would like to see strict deadlines for the completion of preliminary and final findings, some of which have been taking up to two years for a response.

A related issue is that of secondary dumping of steel feed, which affects downstream steel users. The problem is that secondary dumping is almost impossible to prove, involves considerable work and has little chance of success. We have recommended that the secondary dumping issue be immediately referred to the Industries Assistance Commission for advice on whether longer-term anti-dumping action is desirable.

The Committee has also made a recommendation on developing country preferences for steel imports. We can see no justification for the present situation, which allows reduced tariff imports from countries possessing technologically superior steel industries to Australia's and which are heavily protected by their own governments. We have recommended that the whole area of granting developing country preferences be reviewed and, specifically, that the remaining preferences for steel imports from South Korea be removed.

We also found no justification for the continuation of an agreement between the United States of America and Australia, restraining Australia's exports to the United States. The Committee believes that the export restraint agreement can cut back potential steel exports to Australia's disadvantage. Although it is not having a great effect on exports at present, due to current production difficulties by BHP and lower production because of industrial disputation, in a revitalised industry it could considerably limit potential exports. We recommend that, at the expiry of the current agreement in 1989, the relevant Ministers-that is, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-re-examine the need for Australia to enter into another agreement with the United States of America. If another agreement is unavoidable, we would like to see the export level recalculated on a more appropriate base year.

In conjunction with the steel industry plan, the Committee examined the steel regions assistance program, which, although separate from the plan, was implemented at the same time. The program is providing $102m over a period of five years to assist the major steel regions in economic diversification and to expand employment opportunities. One of the most important aspects of this program to the regions was the tourism component. Although some of our recommendations have been largely overtaken by events-and I will not say too much now-the essence of the problem was inadequate local consultation, a convoluted approval process ranging from local to State to Federal governments, and outstanding expenditure for this component. We have made recommendations to overcome these problems and perhaps to indicate potential problems in relation to future regional assistance packages.

Finally, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this inquiry. In particular, I thank those members of the original sub-committee, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford), the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who are no longer members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration; the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who is a continuing member and I am sure will contribute great things to the present Committee; the Committee secretariat and in particular the Committee Secretary, Monica Telesny, and Mr Peter Ratas, Ms Kelly Edwards and Ms Kylie Freer. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you have just intimated, there are two Bills before the House.
