The actual circumstances, however, the manner and form of the Government's actions in this matter, are not something in which there is any more consistency than there was in the privatisation debate that occurred a little earlier in the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the House of Representatives Hansard back in the days when the Australian Labor Party was where it will be as soon as we can possibly get it there-back in opposition-contains some interesting observations by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Given that the present Treasurer seems to believe in the past in a way that really does not enhance his reputation, I thought it would be worthwhile at the beginning of this debate to refer to the remarks that he made when he occupied the position that I now occupy-that is, spokesman for the Opposition on resources. Surprisingly enough, there was a similar Excise Tariff Amendment Bill before the House and it seemed to me to be very appropriate that, therefore, his remarks might be borne in mind when considering these changes in the excise formula; for they essentially are to change under the present legislation from using the import parity pricing base to using a new base, a base that is determined by calculating the excise on the volume weighted average prices realised for crude oil sales. Of course, only part of Australia's crude oil production is excisable-that produced by Bass Strait producers. So the form is to change from one based on import parity pricing to one based on volume weighted average prices, and I shall speak a little more about that in a moment.

The introduction of import parity pricing was the circumstance of that Excise Tariff Amendment Bill referred to in the House of Representatives Hansard of 2 April 1981 when the present Treasurer said:
We-
that is, the Labor Party-
. . . are opposed to import party pricing. We do not believe Australians should be forced to pay through the nose for their own oil. The Opposition-
that is, the Labor Party-

. . . is opposed also to the use of the crude oil levy as a mechanism for taxing oil producers. It is inefficient and inequitable and should be removed and replaced by a properly designed resources rent tax which is neutral in its effect, efficient, and a better mechanism to divide this wealth between the companies and the community.

One of the interesting parts of this debate is that there is, in fact, an increase in the excise. So much for the Government and the Treasurer in particular-the man who, above all, is responsible for administering this particular part of the legislation. So much for his desire to get rid of it. Indeed, we now find ourselves in a position where, as a result of the increase in excise, over a period of years the Government's dependence on crude oil as a source of revenue will continue to be high. I am told that, as a result of some negotiations with the Bass Strait oil producers, there will be an increase in excise from 6c a litre to 20.83c a litre as from mid-October 1987.

Of course, members on this side of the House have always said that import parity pricing was right but, equally, we say both automatic indexation, which is referred to in these Bills, and the dependence of the Government on fuel excise have a cost, and the Treasurer recognised that cost when he was in opposition. But he has totally ignored it in the years that he has been in government. Not only has he ignored it, but he has also significantly added to the cost the average motorist pays for petrol and oil products because of the way in which the Labor Government has depended so heavily upon a tax which the Treasurer himself acknowledged was inefficient and inequitable and should be removed.
It is interesting that in those days, in opposition, this Treasurer said:
We have a sleight-of-hand policy, a tax by stealth levied at the bowsers instead of being levied directly through the tax system or through incomes . . .

How right that is. Yet here is this Treasurer denying money for roads. I see my colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), whose electorate roads, like mine, are absolutely deplorable. They are deplorable because this Government has reduced the amount of money that goes to the States to develop their road systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like him to travel to Bulahdelah on the Pacific Highway.
—The Bulahdelah-Pacific Highway route is one; I can tell the House about a few others in New England.
—They ripped that up and now it is going to gravel.
—That is so right, as my colleague says. The Treasurer continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The trite argument advanced by the Government that one needs to have a high price-the world price-for oil discovered 10 years ago in order to keep exploration going is nonsense.
It is amazing how everything that he said in that debate has now been reversed. What he said then was:
Another aspect of the Government's crude oil policy which needs a mention is the nature of the crude oil levy.
Just listen to this:

All levies are arbitrary, inefficient and inequitable. They create distortions in investment decisions, in particular, in the bringing into reduction of smaller pools of oil and in the extraction of maximum possible levels of oil from producing fields.

Those remarks are absolutely applicable to the Bills now before the House. There is little doubt that the circumstances have changed, but the circumstances of this present Labor Government have changed to the point where all those homilies of the Treasurer have been ignored and excise today is more and more the agency of the Australian Taxation Office. More and more those words of the Treasurer, when he talked about `a sleight-of-hand policy', about `a tax by stealth levied at the bowsers'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—And my colleague from Tasmania the honourable member for Franklin, agrees-are statements on matters that affect the ordinary men and women of Australia. Whilst we are totally in favour of deregulation and whilst we support these two pieces of legislation, we say to the Government that the way in which it is increasing excise and the way in which excise itself is becoming more and more a vehicle from which the Government funds its extravagant programs are matters which the Opposition believes the people of Australia should have brought to their attention.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, of course, in the changes to the formula a number of intricacies which really do not bear elaborate scrutiny in this place. There are, in the introduction of this volware base, as it is called, for determining excise, a number of statistical changes which I am told have generally been accepted by the industry. However, a number of aspects of the changes need to be considered. The first is that if there is, as is suggested, to be a price reduction at the bowsers as a result of these changes, it needs to be understood that it does not come from any great generosity on the part of the Government. What it does do, of course, is reflect the actual change resulting from the volware determination. In other words, the reference price will be adjusted for relevant factors such as movements in world oil prices and changes in exchange rates. Those factors may lead to short term reductions in fuel prices.

But there are two dimensions of this equation which people need to keep in mind. The first, and obviously the one that is of most sensitivity, is the price of petrol at the bowser, the price of fuel at the tank, the cost to the motorist, the cost to the energy consumer, if he uses not only petrol but also distillate, fuel oil or any other products emanating from the oil industry. That is the sensitive part and it is the one where government intervention has made the price so dear. But the other end is the one which led us in government to introduce import parity pricing. That is what we see as the absolute necessity to encourage exploration and production of oil.

I believe there is a great deal that needs to be examined in respect of where we go in terms of future exploration. Indeed, part of our concern in the details of these changes is the way in which there could be an effect on small oil producers. We certainly support deregulation, but the Government has been involved in rhetoric and has said that it will look after the small oil producers. On our side of the House, we say that we would be looking at the trade practices legislation to ensure, through its mechanisms, if there is need to help the small oil producers, that there is a technique that is sufficient to be able to ensure that not only the large producers but also the small oil producers can continue.

Recently there has been a significant increase in on-shore exploration, but I am concerned that there should be a continuation of exploration off-shore. Sadly, the record off-shore has not been as good as it has been on-shore. Frankly, with the changes, particularly following the introduction of the resource rent tax, we see the circumstances of disencouragement and of disincentive pursued to the point where it is not only going to be extraordinarily doubtful that Australia's self-sufficiency or reasonable self-sufficiency can be maintained into the 1990s, but we will have what has been said will be a $3 billion Budget deficit that will creep in as a result of the change in dependence on domestic produced oil to imported oil.

All those are matters which, in the consideration of the Government's total oil package, have to be put into perspective. This particular package, of course, is a significant element of the deregulation of the market, but the circumstances of the introduction of the resource rent tax and the way in which the Government is pursuing its policy make us concerned that there will be problems in the future. The Government seems to be almost totally ignorant of them and certainly not prepared to do very much about them. But, of course, the Government will say that part of this package relates to the incentive that it will give to new oil discoveries by exempting the first 30 million barrels of oil from on-shore discoveries and that they will be excised free regardless of when production started.

I am told that new off-shore projects will also be able to claim the first 30 million barrels of production free of excise. I am told that there have been some changes in the application of that particular concession. If that is so, and if the Government is now in any way to water down that concession-the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) should advise the House when he responds in this debate, which I trust that he will do-and there is some doubt about that full concession, particularly for off-shore explorations, there will be real problems for the industry in the future. Honourable members should understand that this will affect the level of future exploration in a way which cannot help the industry.

There are also within the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill some problems with respect to safeguards to ensure that the prices realised by domestic crude producers in fact reflect the best on offer, be it from a domestic refiner marketer or an off-shore bidder. A producer should not have the right, according to some sectors of the industry, to sell crude off-shore at a discount when a domestic buyer is willing to offer more and expect the Commonwealth to subsidise the discount sale by reducing its excise share.

In other words, there are a number of formula consequences, one being the extent to which small oil producers are affected; a second being the degree to which there will be adequate stimuli for future exploration; and the third being the degree to which in some instances sales might be made off-shore at a discount, thereby leading to the Commonwealth subsidising the sale by reducing its excise share. There are, therefore, within this legislation, a number of matters which the Government needs to consider and comment on. However, there are a number of other aspects of the legislation which I wish to comment on briefly. There is reference in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) to the change in circumstances applicable to duty on aviation gasolene, or avgas. I have been told that long ago the Minister for Transport in the last Hawke Ministry apparently refused to accept industry proposals that there should be a switch from the levying of air navigation charges to the imposition of a levy on aviation gasolene. However, this charge has been incorporated in legislation on this occasion. The then Minister for Transport should tell the House why he refused to acknowledge that change. According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Science and Small Business, landing charges will still be levied on general aviation.

The National and Liberal parties are concerned that general aviation remain viable. We are concerned that there should be no disincentive for those who provide a very important alternate transport service around Australia. They should not be unduly discouraged. If there is a switch from navigation charges to an increased price in aviation gasolene, we hope that that will not mean that there will be a continued increase in price to the point where general aviation becomes less and less viable. However, as I have said, the industry originally made this suggestion about four years ago. I gather that the industry is quite pleased with the proposal and, therefore, the Opposition offers no objection to it.

However, a number of other aspects of the legislation deserve to be considered in relation to deregulation. To us deregulation is still only a very small way along the line. For example, we are concerned that the Prices Surveillance Authority continues to intervene in the whole of the industry. We think that if the Government were fair dinkum about deregulation it would have said in this package of legislation that it would scrap the Prices Surveillance Authority. It sets maximum recommended wholesale prices for petroleum products which are uniform between capital cities. We believe that the way in which that price uniformity is set should be determined by the market-place.

Of course, those of us who represent rural areas are concerned that the prices in our areas always seem to be so much higher than they are in the cities. Rarely do we see discounting in our parts of the world. We have seen the incredible circumstance on occasions when there has been a petrol price differential of 10c a litre between one end of my electorate to the other. That, of course, is partly because the New South Wales Government is levying absolutely ridiculously high excise charges whereas the benign Queensland Government is recognising the degree to which it is important that there be no additional surcharge on motorists. There are problems as far as the Prices Surveillance Authority is concerned. It would be a very good idea for the Government, if it is looking seriously at deregulation, to look at eliminating the Prices Surveillance Authority.

A second part of the problem is the whole question of labour costs and the general circumstances that apply in the maintenance of the special relationship between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government. Until the Government deregulates labour and the price of labour in Australia-deregulation in the oil industry, deregulation of the financial system or deregulation anywhere else-industry will be only partly effective. A particularly significant impact of deregulation is in relation to shipping.

The imminent decline of Bass Strait oil production will result in less demand for coastal shipping and increased demand for ships carrying oil over longer distances. Under deregulation this process will be accelerated and in those changed circumstances it is important that we understand that the charges imposed on Australian flag vessels make their operation absolutely impossible. Their manning scales are too high and they operate in a closeted environment which makes them totally non-competitive. These things cannot be sustained. Unless that part of the industry is also deregulated, the costs to motorists and the cost of oil will continue to be far higher than they should be. Australian flag vessels must become internationally competitive or, in the view of the coalition parties, we will need to look at removing altogether the protection that is now given to them under the Flags Act.

A deregulated oil market and the enforced use of high cost Australian vessels would certainly increase import prices and reduce export prices. Higher import prices will boost domestic inflation. Increased petrol prices will, of course, flow to consumers and overall they will reduce the international competitiveness of Australian industry with higher import charges. Moreover, effects such as these would not diminish over time because if Australian flag vessels were to receive a guaranteed share of the market, as is now required, their incentive to become internationally competitive would go altogether.

These Bills reflect what those of us in the Liberal and National parties see as a worthwhile step towards deregulation. We are concerned about a number of aspects in the legislation. We are certainly concerned about the degree to which there seems to be an increase in the oil levy in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). I am told that the long term effect of this will be an increase in the government take. As I have said, the increase is somewhere from 6c per litre to 21c per litre as at the mid-October 1987 date. The volware figure and the fact that there is a change from import parity pricing and the lifting of some assistance-the Bass Strait subsidy and so on-mean that there will be an impact on small producers. We are concerned that apparently they will get no more than words from the Government. Small producers are likely to be adversely affected.

We are concerned about the long term effect of these changes on maintaining production from smaller wells and smaller oil fields as well as large ones, but above all we are concerned that as a result of the introduction of the resource rent tax (RRT) in the other part of this package the Government is providing a real disincentive for future exploration. Australia must find more oil. We must encourage exploration off-shore as well as on-shore and the RRT will be only a discouragement to those who are seeking oil off-shore. The Opposition does not oppose these two Bills. We look forward to further moves towards deregulation right across the whole of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks in this cognate debate to the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill. It is worth reflecting on the words of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who introduced this legislation, because in his second reading speech he succinctly summarised the purpose of this Bill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides for an effective and equitable system of collecting excise on crude oil production. It is a major component in the implementation of the Government's decision to deregulate the Australian crude oil market.

That encapsulates perfectly the Government's view of this legislation and what it seeks to achieve. The House has already debated the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill which were a package of measures to enable the implementation of arrangements for the transition of marketing of Australian produced crude oil from a regulated to a deregulated or free market scheduled for 1 January 1988. These arrangements will be known as the Bass Strait freight adjustment scheme. It was my pleasure to talk on that package of legislation when it was debated in the House recently. I am also pleased to see that the honourable members who will debate the legislation before us today are in the House and will follow me in this debate. Obviously we will go over a lot of the same ground. I will try to be a little briefer than I was the other night and I suspect that other members will also be briefer.

Some refiners will be underlifted against their Bass Strait allocation obligations as of 1 January 1988 and they will need to clear their underlift in 1988 before being permitted to purchase Bass Strait crude oil on the free market. Therefore, it is necessary to implement some transition arrangements to ensure equity between oil refiners. Moving from a regulated to a deregulated or free market is a complex process especially if one's priority in doing so is to maintain equity. This is certainly the priority of this Government. However, as is evidenced by the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill and the package of Bass Strait freight Bills, this Government is committed to a smooth transition from a regulated to a deregulated market and is attempting to accommodate the concerns of all involved.

I was pleased to hear in the contribution made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) this afternoon that he acknowledged that the industry had been consulted upon the proposed changes in this legislation and was broadly in agreement with them. Again, this goes to the very heart of this Government's approach to legislation. It is one of consultation with the parties affected and of trying to come to terms with the concerns that they may express about the implications of legislation and endeavouring to meet those concerns. The Government's decision to move to a deregulated market arose out of a review of the present import parity pricing arrangements. It involved the State governments, producers and refiners, trade unions and consumers. Again, that follows from what I have just said about the process of consultation. Of course, we must remember that the present import parity pricing arrangements were put in place by a former conservative government. But I certainly acknowledge that they were maintained by this Government.

The decision was based on a number of reasons. Firstly, we are running out of Bass Strait oil and, as we all recognise, production is slowing every year. In the absence of major new discoveries, this will mean a steady rise in the volume of imported crude oil. Thus, there will be a push from overseas markets for Australia to move to a free market. As I indicated in debate the other evening, it is my belief and that of the Government that it is best to move now and reap any benefits available and also to prepare our industry structure for that inevitable day when our Bass Strait oil reserves are exhausted. Secondly, in a deregulated market, the average Bass Strait crude oil prices could be expected initially to fall between $A1 and $A4. Even a fall of $2.50 a barrel would result in petrol prices falling by around 1.3c per litre. This Government is committed to passing on to consumers the full benefit of any crude oil price reductions. I am sure that that will have a great deal of appeal for the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who will follow in the debate tonight, because I know that he is one who is greatly concerned about petrol pricing policies in Australia, not just in Tasmania. I am hopeful that he will take notice of this particular part of the legislation.

Thirdly, it is possible that positive balance of payments effects will flow from this decision. Under deregulation refiners could purchase different grades of imported crude oil suitable for their needs at a lower cost than current domestic prices. Our relatively high quality crude oil could be exported at a higher price than that of imports, resulting in a net balance of payments gain. Obviously this would represent a greater efficiency in the use of the nation's oil resources. Efficiency in the use of resources is particularly important when dealing with a resource which is, sadly, becoming depleted. Finally, the Government has received assurances from refiners that deregulation will not result in the closure of any Australian refinery and, further, that they will continue to lift the output of small producers in a timely manner and at fair market prices. This will ensure that small producers are not disadvantaged by deregulation and, of course importantly for all honourable members, that people who are working within the oil industry are not disadvantaged and perhaps thrown into unemployment.

Specifically, this Bill fits into the Government's plan for deregulating the market by providing that the revenue flow to the Commonwealth is maintained through an excise system for crude oil based on prices achieved in a free market. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will have powers to determine the price to be used as the basis for crude oil excise and, in particular, to determine the volume weighted average of realised-that is, volware-prices for sales of Bass Strait crude oil. The final volware price for each month will be the final price basis for crude oil excise for that month.

I also take this opportunity in the debate to indicate that the fact that the Government is moving to a freer or deregulated market in this particular area is not a sign that the Government is walking away from its commitment to provide a more efficient use of resources and pass on benefits to the general public. It is interesting, again, that the Leader of the National Party raised in his contribution this afternoon this whole question of public ownership of assets and so on and tried to bring into the consideration of that particular debate this question of the deregulation of the crude oil market. Let me say that this measure, in my view, is an example of how by making a freer market the consumer of Australia can benefit. Consumers will benefit in the future from our having a much more efficient allocation system and from our providing for exploration and improvements in the crude oil area. This is something which, in my view, should not be weighed down by any philosophical considerations.

It is quite interesting to examine the financial impact of this particular Bill. The Leader of the National Party made some comment that there was a financial disincentive to the package of Bills that is being debated here. If one goes to the section dealing with the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum which accompanied the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill 1987, one sees that the financial impact of deregulating Australia's crude oil market will in fact be dependent upon the crude oil price movements in the free market. As I have indicated, in a deregulated market prices might be expected to fall by between $A1 and $A4. On the basis of taking an average of those two figures-something like $2.50 a barrel-the drop in government revenue in 1987-88 and 1988-89 is expected to be $100m and $168m respectively. This drop in government revenue will be passed on to the consumer. There will be no offset in product excise adjustment to recoup revenue forgone by the Government as a result of the drop in crude oil prices upon deregulation. So I just point that out to the Leader of the National Party and I hope that he takes that into consideration.

In conclusion, let me just say that I concur entirely with the comments made by the Minister his second reading speech that this system that the Government is putting in place is both effective and equitable. It will lead to a real reduction in petrol prices, it will see something being passed on to the consumer and, as I have indicated in the debate, we have had a range of Bills in respect of the oil industry in Australia over the last few sessions. I believe the Government is approaching the matter in a very rational way. I certainly commend this package of Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —To pick up a point made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), these two Bills-the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Petrol Excise (Prices) Bill-are the last in a whole series of Bills that will bring dramatic changes to the petroleum industry in this country. Indeed, all of us are hopeful that the consumer will be the end beneficiary, but that remains to be seen. I wish to talk about the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill 1987. As the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) has already said, this Bill enjoys the support of the Opposition. We broadly support the deregulation moves made by the Government within the oil industry. The deregulation of crude oil marketing on 1 January 1988 abolishes the old allocation scheme for crude oil and import parity pricing (IPP). I think the allocation scheme has been in place since about 1965. Thus, the import parity prices will no longer be used as the basis for allocated sales of domestic crude oil for the calculation of crude oil excise.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy with the power to determine from 1 January firstly the prices to be used as the basis for crude oil excise and, in particular, to determine the volume weighted average of realised prices for sales of Bass Strait crude oil, described in the legislation as the volware system. The final volware price for each month will be the final price basis for crude oil excise for that particular month.

That is a complicated set of provisions, but it needs to be put in perspective by looking at the background. Changes to the marketing arrangement for crude oil to apply from 1 January 1988 were announced in June 1987 by the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. The refiners and crude oil producers will be permitted to negotiate freely the quantities and prices of crude oil they buy and sell without government interference. We certainly welcome that. The deregulation decision was made on the basis of assurances from oil refiners that they would continue to lift the output of the very small producers in a timely manner and at fair market related prices. We hope that that will be the case. As the Leader of the National Party pointed out, and as I have pointed out previously when speaking on this type of legislation, the small producers are vulnerable. It remains to be seen how vulnerable they are. One would hope that their produce will be lifted and refined by the major refiners.

The Government also claims that oil refiners also gave assurances that there would be no closures of refineries as a result of deregulation and that they would maintain their existing arrangement for Australian flag shipping. The new marketing arrangements require a change in the basis for calculating crude oil excises. Previously, the IPP was used for sales under domestic allocation arrangements while excise on exports was calculated on realised prices. From January a system based on the realised prices will be use for all crude oil existing calculations. That includes exports, as I understand it. The Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, might like to clarify that point. As I said, calculating the prices is reasonably complicated. The Bill is directed towards oil production from Bass Strait as this is currently the only area producing oil attracting the excise.

The Bill underlines the importance of Bass Strait oil production. Therein lies an interesting admission. We just heard the last speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), state that IPP had some benefits, that exploration was enhanced by the introduction of the IPP system and that the domestic production of oil also benefited by the introduction by the Fraser Government of IPP. Yet at the time that IPP was put into place we were subjected, whilst we were on the other side of the House, to unending vilification. Who did it come from? It came from the master of vilification techniques in this House, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who on that occasion was the shadow Minister for minerals and energy. He sat at the feet of Rex Connor for many years. He probably learnt something. One thing he learnt was how to change his mind. He has changed his mind completely from the position he took then. I would like to put on the record several quotes from the Treasurer. In 1977 he said:
Labor is determined to straighten out the (oil) industry once and for all so the Australian public will be better served with a more efficient, cheaper marketing system for petroleum.
They are laudable sentiments. He went on to criticise the IPP mechanism. He said again in 1979:
A Commonwealth Labor Government will break the nexus with the Fraser Government's import parity pricing policy so that Australian oil will be cheaper than the world price.

That is what he said. But did the Government do it? It did not do it because when the then Opposition got to the treasury bench it saw the benefits of IPP. We applaud the move towards deregulation of the refining stage in crude oil but the Government must admit that we were right when we put that IPP mechanism into place. It was a difficult time for this country. We can argue until the cows come home whether the money ought to have been applied in the way that it was. In any event, it did have dramatic and important effects on exploration for the domestic scene both on-shore and off-shore. Explorers knew that if they found oil they would get a reasonable return for it because the price through the IPP mechanism guaranteed that. In 1979 the Treasurer said that `the great petrol rip-off must be curbed. Only Labor will stop this pernicious tax by stealth'. Also in 1979 we had the famous quote:
Mr Fraser has virtually established a branch of the Australian Taxation Office at every petrol pump.
Do not the realities of being in government bring it home to people how difficult it is and what is involved? Also in 1979, it was reported in the Age newspaper on 17 December:
Petrol would be up to 30 per cent cheaper under a Labor government, Labor's energy spokesman Mr Keating said yesterday.

The Treasurer learnt the lesson. It ought to be a lesson to all of us that this industry is a complicated one. It is not an easy one. It is not just an Australian industry; it is an international industry. There are many issues that need to be considered. The decision we took in this Parliament to put IPP into place was a decision that all of us must now, in retrospect, applaud. It was very interesting to hear, and we appreciated hearing, someone on that side of the House-in fact it was the last speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur-acknowledge that the Government continued with IPP and that there was some benefit there. The Australian public ought to realise that IPP was something from which the whole country benefited.

The calculation of these prices under this legislation is complicated. The Bill underlines, as I said, the importance of Bass Strait oil. Its large fields, old and new oil, produce most of Australia's oil. However, the proportion of high excise old oil will decline as the oil fields deplete. Production from areas on-shore will attract the excise in the event that production exceeds the 30 million barrels excise free threshold. The price basis for existing such on-shore oil production will be considered at the appropriate time. There is some indication that there may be some changes on the 30 million barrels excise free threshold. Perhaps the Minister can elaborate on that point. Excise will be levied on crude oil from Bass Strait using the volume weighted average of realised free on board prices of all sales in a calendar month referred to, as I have said, as volware prices. The volume weighted average realised prices have been chosen because they are directly related to the prices actually realised by the producers. The basis for volware prices will be the realised price of oil as it is loaded on a ship at Long Island Point and Crib Point, and for pipeline transactions, the realised pipe inlet prices at Long Island Point. The Bill makes provision for the determination of three sets of prices for each month of sales. The Bill also has provisions to give the Minister the power to determine the price for any sale when any part of the sales transaction is believed not to be a genuine commercial sales transaction. That point, I think, is well made and we appreciate that.

Unfortunately, we do not have much time today but I want to raise several points with the Minister. In his second reading speech he acknowledged the decline in Bass Strait production and the increase in the volume of imported crude oil. Without IPP, to go back to my earlier point, the importation of crude oil over the last several years would have been much higher than it was. Let us imagine what that would have done to our balance of payments if many of our hard earned export dollars had had to be applied to bringing oil in to run Australian industry. We have been so fortunate-we just do not realise how fortunate-because of the development of Bass Strait. According to the Treasury, Australian crude oil production is expected to fall from around 500,000 barrels a day in 1987-88 to around 300,000 barrels a day within three years and to around 200,000 barrels a day within six years. Crude oil self-sufficiency is likely to dive from the present level of about 90 per cent to less than half that amount by the mid-1990s. How then can the Minister also make the statement that as a consequence of deregulation:
. . . some higher quality crude oil will be exported but this should be at higher prices than the imports, resulting in a net balance of payments gain.

What time span is the Minister considering? An article in Australian Business recently suggested that an annual revenue gap of around $350m next year and between $700m and $1,100m in three and six years respectively could result. Even if the recent measures taken by the Government to stimulate oil exploration are successful-a matter for debate which we have discussed in here on many occasions in recent months-it will at best only cushion an otherwise abrupt landing. The Bulletin, on 27 October, predicted an annual import bill of $5,000m by the mid-1990s as Australia's crude oil self-sufficiency declines. We have to find that $5,000m. As the Minister at the table will know, it is no easy thing to replace oil with other forms of energy. For instance, whilst the technology for the conversion of natural gas to oil is there, it is not yet economically viable to apply it immediately to address the window of crisis that we face.

The report of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research issued a dire warning of the consequences of such a massive import bill on our balance of payments, our economy and employment. This was mentioned in a recent debate on the resource rent tax. Already the Minister for Science and Small Business will know that report because it was commissioned by the Victorian Government, which is also exceptionally concerned about the matter. It too draws revenue from the benefits of Bass Strait and it too, like the Federal Government, is wondering and hoping that the oil industry will continue on its happy way and will continue to be a tax vehicle. We on this side of the House say that governments of all persuasions, of all levels, have to try to move away from their over-reliance on taxation.

Time is running on and does not permit me to address all the other issues I wanted to address. However, there is perhaps time to make one or two quick points. The Government has sought to protect small producers by seeking assurances from refiners that they would continue to lift the output of small producers in a timely manner and at fair market prices. The Government is apparently satisfied by responses by refiners that indicate that these conditions will be met. Indeed, it is interesting to pick out an article that appeared recently in the Australian Financial Review which mentions concern about condensate. The article refers to a Mr Craddock, who is the Assistant General Manager for Santos Ltd, and states:

Mr Craddock's comments reflect current concern by the Cooper Basin producers that oil refiners, such as Mobil which operates the Port Stanvac refinery, could opt, in an era of deregulation, for cheap imports of crude and condensate rather than purchasing Australian products.

The article goes on, however, to hope that that will not eventuate. But that makes the point: there is a fear there that because of the avail- ability of cheaper international crudes, oil refiners will take those up rather than take up the products of small producers. We hope that does not eventuate. I urge the Government to monitor that situation extremely closely because, as I said before, small explorers have the potential to become big explorers and big producers. We want to provide the incentive for domestic companies to be able to fulfil that ambition because we, the Australian public, and Australian investors-and it is a high risk industry-will be the beneficiaries.

Another point made by the Leader of the National Party concerned the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). The Prices Surveillance Authority sets the wholesale price based on an average of capital city pricing. It is now being argued, and I accept the argument, that it will have to change that arrangement. Indeed-as I quoted from a letter from the Authority the last time I spoke-it is yet to determine exactly how that will be done, and there seems to be quite a deal of discussion about how it ought to be done. It seems to me that a line of logical thinking would demand that the PSA's role ought now to be somewhat changed. If we want to get away from the highs and troughs of the petrol price at the domestic pump, which the petrol stations suffer-and do not forget the wholesalers, who probably suffer more than the petrol station proprietors when the price goes down, when there is a price war, because they have to carry the bigger margin; although they have greater capacity, they too are in the business to try to make a profit-the PSA, in my view, would be far better to move away from setting prices and to have a role of monitoring only. If we are to have deregulation, let us go all the way. Indeed, if I can draw an analogy using interest rates, we kept the 13 per cent level of interest rates in the housing area--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—It is all right to say, `Hear, hear!', but some of us could not get it and missed out. It would seem to me that everyone ought to be treated in the same way. That is the situation in the oil industry. The Government is setting an artificial price. Once it has deregulated half way, up to the refining stage, what will happen to the other half? Is it going to regulate that? I think in time the inconsistency that is apparently there will have to be addressed by the Government, and I hope that it will look far more carefully at it. The PSA wrote to me again the other day and made the point-and I think it is a point well made-that in section 17 (3) of the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act, part of its role is the need to maintain investment and employment, including the influence of profitability on investment and employment. It does have a role to ensure that there is investment in the industry and that the industry is profitable, whatever that industry is that is being looked at in terms of price surveillance.

SPEECH.PARA: So let us not forget that the people in the oil industry who make it all happen are the companies that invest the money, and although many of them may be foreign nationals, many Australians are also investing cash in that industry. It is a high risk industry, especially on the exploration side. We want to do everything we can to ensure that exploration takes place in this country. We read in the Australian today that one of the products of deregulation may well be, according to Keith Orchison, from the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, that exploration will suffer. He said:
Small to medium producers, particularly in remote areas, would be worst hit because they would not be guaranteed markets.

He goes on to talk about how the smaller explorers may be seeing incentive taken away from them. They are some of the issues that I think the Government has to come to grips with. Whilst we applaud the decision to move towards deregulation, it ought to be acknowledged that the Government has not gone all the way. There is still further work to be done, and it certainly revolves around what the PSA is going to do. Perhaps the Minister or other speakers in the debate will elucidate a little further on what the Government intends to do.

Finally, I come back to the political point that I made. This legislation acknowledged the importance of a decision made by the former Fraser Government about import parity pricing. This Government has benefited from it. It followed IPP, as indeed has the whole Australian community. As we put the IPP mechanism to bed today, we ought to acknowledge the benefits that IPP, and the foresight of former governments, brought to the oil industry and to the Australian consumer in this country. Today ought to be the day when there is a bipartisan acknowledgment of the wisdom of that decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to compliment the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who again, and I repeat what I said the last time, put a lot of effort and research into his speech. I will confine my remarks specifically to what I see as some of the problems that may occur in the future in this industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The motorists driving home tonight, particularly those in Tasmania, will be saying to themselves, `Boy, is something going to happen with this industry! Are we going to get a reduction? Are we going to get a fair go?'. Of course it is problematical. We have headed for deregulation. The honourable member for Bass supported the Government, as I do too. I was apprehensive about the introduction of import parity pricing, but of course in the long term we have to look ahead. There was a world shortage of oil and we needed future exploration and future production. We also needed to look for alternatives. It is good to see the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) in the chamber tonight, because I know that he is a gentleman who thinks about it. It is not easy to put these things into play.

We talk about converting to liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and we say to ourselves, `Let us make 25 per cent of the motor vehicles in Australia use LPG'. But if people do not want LPG, what can we do about it? We should have conserved more in that area. We should have introduced legislation at the time and made it mandatory for a percentage of cars to run on LPG. I spoke about this last time. I know that the then Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), made a Press statement indicating that he would look at the matter very seriously and, if possible, would endeavour to encourage people in Australia to convert to LPG. I said in my speech on the last occasion that one manufacturer produced a motor vehicle specifically to run on LPG, but it was a failure because he did not allow for the alternative, so that a person could use it either on petrol or on LPG. It used specifically LPG, and a lot of people shied away because of rumours that they could not get LPG at certain locations, and that it was unsafe. I think we need to look for alternatives if petrol is kept at such a high price.

Let me refer to the case of a person travelling today from Bridgewater, a suburb of Hobart, to Hobart who may be on a low income and who may have the worst possible car. Most people buy a car, but those on lower incomes regrettably sometimes buy a poorer type of car, one that uses more petrol and more oil. If that person travels about 10 or 20 miles to work and then another 10 or 20 miles home tonight, it is costing him about $3. The point I make is that we often hear about the hip pocket, and the governments win or lose on the hip pocket nerve. But the price of petrol affects everybody.

Tonight we are talking about the complex issue of deregulation, of getting away from import parity pricing et cetera. The average person in the street tolerated our going to import parity pricing for various reasons. The present Government has found it necessary to continue with that policy, because it knows it is a way of getting revenue. It is a simple way of extracting taxation at the petrol pump. We do not need to go over history. The Treasurer at the time said that it was stealth at the petrol pump, but he found it necessary to use the same system to keep up his Budget allocations. The motorists are saying to themselves, `All right, we have put up with import parity pricing. It went from about 15c a litre to about 45c a litre, and it was very hard to substantiate at the time'. But now they are saying to themselves, `Look, Mr Hawke said that he would reduce the price of petrol by 2c a litre. The Treasurer said that he would reduce it by 30 per cent'. People are still waiting patiently for it to happen.

Since the Hawke Government came to power, regrettably the price has risen by 13c a litre on average throughout Australia. We are always hearing that the petrol price in Tasmania is the highest in Australia. We know that, but Mr Gray found it necessary-some of us doubted his wisdom, but it was his decision-to put up the price by 7c a litre because he said that there was a shortfall from the Federal Government. As a consequence the people of Hobart are paying about 64c a litre, and I think that people in Canberra will be paying around 60c a litre for petrol. It is a lot of money for petrol when people are already meeting mortgage repayments, payments on their car and so on.

Petrol is a precious commodity. If we are able to make the position fairer for all Australians, we should give careful attention to the matter. It is said that there is a possibility that the price will go down by a certain percentage. I do not know whether that will be the case. The Prices Surveillance Authority has a grave responsibility. I know that the honourable member for Bass has written to that Authority, but I do not think that the Authority can handle the petroleum industry. It has answered the honourable member and I have heard his comments that the Authority said that it has to consider investment and so forth.

The oil companies are very powerful. Previously each individual oil company went to the Prices Surveillance Authority, and if it could justify an increase it would get it. So there were different prices right throughout Australia at the maximum wholesale level. The position has changed. There is a common wholesale price right throughout Australia which does not vary very much from capital city to capital city. But then all hell broke loose, because if the oil companies found that they could sell more petrol in a certain locality, they dropped the price. An article in the Australian of 18 November, headed `Cargo price petrol plan attacked by Ampol chief', says:
Ampol Ltd yesterday attacked proposals that Australia's maximum wholesale prices for petrol be based on cargo product prices in Singapore or other key refining centres.

All oil companies have a different interpretation of how the maximum wholesale price should be fixed. The most interesting comment came from Esso Australia Ltd, and at least that company was truthful:
An Esso Australia Ltd spokesman said the company would prefer not to have a maximum wholesale petrol price.
`We never reach maximum price anyway, and we're usually at a discount of about 4c to 5c a litre . . .

That is exactly what I have been saying for years and it has been substantiated by Esso that the company is able to drop the price below the maximum wholesale price when it finds it necessary to compete in the market place. We support free enterprise and letting market forces go free, but this aspect is so important to the average motorist. If motorists see the prices varying dramatically they are justified in becoming wild.

People who leave Tasmania and drive around Australia, on their return tell me about the varying price of petrol discovered on their trips. It is extraordinary how the price varies from place to place. They say, `We can understand, Bruce, why prices should vary a little', but when the price varies by as much as 15c or 16c a litre or 12c, 5c, 6c and 7c, they start to ask questions. This is particularly true of the country areas. I see my good friend the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) present for this debate. He did so much for the petroleum industry when he was Minister for Transport. People are justified in their complaints.

Tonight we are debating the complexity of the oil industry and its future direction. Last year I read in the Petroleum Gazette an interesting article on restructuring. Following a world shortage of oil, problems started to occur, and the world was talking about restructuring. It was spoken about not just in Australia but throughout the world. We do not want a repetition of what happened before when Americans did not have enough oil to keep themselves warm. Suddenly there was a concentration on oil for heating, there was a shortage, and they could not keep up supplies.

TALK.START.PARA: —People died.

—Yes, people died as a consequence. The world has restructured, and this has not happened in Australia alone. Let us hope that we can restructure for the betterment of the people who work in the petroleum industry and on the exploration side in the oil companies. Of course, the Prices Surveillance Authority said that it had to ensure that investment continued. One cannot knock the oil companies ad infinitum. They provide employment, they give grants and do many other things. One has to give those companies credit for those things. It is only on the marketing side where one sometimes thinks that the attitude is that everybody outside is just a number on the wall and that the poor service station proprietors will do what the companies want. They are just pawns in the game. As a consequence, sometimes the oil companies are condemned. I emphasise that we need to make the industry better for the people at the exploration level of the industry and for those who work in the oil companies.

SPEECH.PARA: Then one has to consider the poor little blokes out there trying to make a buck in this cold hard world in service stations, who have their wives, daughters and sons working with them, and who have mortgaged their homes and so on. We want to make the position fair and decent for them. Then, very importantly, we want to make it fair for the consumers. If we can reduce the price genuinely, we need to do so. I say to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Small Business, that we must forget stupid promises about reducing the price by 2c a litre to win votes. Let us forget claims that the price would be reduced by 30 per cent. Forget about those promises because we have not been able to come up with the goodies, and the people out there know it. Let us try to offset the actions of the State governments in imposing taxation. If they are forced to impose taxation to the level of 7c a litre, there must be something wrong. We need to make certain that such things do not occur. Hopefully we can restructure, and I feel that deregulation is going in the right direction. There is a hope that the price will come down and that more exploration will take place, which is all to the good. We in Australia might then be self-sufficient and not depend on oil imports. If that happens we might have a decent, respectable industry of which we can be proud, and thus help the motorists of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to offer a small contribution to the debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill and rather than going into the specifics of the Bills I wish to respond to a few comments made by Opposition members. The Opposition spokesman on science and energy, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), suggested that one should acknowledge the imposition of world parity pricing by the Fraser Government. In the seven years in which that Government did so little that was geared to a sensible and rational economic structure in Australia, I agree that that probably was its single proudest moment. I am happy to acknowledge that in the long term it was a very important step. It was a step which undoubtedly had its electoral costs initially, but we can be thankful that it was taken. It is also fair to point to the irony that so many economic moves in building the Australian economy and industry and in providing jobs have come from the Labor side. Deregulation of the financial markets, for example, was begun by the coalition Government, but it was not really able to follow through. I know that there is debate now as to whether the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was responsible for socking it to the Cabinet and Mr Fraser opposed it, or whether Mr Fraser was very keen about the matter and the Leader of the Opposition opposed it. One has to look at the matter with a sense of history, and I guess that it is not that important.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are dealing with a deregulation Bill. The Opposition supports this measure. I have taken part in a number of debates, prior to the election in July this year, dealing with industry assistance and customs and excise legislation. The basic feature of those debates was the degree of unanimity between the Opposition and the Government. I suppose that I can be accused of being a little naive, but I was genuinely shocked when the then Opposition shadow spokesman on industry, Senator Messner, brought out a policy which would dismantle every form of assistance to industry. I shall not recite the number of Opposition shadow spokesman and Opposition members who have spoken in this Parliament in support of assistance measures, even though they may have been critical of some aspects, which is the proper role for an Opposition. Then we went into an election and suddenly the Opposition made a complete turnaround. It intended to dismantle assistance but would do so in a consultative way. I hope that the Opposition's support tonight is not of that variety. I hope that it is genuine support, welcoming the Government's move to deregulate this industry.
It is true that we could not have a Bill such as this, dealing with the petroleum industry, without a contribution from the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck)--

TALK.START.PARA: —A great speech!

—The honourable member always makes an entertaining contribution. I wish to respond to a few of the points that he raised. For example, he talked about the 2c promise and the 30 per cent reduction that this Government had planned in petrol prices. Honourable members must understand that once one imposes world parity pricing, as introduced by the Opposition, this takes away some of one's options for reducing the price of petrol which rises and falls with the prevailing international price. That has happened with this Government. Additionally, I point out-and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has made this point a number of times in the Parliament-that the Government which really reaped the windfall harvest of the Bass Strait discovery, the importance of which was so rightly pointed out by the shadow Minister, was the Fraser Government. That Government was awash with money. Did it apply that money to lowering the price of petrol? No. Did it apply it to a reduction in income tax? No. Did it apply it to some other worthwhile economic measure such as industry assistance? No, it did not. Unfortunately, once those opportunities are forgone, they are gone for ever.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to offer a personal and individual contribution to the debate. The honourable member for Franklin suggested that this industry is complex. I certainly accept that. It has its facets of exploration, export, refining and marketing. If we are ever to make a beneficial impact for our consumers at the petrol pump, we must act now. I am very mindful of those people from my electorate who travel home from Sydney's central business district to Blacktown and St Clair and who daily face the frustrations to which the honourable member for Franklin referred-that is, the complete volatility of and variation in petrol prices. Significant variations occur, not only within an electorate such as Chifley but also between different electorates such as Chifley and Banks. In Banks the petrol is much cheaper. Honourable members often stand up in this House and try to explain that this is private enterprise at work, that there are forces there that we cannot control or that there should be intervention by the Prices Surveillance Authority to correct the matter, but I suggest that that is not a fruitful course and it will not produce significant change. We really must take the bull by the horns. I suggest to the Minister that sooner or later the Government will have to look at divorcement-that is, restricting the ability of those who market petrol, the petrol companies, to own the retail outlets, the petrol service stations.

If there is some apprehension about moving straight into this, I suggest that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), a body for which I have little time, could be employed productively in examining this proposition. There could be an investigation by the IAC into the wholesaling of petrol through further distributors, but in particular to the petrol stations, and the question of the ownership of those petrol stations.

It is accepted wisdom today that in the metropolitan areas particularly we have far too many petrol stations. The problem is that we are allowing the petrol companies to rationalise those petrol stations and they are doing so against those small businessmen who have the least ability to respond-that is, the leaseholders. I have a real and genuine concern about the small businessmen who are leaseholders to petrol companies for their service stations. They have little ability for independent activity. They can only raise and lower their prices as agreed to by the petrol companies and they are in a completely subordinate position. It has come to my notice that petrol companies can be less than generous with such leaseholders. I say to those leaseholders that if they have a particular grievance or concern about the actions of petrol companies they may certainly write to me and I will take up the matter because I think it is an issue that is worth pursuing, that is, the divorcement between the big petroleum companies and their ability to own service stations and lease them out.

I return briefly to the Bill. It has already been said that the Bill will deregulate the crude oil that is produced from Bass Strait. It implements a courageous decision by the Government to deregulate oil marketing within Australia with effect from 1 January 1988. I also point out that whilst companies now have the ability to export some Australian crude, it is expected that in export-import terms, this freeing up is likely to be either revenue neutral or perhaps even revenue positive. It also opens up some export opportunities for refined products, from Australia's sophisticated refineries, as pointed out in the second reading speech of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). This is exactly what Australia needs. We really need to hook on more value-added to our exports and to be less reliant on crude exports, whether they be petroleum, minerals or whatever.

I indicate that I support this legislation. I think it is important legislation. On the petrol retailing aspect, it is very true that all members on the Government side are concerned about price volatility and that government opportunities for reducing the cost of petrol probably came during the period of the Fraser Government when it was awash with money. When the average motorist driving home in my electorate of Parkes, whether in Forbes, Parkes, Dubbo or distant towns like Bourke or Wanaaring, filled up in 1983 he was paying the Treasurer about $3 a tank. Today he is paying this Treasurer, who made the statements I have just read out, about $11 in tax for each tank. If a worker filled his petrol tank only about once a week, he would be paying the Government in excess of $500 a year in petrol tax alone just to get to work in towns like Dubbo, Forbes or the big cities of Australia like Sydney and Melbourne. The blatant, cynical and money grabbing action of the Treasurer does not sit well with the earlier statements he made.

A question that has been asked in this debate is why we have different petrol prices in different parts of Australia, whether they be from week to week in our cities and towns, or in city and country areas. It puzzles many people. It is a very complicated issue. The ownership of outlets is one thing that complicates the issue. In country areas such as in my electorate we can pay up to 65c a litre, particularly in distant towns like Nyngan and Brewarrina, for petrol and perhaps around 61c, 62c or 63c a litre in Dubbo. At the same time specials can be running in Sydney of 49c a litre. A gap of 15c a litre means that people in the country will pay more than $9 extra for a tank of petrol than their city cousins. When one lives in the country and has to travel greater distances than people in the city anyhow this is a bit hard to stomach.

People in the country will always have to pay slightly higher prices for petrol because country outlets sell less petrol and to not have the economy of scale city outlets have. There is also a freight charge. But even the freight cost to get petrol, say, from Sydney to Dubbo, works out to only 2.7c a litre. Country outlets never seem to get the specials. To understand this we have to realise that there are four main types of petrol retailers in Australia. There are the independents, who own their own service stations, the secondary marketers, such as Solo, the commission agents who run company-owned stations, and the lessees who lease stations from the oil companies. Both the independents and the secondary marketers are able to buy their petrol, particularly cheap petrol on the open market, from the refiners. They can do their own wheelings and dealings and get special prices.

However, the commission agents and lessees, who are in the majority in this country, are tied to the oil companies for the prices they can get their petrol for. The commission agents do not actually buy the fuel. They simply sell it on behalf of the oil company for a commission. The lessee dealers buy their fuel from the company at a price determined by the company and then put their mark-up on it. The discounting that occurs in this country starts when an independent or secondary marketer manages to buy some cheap fuel and then marks his price down. Because the price of retail petrol in this country is so sensitive, the volumes that are sold can shift very rapidly from those charging the standard price to those charging a discount price. So we get discount pricing.

Oil companies, on average, get about 12 1/2c per litre for each litre they sell. They will sometimes mark this price down to 2 1/2c a litre, which is a 10c reduction. The retailer will have a mark-up when he or she sells petrol of about 4c a litre in the city to about 6 1/4 a litre in the country. They can sometimes mark the price down to 3c a litre. If one combines the two, petrol can be sold at one bowser for 58c a litre and at another bowser can be on special for 47c a litre, which is quite a difference. It is worth while remembering that Government taxes remain the same, regardless of whether the petrol is sold at the standard price or at a discounted price. The taxes, excise and royalties on petrol amount to something like 34c a litre in total.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Some 34c a litre, which, when petrol is selling at 58c a litre, is something like 58.6 per cent of the price; but when petrol is marked down to 47c a litre the taxes are in excess of 72 per cent of the total price. An industry that should be encouraged is being taxed out of existence. The Government should make hard decisions to get off the backs of the high risk, high cost oil industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bass directed some of his comments towards the exemptions from excise of the first 30 million barrels of crude oil produced, and sought a clarification of this particular measure. There are exemptions for on-shore fields, that is, for oil fields within the States and Territories and areas off-shore out to the limits of the territorial sea. A crude oil excise exemption applies to the first 30 million barrels of stabilised crude oil produced from each on-shore field, regardless of when it came into production. To be eligible for the excise exemption, the crude oil production must come from a naturally discrete accumulation. On the basis of experience to date, all but the very largest on-shore fields currently in production are likely to be exempt from crude oil excise in the future.

For off-shore fields, that is, for fields in the North West Shelf and Bass Strait areas, a crude oil excise exemption applies to the first 30 million barrels of stabilised crude oil produced from new off-shore projects. Each off-shore field coming into production for the first time after 30 June 1987 will be eligible for a 30 million barrel excise exempt quota. In the case of a field already in production before 1 July 1987, a significant new development project, involving the recovery of additional crude oil which would not otherwise have been recovered from existing facilities, will also be eligible for a 30 million barrel excise exemption for the additional oil recovered.

All off-shore regions other than those specified above are subject to the resource rent tax arrangements and excise, and royalties do not apply. TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for Murray I very much appreciate the terminology when speaking to the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987. The River Murray is important to all Australians. It is supremely important to those who live along the river. They have a great feeling of responsibility and love for the river, the river system and the area. They, above all Australians, are anxious that the necessary remedial works which, if acknowledged have to be done to improve further the quality of the river, will be done. SPEECH.PARA: The Murray is our greatest river system. The Murray-Darling Basin is the core of agricultural production in Australia. That area is the heartland of agriculture in its finest forms in this country. The Murray is the provider of irrigation water for the preponderant irrigation areas of Australia. Irrigation agriculture is very important and it is becoming increasingly so with our need to increase exports. The Murray is also a very important source of water supply. Adelaide is the largest city which it supplies but it also supplies many significant cities, towns and industries along its banks. The Murray is a very important recreation area. At the present time there is very rapid growth of tourist facilities of both national and international significance.

At this stage I will comment on some fallacious views of the Murray that some people have which, I believe, makes it difficult for them to understand the reality of the river, the problems and the way in which the people living along the river have responded. It is only by having a better understanding of the real situation that we can arrive at the best solutions possible. The first important point to make is that the Murray downstream in South Australia has never been a pristine, pure stream of water. Well before there was any settlement or irrigation, over half of the salt load that now goes into the Murray has always gone into it simply because of the geology of the area. There has always been silt and clay in suspension going down the river as well. The geology of the Mallee area, which is the most significant area in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia through which the Murray flows, is saline. That means that there is salt in the river and this has come naturally but has been exacerbated by irrigation.

The second point I make is that the Murray is not always a majestically flowing river. My understanding is that the 1914 original agreement for the Murray came largely as a result of the fact that the river stopped flowing completely during the drought of 1910 to 1912. Without the assistance of the Hume Weir and other weirs, the river has stopped, and will stop, flowing at various times. The third point I make is that many of the lakes or lunettes in the Mallee area have always been salty; it is not just a matter of irrigation making them salty. The fourth point is that one reads that production is down by about $200m on what its optimum production rate could be, and I do not disagree with that. But people then take it that production value is falling from the irrigation areas of the Murray, and that is rot. The volume and value of production of irrigated agriculture right along the Murray is increasing at an accelerated rate every year. The final point is that somehow or other the system continues to deteriorate. I have represented the Kerang area, which is part of the area that has had difficulties with irrigation. Whenever I drive through that area, as I do frequently, I have a feeling of pride for the work that has been done by the irrigation farmers of that area to improve the irrigation and the land management and to overcome the problems that were exacerbated in the early years of irrigation.

We move now to the stage where work was done to control the flow of the river. The Hume Weir was the first reason for the River Murray Agreement and that overcame the flow problem. Irrigation came afterwards. In areas west of Echuca-some would say west of a little further down the river-because of the geology and the saline history of the the areas we had drainage problems. There was increased drainage into the Murray and that, in turn, increased the salinity. Over a period of years other pollution has increased simply because of increased habitation-industrial, agricultural, tourists and so forth. The deteriorating situation-the low flows and the saline concentration-was exacerbated by the drought of 1967. I here make a distinction between saline concentration and the tonnage of salt in the river. In years of low flow-drought years-the percentage of salt in the river increases, and one form of measurement is electric conductivity (EC) units. But is years of good flow-the wetter years-the concentration falls but the actual tonnage of salt increases as part of the increased total flow of the river. All of this came to a head with the realisation that something had to be done and the pioneering or landmark work of Gutterige, Haskins and Davey started in 1967. I dusted off the report because I believe that it is a very important one for anybody who lives along the Murray or has a feeling for it.
