Over a period of years, $640m of Commonwealth money was to be provided because of this frustration of waiting for the States to play their part. A number of valuable works which would have improved the situation in the Murray were planned, including the Mallee pipeline. Of course, when the Australian Labor Party came to power it dropped that bicentennial program.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was $65m.

—As the honourable member for Mallee says, that was $65m. Also as part of the improvements that were occurring, the irrigation farmers and the research workers were gaining a greater understanding of irrigation, drainage and water-tables. There was also a dramatic increase in the horsepower of tractors and scrapers, and the dollar cost of that horsepower, to allow better land formation to take place to irrigate more efficiently and reduce first of all the drainage off the farms-I speak now as a lifetime irrigation farmer in the area-and also what goes down through the soil, which can raise the water-table to the dangerous levels, as has occurred in some areas.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, there was the introductions of laser technology. The people of the area have been world leaders in this field of technology. There was also the introduction by the coalition Government of section 75d of the Income Tax Assessment Act which provided for tax deductibility for this laser technology that have been and is being so successfully used to improve the irrigation and drainage practices and so forth in that area.

There were also many other issues at that time such as a better understanding of the flows of the river for flushing, management of weirs, et cetera. Of particular concern, both then and now, are the great red gum forests. I believe that the Barmah red gum forest in my area is the greatest red gum forest in the world. My compatriot across the river might believe that the Millewa forest is the greatest. But, in any event, these are the great red gum forests of the world. There is the problem of the Barmah choke and the flows that are necessary along the river to make sure that Adelaide and the irrigation areas get the water. This could mean the flooding of the red gum forests at the wrong time of the year. I want to make the point that there is this great concern for the protection of the red gum forests in my area, and there is an acknowledgment that, if special allocations of water are needed to guarantee that those red gums are flooded at the right time of the year in the very dry years, that should be done.

Together with that there is the issue of the protection and encouragement of the great ibis rookeries of the area, which are very important not just for the quality of life but also for agriculture itself. I also make a claim for a second type of forest. When we are talking about the Murray-Darling Basin, we are talking about the home of the Murray pine. The largest Murray pine forest in Australia also happens to be in the electorate of Murray, at Mitiamo. That is not necessarily saying much; it is not a very large forest. However, I make a plea on this matter. In all of our talks about conservation we have not done enough to ensure the protection of the whole range of Murray pines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it want a World Herit- age listing?

—No, we do not need a World Heritage listing; we just need a better understanding and priority to ensure that the growth of the Murray pine is encouraged, because it is also a great timber for housing, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to these issues there was increasing industrial pollution and increasing tourism. That meant that in the early 1980s not only was the question of water quantity important-the control of the river and its diversion between the three States-but also water quality became very important. There were amendments at that time to give far greater power to the River Murray Commission for water quality within the river itself and an advisory role for water quality for the tributaries coming into it from the States. The States continued to remind us that they are sovereign in respect of the tributary rivers to the Murray, and hence the Commission could be advisory only. Through all of this there was this great determination of the people living along the river and in the basin generally to improve the situation. Also, I might say, the River Murray Commission enjoyed then and enjoys now a very high reputation. In fact, the reputation of the River Murray Commission along the river to my knowledge is higher than that of any State government, because it is seen to have had concern for the future of the river, which is more than can be said of some of the State governments at various times.

I now want to refer to some of the attitudes of people who do not know the river or the area or irrigation water use. Some people promote the idea that irrigation farmers have been careless with the application of water, that they have almost been criminal with it, and that the practices of the 1930s and the 1940s are still being cited as if they were still the practice of irrigation farmers today. I want to say again that the value of irrigation agriculture is increasing rapidly. There have been quantum leaps in technology in recent times which not only will add to the value of production from the area, but also reduce water usage and therefore the drainage problem. I refer to laser technology and drip irrigation in particular.

Flood irrigation for pasture production, principally for dairying, is one of the major uses of irrigation water, certainly in my part of the Murray system. Looking at dairying in this area, the productivity per farmer is two to three times that of Europe or the United States of America. It is up with the best in the world, meaning the Waikato in New Zealand. There have been bottlenecks or restrictions on increased productivity in dairying in that area. There were three in particular. One was the question of how one man could handle large amounts of hay. The answer came in the packaging or palleting system with the big round bales.

The next problem was how one man could milk an increasing number of cows. The answer came with automatic cup removers, herringbones and rotary dairies. The third problem was how one man could handle a certain area of irrigation, which meant working seven days a week and all hours of the day and night. People tend to forget this. The answer to this came with lasering and automatic watering systems.

In horticulture there are tremendous opportunities for new exports. It could be table grapes from the Mildura area or wine from the same area and down the river in the Riverland. It could be citrus fruits or pears, including Asian pears or nashi pears from my area, tomatoes, et cetera. These horticulturalists have now reduced their water usage so much by drip irrigation that, once the transferability of water rights becomes possible in Victoria, they will be selling off a good percentage of their water rights. This indicates the progress that is being made.

What worries me particularly is that in some quarters now, instead of encouragement to improve further the efficiency of water usage, some people are suggesting penalty systems. These include trebling the price of water, instead of working with the irrigation industry through taxation incentives, loans, technology, et cetera. They think that somehow or other just applying the price mechanism will further increase water efficiency. I believe that is an ignorant and unfair attitude. It is counter-productive, because it first of all ignores the improvements that have been taking place in the system.

Secondly, and more importantly, such a system would reduce cash flow to the individual irrigation farmer and his ability to finance the new technology which in turn would further increase the efficiency and reduce the water requirement, the drainage and so forth. Also, these people feel that they have been unfairly singled out by the double standards of State governments. The talk about cost recovery means including the capital works for irrigation. With railways, particularly suburban commuter railways, one is lucky to get 35 per cent cost recovery. Yet somehow or other irrigation farmers are expected to have 100 per cent cost recovery applied. One could go on with many other examples. If there is to be a price mechanism or a financial penalty to encourage more efficient irrigation, the answer is to put it on drainage, because it is drainage which causes the problems.

In regard to primary industry, I last had a role here as parliamentary secretary to Peter Nixon, and I spent some time in Washington and elsewhere in the United States of America studying irrigation and drainage. I have spent some periods over many years in the Platte Valley in Nebraska, the Imperial Valley, the San Joaquin, the Central Valley and the Sacramento Valley of California, and the Moses Lake area in Washington State that is watered from the great dams of the Columbia River. I am therefore familiar with some of the major irrigation areas of the United States. It was argued there that if price mechanisms are used to increase irrigation efficiency or for any particularly bad effects of irrigation, they should be used against drainage and not against water going on to a property. That brings me to particular aspects of the legislation.

The first point that is clear with this legislation is that the new Commission has no additional powers. That is not a criticism. The States jealously guard their powers in relation to rivers, land use, and so forth. So the powers that the River Murray Commission had remain with the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission-that is powers over water quality and quantity within the river and advisory roles from thereon. This legislation envisages a greater advisory role for the Commission. The legislation refers to the whole drainage basin, the Murray-Darling Basin, and extends the advisory role of the Commission to land management, water use, environment, et cetera. The reason for this, the argument goes, is that there is more to the future improvement of the system than just engineering solutions. I accept that. I think the term used is a `total' approach, a `holistic' approach, to the problems of the whole area. There is a need to lift the political involvement in it. If that particularly lifts the New South Wales involvement, I would say that that is doing something. As a Victorian I may be considered to be biased, particularly by South Australians, but I think we would all agree that when it came to the question of priority for the Murray Valley, New South Wales was a long way behind the other two States, and therefore the creation of a broader awareness of the total problem. To achieve this, the River Murray Commission is being replaced by the Murray Darling Basin Commission. The four governments will have two commissioners each instead of one commissioner each as under the old system. A Ministerial Council is being established comprising the three Ministers from each of the four governments; that is, those respon- sible for water, land and environment policies. It establishes a Community Advisory Committee comprising 17 members, the Chairman of which is Professor John Burton of the University of New England, to bring together people from along the river and elsewhere with particular interests and attributes in relation to the system. A standing committee was established in 1985 comprising 12 officials. The eight commissioners of the Commission are on that committee. The additional financial cost, according to the Bill, is $320,000, to be borne equally by the four governments, plus the additional costs to the States.

I do not disagree with that arrangement but I do want to make some points about it. Is it necessary to have all of this extra bureaucratic structure? Is all of this extra bureaucracy productive? Is it the best and most efficient way of achieving the improvements we all desire? We all know that it is very difficult to get a group of members of parliament, particularly a group of Ministers, to any meeting at a given time. If we are looking at getting 12 parliamentarians together we will have quite a job on our hands.

There is also the matter of the States sorting out competing and contradicting policies not only between the States but also within the States. The Barmah Forest situation is a good example of that in Victoria. There is also the matter of duplicating the work that the States are doing with their own environment and land management in employing people in Canberra and, presumably, employing extra people in the States.

Also to be considered are the concerns of the people who live along the river. I represent those people who live along quite a section of the Victorian side of the river. On the one hand, they welcome the Community Advisory Committee and they are pleased that a man of the standing of Professor John Burton is the chairman; but on the other hand, they are worried that people who are remote from the area, who have not really lived with the system, will have too much influence and that the Committee will become too bureaucratised. Cost is also a consideration. Nowhere in this legislation can I see any mention of the cost of the Community Advisory Committee as distinct from the cost of the extra staff being employed in Canberra. I would welcome some advice from the Minister on how that cost will be met and what it will be.

My next criticism relates to the way this new arrangement is being promoted. For example, at present inserts are being placed in the newspapers of towns along the Murray River. The heading on one such insertion reads, `Together. We're caring for the Murray River'. The hype in this insertion gives the impression-I am sure quite deliberately-that this is the first time that anything has every been done for the river. That is absolutely wrong.

The Times on Sunday last week contained an example of a number of beat-up stories pushing the same hype-that somehow or other nothing has ever happened before for the river, and that suddenly all is going to happen along the Murray even though the Commission has no extra powers. Some of the information in those articles is factually wrong. I am worried that this far more complicated system could slow down progress by, firstly, everything having to be reviewed before anything can be done and, secondly, the fact that the single most important thing that is required for progress to be made along the river, immediately, here and now, on reducing salinity in South Australia, is money. It is not new technology; it is not research; it is not community meetings. It is money. This Government and this Bill give no guarantee of any commitment to financial assistance for those works which would significantly reduce salinity along the Murray. This Government has actually reduced the amount of money granted to those programs along the Murray which can and do reduce salinity. I know that engineering is not the be-all and end-all, but engineering, through salt interception works, has shown that for $27m the EC level at Morgan can be reduced by 80. That is shown from the result of work being done now; it is not from the anticipated result of work to be done in 20 or 30 years with modification to management procedures. In addition, the alteration to the Menindee Lakes system can further reduce the EC level by another 30 and also allow some input from the Shepparton area and the southern New South Wales area, which is not saline water, to reduce the water table in that area. The salinity and drainage strategy indicates this. It is a cost-shared system. The interception is to be downstream to have the greatest benefit for South Australia.

I urge the Government to guarantee the finance necessary-as well as these other things, as we are not opposing the legislation-to produce the here and now results which are of critical importance in reducing the level of salinity in the river. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the Bill, the House is of the opinion that the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement should be amended:
(1) to recognise progress made (a) by previous governments, (b) by the persons who live along the Murray River and (c) in the River's drainage area;
(2) to reduce the new bureaucratic administrative and consultative arrangements for the Basin to enable efficient action and co-ordination; and
(3) so that the Government with the States provides a firm commitment to finance the already known necessary remedial measures along the Murray River which would immediately improve water quality'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—In conclusion, I say that in moving the amendment we are not opposing the legislation but we are drawing attention to what we believe are ways of accelerating the improvement that is taking place along the river at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The River Murray Waters Amendment Bill is another positive step initiated by the Hawke Government in protecting this vital water resource, the River Murray. It is indeed pleasing to see the co-operation between the Commonwealth Government and the State governments of South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales in attempting to overcome some of the problems associated with the Murray-Darling Basin. Through the co- operation of the State governments I have mentioned and the Commonwealth, this amending legislation provides for the improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. This is imperative, because there is no doubt that in the past poor land, water and environmental management practices were commonplace and led to the abuse of the Murray-Darling Basin.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will give a clear legislative base to the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council. This Council is made up of those Ministers representing the portfolios of water, land and the environment from the four governments. The Council will be in a position to take positive steps to initiate worthwhile programs for the protection of the Basin. The Council will exercise general oversight and control over all major policy questions of common interest to the government involved.

The Murray-Darling Basin Commission will be established to encompass the statutory responsibilities provided for under the River Murray Waters Agreement, to undertake an advisory role to the Council on water, land and environmental matters not covered in the Agreement. The Commission will comprise two commissioners from each government, representing between them, water, land and environmental interests, and the following institutional arrangements have been agreed to: a secretariat to be located with the new Commission to service the work of the Council and the Commission; governments to share the associated administrative costs of the Commission; legislation to implement the changes to be enacted in the four parliaments involved by September 1987, to take effect from 1 January 1988; provision to be made in the legislation for later participation by Queensland, following further negotiation; and a standing committee, comprising the heads of major policy departments involved in the management of the Basin to continue to provide policy advice to the Commission. Community groups will also have an opportunity to participate in the strategies of the Murray River for both now and in the future. I think this is very important. Consultation and participation are encouraged, and it is in everyone's interest that a total commitment to protecting this natural resource is an ongoing event.

South Australia is a State relatively deficient in both surface and ground water resources. Water is not only in short supply but also generally of poor quality. As my electorate of Grey covers 86.2 per cent of South Australia, I naturally have more than a passing interest in the mighty River Murray. The northern town regions of Port Pirie, Port Augusta and Whyalla in my electorate, along with Adelaide, depend on water pumped from the Murray River for their survival. I was pleased to have the opportunity to represent the Federal Government last year at the opening of a major filtration plant at Morgan, which now provides a high quality filtered water supply to residents in the northern towns in my electorate, as well as Adelaide. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), emphasised the problems facing residents along the Murray. But it is also important to many other areas, particularly in my electorate of Grey and in Adelaide, that we have a good water supply. It is surprising to learn how many members of this House are quite ignorant of the problems of the River Murray. I think the following recent article in the Times On Sunday, headed `The degradation of the noble Murray', is very appropriate and very succinct:

Mention the Murray River and many Australians will conjure up memories of distant history lessons and stories of how explorer Charles Sturt's small boat shot from the Murrumbidgee into a ``broad and noble river'' in 1830. The Murray evokes images of the paddle steamer trade and an agricultural eden of lush citrus groves and vineyards.
But time is catching up with the Murray, where over a century of irrigation projects-and $4 billion in public money, according to one estimate-have created an environmental disaster.

Millions of tonnes of salt, fertilisers and pesticides are being dumped into the river every year. Hundreds of thousands of hectares of some of the richest farming lands in Australia are salting up or suffering other forms of land degradation. Wetlands have been altered or destroyed, forests endangered and much wildlife killed off or put in jeopardy.

All this has had an enormous impact on Australia's agricultural production. The Murray-Darling basin, covering parts of four States, accounts for about a third of Australia's total output from natural resource-based industries. It supports a quarter of Australia's cattle and dairy farms, about half its sheep, lambs and crop land, and 75 per cent of its irrigated land.

According to a recent report by the Murray-Darling basin Ministerial Council, the land degradation includes soil structure decline, wind and water erosion, dry land and irrigation salinity and soil acidity and is reducing production from cropping land alone by $220 million a year.
That sums up some of the enormous problems that have occurred in the past. It is indeed gratifying to see the Government introduce some positive legislation to overcome some of those problems.

It would be remiss of me not to say a few words about the previous honourable member for Hawker, Ralph Jacobi, who retired at the last Federal election, and who I believe pioneered the legislation that is presently before the House. When Ralph Jacobi was elected in 1969 he single-handedly led a crusade to overcome immediately some of the difficulties that he was aware of. Back in the 1970s Ralph Jacobi had the following to say-and this is only a short passage from one of the many speeches that he made in this House on this important problem:

The problem as I see it is that if salinity is not controlled along the entire length of the River Murray basin, the River Murray will act as a giant saline drain for South Australia. Farm and domestic water supplies will be tapped from a major pipeline system taken from Lake Victoria. Irrigation as we know it will cease, riverside growth will die or change dramatically. Ecological change will be drastic and the lower Murray will no longer be a paradise for fishermen and will not be so attractive for swimmers and the boating fraternity. That is not a science fiction doomsday message, but neither is it a joke. It is just one of the options facing South Australia in the light of the steadily increasing salinity control challenge for the lower Murray environment.

Mr Jacobi was so right, back in the early 1970s, as we are today. I am sure that Ralph Jacobi would be pleased to see the number of South Australians who are prepared to speak on this important Bill tonight. It is quite pleasing that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), along with others, are going to make an important contribution to the debate on this legislation.

Apart from the problems of salinity and land and water degradation in the past in my electorate, there has been the problem of a number of deaths caused by amoebic meningitis. The last case was in 1981, when a young lad who was swimming caught amoebic meningitis and later died. It was a tragedy, in today's environment when we like to think that we are up to date with modern medicine and science, that such a thing could happen. Although it is too late to overcome the tragedy suffered by that family, this is positive legislation which will go a long way to overcome many of the difficulties and problems that have been experienced in the past. I am delighted to support this legislation. I oppose the Opposition amendments. I believe that this legislation is objective and is the way to go about overcoming the problems of the River Murray. I am glad that South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales have co-operated with the Federal Government in bringing in this very constructive legislation. I hope that in the not too distant future it will also have the support of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill, and largely echo a number of the sentiments that have already been expressed by my colleague, the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). Although he has said that the legislation should be dealt with in a bipartisan fashion-and I agree with him-I cannot turn a blind eye to the all too low priority given to the River Murray Basin by this Government since it came to office. Somerset Maugham once penned these words:

SPEECH.PARA: It is dangerous to let the public behind the scenes. They are easily disillusioned and then they are angry with you, for it was the illusion they loved.

Frankly, this Government has been a government of illusions in areas where it ought to have been active. There has been the illusion, as recently as this September, of a balanced Budget; the illusion of improvements in our export opportunities, which have largely resulted from the falling Australian dollar and not from specific government action to make our industries more competitive; and the illusion of four years of this Government and of four years of relatively good River Murray water. It has created the impression that a number of the problems in the River Murray Basin have been solved under this Government. I am sorry to say that that is the saddest illusion of all.

The truth is that over the past four years we have had the sort of climatic conditions that, even in periods of relatively low flow, have favoured quality water in the River Murray Basin. The very years that should have enabled us as a nation to ready ourselves for the inevitability of the next drought have been frittered away. The Government's inactivity has been masked by climatic conditions which, even though the flow may have been lower, has meant that irrigators have made less demand on the river; and the lower flow has not produced the sort of saline inputs which sometimes have been characterised by low flows and drought years, and which the former Government had to face and could not escape in 1982.

As a result of its experience in 1982, the Fraser Government made a commitment to spend $640m in a bicentennial water program. It is fair to say that the Hawke Government has not entirely ignored the nation's demand for improved water reticulation. As the Budget Papers illustrate, in the years 1983 to 1987 the Hawke Budget has committed $240m to improved water reticulation programs, and in the 1987-88 Budget year it has promised to spend $57m in improved water reticulation. But the portion of that money committed from 1983 to 1987 to salinity and drainage control in the Murray Valley was $20.8m. Less than 10 per cent of our total national water resource budget went into our major water resource, and there can be no excuse for that.

Australia has no major resource to match the River Murray. When we talk of resources we tend to think about mining, wheat, wool and horticulture, but the truth is that this nation depends totally on water. Consider, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you as a Western Australian will be well aware, the all-too-sobering fact that if one travels from Perth to Adelaide, by the time one is 100 kilometres east of Perth one has passed over the last flowing stream until one reaches the city of Adelaide. On the Murray River within the Murray basin there are 16 cities, a quarter of the nation's cattle, half of our sheep and lambs, a quarter of our dairy farms, half of our crop land, 30 per cent to 40 per cent of our natural resource based industries and over $10 billion of annual production. For all of this, this Government has committed nothing more in its term of office than $20.8m, or less than 10 per cent of its total national resource budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do when you were in government?

—I remind the honourable member for Hindmarsh that I have nothing to apologise for, when I look at the record of the Fraser Government in its commitment to the river basin. I can understand the honourable member's indignation, but I cannot excuse it. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has already made the valid point that the present problems of the river basin are not new. Since time immemorial the River Murray has carried an enormous salt load out to sea. It has done so because it and a number of its tributaries flow through what was once a vast inland sea. In the process it picks up two of the major problems that irrigators and those who live off its waters have to face. I refer to the problem of salinity and that of turbidity-the clay particles and fines that make up the mud that is characteristic of the river.

SPEECH.PARA: Between the river rising in the Albury area and reaching the border with South Australia it carries 1.4 million tonnes of salt per annum. Astonishingly, from the South Australian border to the sea, that 1.4 million tonnes is supplemented by another 600,000 tonnes of salt per annum. If one were to sit on my property in the Riverland of South Australia and watch the river flow past, one would be watching the equivalent of a semi-trailer load of salt-24 tonnes of it-pass one's eyes every 12 minutes. That is the problem-a problem which can be rectified, but rectifying it calls not only for government legislative action such as we have before the House this evening, but also for a dollar for dollar commitment from the Government to do something about the salt and turbidity loads of the River Murray.

I speak with some passion as a South Australian because salinity is estimated to cost my State at least $42m every year, and the cost of filtering the turbidity in the water is around $40m in the maintenance of existing filtration systems. I belong to a State that is at least 49 per cent dependent on the resources of the Murray for its total water uptake. I have alongside me the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) who, as Premier of that State, committed his political future to improving the quality of the water in the River Murray. As the honourable member for Grey, a fellow South Australian, acknowledged, I am joined tonight in this debate by South Australians from the electorates of Barker, Boothby and Mayo who also are concerned about what happens in South Australia to a river that rises in Victoria and New South Wales. In our State, from Keith in the south east to Woomera in the far north, communities are dependent on the River Murray because no other reliable water source is available. The honourable member for Grey has already eloquently outlined the problems of the River Murray. He said that they are major problems. My plea to the Government is this: As one of its members says that this river faces major problems, where is the major expenditure necessary to address them?

I turn for a moment from the attack on the Government and the paucity of money it has made available specifically to the River Murray Basin, to remind the Government of one other uncomfortable truth; that is, a great deal can be done to improve the quality of the water that flows out of the Murray-Darling Basin without necessarily spending enormous sums of money. On 30 March 1984 I met for the first time the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) at the opening of the Rufus River saline inception plant. That was a major piece of government expenditure. By the way, no one from the Federal Australian Labor Party was present for the opening of that plant. Six months later I happened to be in the Loxton Irrigation Area and saw the plans and progress that had been made in installing the saline inception plant designed for the Noora basin south of Loxton. It was designed to pick up drainage water out of the Berri, Barmera, Monash and Loxton irrigation waters and push it out to Noora so that the saline water there would evaporate away. That involved major expenditure; in fact, $15m had been committed to that whole operation. But as it turns out, Noora was a lesson in just how it is possible, without expending large sums of money, to address some of the problems that irrigators and South Australians face in water quality. With only minor expenditure, great steps can be taken to redress some of the problems currently facing the Murray River.

I want to ask the Government-as I last asked it on 21 November 1985-how, having so amended the Taxation Act under the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), it can possibly defend taking away from irrigators the right to make a major tax deduction of the water conveyancing improvement measures they have made on their properties. The removal of that tax deduction, which cost the Government nothing more than $25m over five years or a total of $5m a year, was a major blow to irrigators efficiently using River Murray water. That major blow meant the inefficiency continued and so frankly we have further pollution of the River Murray Basin as a result of irrigation-unnecessary pollution at that. The provision that existed in the tax Act that allowed irrigators to install pipelines, drip irrigation, micro jet irrigation and so on to measure the amount of water that went to every plant, has gone. For the sake of saving a very small outlay-$25m over five years-the Government has destroyed the efforts of a multiplicity of irrigators endeavouring to sort out their own irrigation problems. Worse than that-as if that were not bad enough-it has destroyed the opportunity for a productivity increase that every irrigator had under that particularly encouraging piece of legislation.

It is easy to rise in this chamber and say, `Well, why should the Government be committed to enormous sums of money to tidy up the Darling-Murray Basin in order to further subsidise irrigators?' That is a piece of arrant nonsense, to which the honourable member for Murray has already alluded. I would gladly take you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to areas in my own electorate where there are private, not government, irrigation schemes and where there is no government input as such. Those are the areas that are not only making money but are also currently in demand. In resale terms it costs far more in my electorate and in the electorate of Barker-at least 100 per cent more-to buy into a private irrigation area than to buy into a government irrigation area. What does this tell us about subsidies for irrigators and about privatisation of our existing irrigation schemes?

It has been easy to say that we need the locks and all this investment in order to sustain irrigation. As the honourable member for Grey has said, the truth is that we need locks and this investment not solely for irrigation but also for all those people in the Iron Triangle cities, 90 per cent of whose water comes from the River Murray, all of whose production goes into industrial pursuits and who desperately need River Murray water. We need those locks and those facilities for Adelaide people whose water dependency on the River Murray may range between 20 per cent and 80 per cent, and not solely for irrigation.

Tonight we have before us legislation which changes the form of the existing River Murray Commission. This legislation brings the four governments of South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth together in what will be known as the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. This body will effectively succeed the River Murray Commission. This has taken a long time. It took us from 1863 to 1913 to set up the River Murray Commission. From 1913 to 1983 and subsequently, we have had a lot of reports that frankly we could not jump over. Now we have an opportunity to make the recommendations of those reports work. We have that opportunity first, by passing the legislation that is currently before the House so that we can establish the Murray-Darling Basin Commission; secondly, by giving legislative recognition to the existing Ministerial Council; and thirdly by allowing that Ministerial Council to establish a community advisory committee. But all those reports and the legislation currently before the House will be meaningless unless the Government is prepared to commit some dollars and cents to this new program.

The honourable member for Grey said that we have legislation before this House to overcome the problem. I am sorry, but he was wrong. Tonight's legislation does not overcome the problem. It merely facilitates the steps to overcome the problem if the Government is prepared to commit the resources that the Murray-Darling Basin so desperately needs and deserves in the interests of future generations. I am prepared and delighted to support the amendment and the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming from Kalgoorlie, which is the centre of the world, I can take a more objective view of this River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987 than my colleagues from New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. However, I am not without a vested interest because I grew up on the River Murray in South Australia and, in a sense, I feel that I am still a croweater. I have retained my interest in the River Murray. I believe that this is a good piece of legislation. It is not by any means the whole answer, but it is a step along the way; it is a gradual improvement. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) asked what this Government has done. This legislation itself is testimony to what this Government has done and its concern for the River Murray. This legislation, long overdue, could easily have been introduced by the Fraser Government, but it chose not to act.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk for a while about the history of the River Murray. It is one of the world's great rivers and it is absolutely vital to Australia. If the Murray were to become saline, the effect on the economy of Australia would be catastrophic. It would probably wipe out two or three jobs in every five and the effect would be equivalent to a large and virulent outbreak of foot and mouth disease taking hold in Australia. It behoves us all to look after the River Murray as a national resource and I believe that this is something that this Government recognises.

Earlier tonight I had in the chamber a very good friend who farms in the electorate of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I must say that he was very impressed with the speech of the honourable member for Murray which I guess, in a sense, shows how easily pleased some of our farmers are. What the honourable member for Murray said was, in a sense, like the curate's egg; it was good in parts. I agreed with him, although I was a little annoyed when he tried to make politics out of the issue. But on balance he was quite sound.

Salinity is a real problem. Honourable members opposite have tended to make light of it. I have heard assertions that productivity is rising. That is true, but for how long can it continue to rise? There are certainly no grounds for complacency. It is true, as was said by the honourable member for Murray-it was reiterated by the honourable member for Wakefield whom I will come to later-that a lot of salt has always gone down the Murray. But the volume of salt has been considerably added to in recent times, basically from three sources: bad irrigation practices over the years which have been greatly modified, rising ground water caused by the ingress of a large amount of water and the effects of erosion and salinity generally.

I have long maintained that the two greatest problems, the twin problems facing the environment of Australia, are soil erosion and salinity. They are overwhelming problems. It is testimony to the shallowness, greed and ignorance of many people in the environmental movement that they do not address these twin problems. In areas of high rainfall and nice trees they love to chain themselves to trees. They feel that that is achieving something. The truth is that in high rainfall areas anything can be regenerated. If the rain falls, the work is relatively easy. The environmentalists do not show any interest in the arid lands of Australia or in the problem of encroaching salinity because it is not a problem that can be confronted with demonstrations. It requires hard and constant work, constant expenditure reserves and vigilance by governments. It is a situation that takes many years to reverse. Therefore, there is no glory in it. One does not pack one's children into the Range Rover to go to see salinity or soil erosion. I often cite the greed and shallowness of this bigoted minority which seems to exercise so much influence in our community today.

The honourable member for Wakefield alluded to Somerset Maugham. I am not a literary man myself, but in my callow youth I used to take part in method acting. Method acting was a type of acting invented by some Russian gentleman where one acts naturally on stage. I remember, during some of the stark Russian dramas, that I had nothing to do but sit on the stage and pick my nose, a habit which I have found very hard to shake, I might add. In one of Maxim Gorky's plays there were some memorable lines:
If tomorrow the sun would cease to shine and light the earth with its rays, tomorrow some madman's dream would illuminate the world.

I think that is very profound. It is true. Whilst we have greatly added to the problems of River Murray salination, we are in the process of redressing them. With goodwill and the necessary commitment from governments, State and Federal, I believe that we can redress them. But the problems of Murray salination do not occur simply along the Murray. They occur in the hinterland of the catchment area, the catchment area of over a million square kilometres that is the basin of the Murray-Darling river. The work one has to do may have to be done hundreds of miles from the Murray itself. In the areas where we have cut down mallee, which has led to rising levels of soil salinity, we have to replace the vegetation to draw down, once more, the water-table. It is much harder to do that when the table one is trying to draw down is saline. One has to attack the problem at the edges. But with new practices and the use of perennial pastures and lucerne we are drawing down the water in some areas.

Over the years we have set loose a glacier of salt which is moving slowly by inevitably towards the Murray. We have allowed the penetration of water into what were previously relatively dry areas. We have raised the water level and dissolved the salts contained in the soil. Those salts are now moving through the soil, so much so that in some places the problem has to be countered by what I call the engineering solution. My very good friend the honourable member for Wakefield gave an appallingly political speech tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was going to be good when he stood up.

—I thought he was going to be good but he really blotted his copybook. This is far too big an issue to play politics with. When he talked about the success we have had in pumping back the water into basins so that it can be evaporated safely, I was struck by two things. Firstly, he said that it involved a significant expenditure of money. He alluded to $15m as a significant expenditure of money. Then he said that one could do it very cheaply, that it costs virtually nothing. One cannot have it both ways, unless one is a member of the National Party and intends to cross the floor shortly. National Party members are the only people I know who employ that sort of logic. The engineering solution is only a method of buying time. It is not something we can do forever. Sooner or later we will fill up the depressions with salt which has to go somewhere. So the engineering solution is an interim measure, a time buying measure. It is not the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer lies to a large degree in the soil structure. One of the great improvements we can make is to monitor soil to the degree of being able to wet it with less water, not applying so much water that it permeates to the aquifer. One has to restore soil structure. In that regard a lot of good work has been done by all State agricultural departments with the advocacy of the addition of calcium sulphate to the soil as a soil flocculent. This is a great initiative, although it is not being done on the banks of the Murray but some distance from it. Similarly, the problem of soil acidity, caused by the addition of lots of superphosphate to the wheat land, has to be countered. Soil acidity reduces the growth of crops and the uptake of water.

South Australia has the hardest job. It is on the wrong end of the Murray and inherits everyone else's salt. I am told that when the water crosses the border of South Australia it already contains about 500 parts per million, which from memory is about 35 or 40 grains, of salt. Whilst the water is still quite potable, the amount of salt is significant and is a high base to be starting from. Thereafter a lot more salt is added to the water. South Australians have had to adapt most to meet the salinity problem. They have done so with channel irrigation, drip irrigation and under-tree irrigation, which has been very successful in the citrus and stone fruit orchards on the Murray. The South Australian Department of Agriculture is to be commended for the work it is doing in this area. The problem is significant.

If one is to face this problem one has to face the facts. Ninety per cent of the water used in the Murray is used for irrigation purposes. Sixteen cities are dependent on the Murray. They are not all in South Australia. Canberra is one of them. It is not by charging people in the cities that we will counter the problem. The locks and the dams on the Murray are essential to controlling salinity. If it were not for those dams we would not be in our present negotiating position, with New South Wales and Victoria agreeing to release large volumes of fresh water at times to provide the dilution South Australia requires.

Let us be quite clear that this is a problem for the irrigation industry. The irrigation industry is facing up to it and will continue to do so. But we cannot go on forever expanding irrigation production on the Murray. It is already, as the honourable member for Wakefield said, the source of $10 billion worth of agricultural produce. If we are to have more irrigation, we must look at expanding into areas as yet untouched. In my electorate, the Ord River offers enormous potential.

The Bill does not go far enough because it does not give any additional power-more persuasion perhaps, but no additional power. This problem is so important that we will have to face up to giving a Murray-Darling catchment area authority much more power-power that overrides and transcends State rivalries. Already as much as 90 per cent of the irrigated land in New South Wales is suffering the effects of salination. The problem is so vast that it effects the whole of Australia. While some 1.6 million people are directly affected by the welfare of the River Murray, it indirectly affects every single person in Australia. The problem is a national problem and must be tackled on a national basis. While I commend the Bill, I believe history will show that the authority needed more teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Upon study, the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill clearly sets out new names and adds new personnel for several new commissions and sets out an organisation for intentions to pay further departmental and governmental attention to the problems of the Murray-Darling Basin. As the second reading speech says, the Bill indeed sets out for improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of that basin. The second reading speech goes on to illustrate how it sets out also in this organisation to reduce conflict between the State governments, particularly in relation to the rights that they hold as sovereign States, and it sets out in one particular paragraph the proposition that it requires reconciliation of the disparate interests and aspirations of diverse populations of over two million people within boundaries encompassing in excess of one million square kilometres. The schedule sets out how far the basin extends physically, and it is sobering to contemplate the problems that exist within that vast area.

SPEECH.PARA: The basin extends further than 400 kilometres beyond the New South Wales border into Queensland. It takes in most of New South Wales and about half of Victoria. It is, indeed, the most productive area of Australia, obviously, from the vast content of land mass. It is good that additional people are to be involved in the Commission and in the new Ministerial Council. One of the problems in the past has been a low recognition factor of the problems that faced the States and the people whose livelihoods depend on this water.

I clearly remember one illustration of how little regard some people have had for the problems of the river and its tributaries. Some years ago when I had a particular responsibility in the negotiating field in relation to achieving the results in Dartmouth, I approached the then Premier of New South Wales, Sir Robert Askin, for his assistance. On visiting him I received a very good reception. I said that South Australia, as one of the contracting States in the River Murray Waters Agreement, would be pleased to receive his help in setting up the agreement. He said, `Sure, I will help you and the South Australians in this matter'. I said, `It is in regard to the Dartmouth Dam,' so he picked up the phone, got his engineer in chief on the line and said, `I would like you to help South Australia in this matter about that river'. He then turned to me and said, `What is the name of that river again?' His failure even to hold in memory the name of the river and the Dartmouth Dam-I should say it was not the river but the dam-for more than about three or four minutes was quite shocking to someone who had spent months and years in the negotiating pit dealing with that matter. So I am pleased to find that more people are to be involved and that there will be additional Ministers on the Murray-Darling Basin Commission with specific Ministers allocated to the Ministerial Council. That is a plus, and I hope that those Ministers will all have further regard and take back to their States and to the Commonwealth Government the greater importance that this basin will have in the future of Australian agricultural and urban activities.

The problems of the past have changed. Obviously, the first question that faced the first irrigators on the Murray was a matter of the quantity of water and the cost of diverting it to their particular usage. That continued to hold the attention of users of the river for a very long period. Even in the 1960s, in South Australia the problem was to get a quantity of water to service the rural and urban areas of my State. Although the matter of quality became very important in the choice between the then proposed Chowilla Dam and the eventual Dartmouth Dam that has been built, it was that question that exercised our minds to the greatest degree.

It has been interesting to find since then the very great change of opinion as the urgency has been brought home to individual irrigators, and to governments that they must try to ameliorate their conditions. I was very pleased indeed to find that in 1983 agreements were entered into and ratified by the various contracting governments and the parliaments involved to give attention for the first time to the quality of water in this great system.

In studying the reports, I was interested to find in the annual report of the River Murray Commission for 1985-86 tables that are annually included which show the evaporation losses for the various storages on the River Murray and its tributaries. I was more than ever convinced after reading those tables how right it was to build the Dartmouth Dam and not to proceed with the Chowilla reservoir, which had such huge momentum behind it from South Australia in the mid-1960s, because the evaporation comparisons between the shallow Menindee Lakes and the Dartmouth Dam are quite staggering. The shallow Menindee Lakes had a net evaporation loss of 602 gigalitres in 1985-86. The Dartmouth Dam, which of course has a much larger capacity, had an evaporation loss of only 19 gigalitres. That comparison sets out the complete answer to the old question, which I do not believe will again be revived, at least for a very long period, if ever.

However, Mr Deputy Speaker, the problem of salination of the irrigation lands of the basin is enormous, and the demand for increased usage in the urban areas will increase. There is a direct relationship between the demand to serve the cities in South Australia, for instance, and the economic growth in the community. The report Water 2000, which was printed in 1983 gives some projections of increased demand for the Murray-Darling Basin over the ensuing year and, of course, they differ according to the growth factors that are taken into account in the basic calculations. The growth projected for the year 2000 is an enormous increase on the previous measurement in 1977. At growth rates of perhaps 2 or 3 per cent a year, over a longer period there will be an enormously increasing load on the river for urban and industrial use.

Many articles have been written about the salt problem. One wonders whether the small individual salt diversion schemes which have been mentioned by my colleagues can ultimately maintain the river at the required level of salinity, or reduce it to the level required to meet the major international standards for water usage. I know that a number of very pessimistic articles have been written in various scientific journals about the future of the system. There have also been major proposals by the more enthusiastic of those people involved in considering the problem of piping the saline waters directly to the sea. Those of a more sober nature who are involved in the possible financing of such wide scale projects hold the view that this is financially impossible, and that the community would be unable to bear the cost of getting the salt in the affected lands from the river to the sea on such a scale as to be effective.

If that is not to be the case-if we are unable to have a major scheme to reach the sea with most of the salt which is now affecting on an aggregating scale the plantings along the river-we inevitably will have to rely on the smaller schemes that have been mentioned and which are proving to be of value, as has been illustrated in the debate tonight. That is something which we hope this Government will take further notice of, and we hope that it will heed the requests from the industry and the people who live in the basin to provide further funds. We hope that the machinery which the Government is setting up and looking to for advice will provide that advice, and that the Government will take note of it and will not simply stockpile the information, as it has done in the past in so many areas.
There is no doubt that one of the big factors behind the current relatively satisfactory position in the quality of the water in the River Murray is that the Dartmouth Dam is on stream.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also, it is almost full.

—Yes, and in fact it is providing some of the best quality water, so far as salinity is concerned, that one can expect. This is borne out in the 1983 report of the River Murray Commission which had this reference to salinity:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the drought conditions which prevailed for most of the year, the salinity of the River was generally lower and less variable than for the previous year.
It also states:

The lower salinities during 1982/83 were due to the fact that high quality water from Dartmouth Dam was used to maintain River flow through the drought combined with the exceptionally dry conditions which prevailed along the lower reaches of the River catchment and floodplain.

The Dartmouth Dam has obviously been proven in that particular time of need. If there cannot be a wholesale plan to get rid of the salt by its diversion and piping to the sea, not only will we have to rely on the individual schemes which are being entered into, but also we will more than ever have to rely on high quality water being released into the body of the stream itself. To do this we will have to look to further storage on the river.

I understand that there is still the capacity in the headwaters of the tributaries to the River Murray for a further dam of consequence. There would be no point, of course, in considering a new significant dam on the headwaters of the River Murray if the water yield from it were to be devoted to further irrigation. That would probably worsen the position, because further irrigation would amplify the salinity problem.

I believe it is now necessary to look with great intensity at the salinity and quality problem; to understand that we must preserve the irrigation areas and the urban usage that we have. We must understand that the problem will probably grow as water tables rise significantly in other areas as time passes; and that to preserve the quality of the water we need a repeat of the Dartmouth Dam situation. We require further storage to allow water of ideal quality into the River Murray under the management of the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission.

I call on the Government not only to proceed with the proposals contained in this Bill but also to act on the advice that it will inevitably receive on the various schemes that will be proposed to ameliorate the salt conditions in irrigation areas and to otherwise improve the quality of the water. I call on the Government to take a lead in this new Commission; to set in motion studies for a further dam on the headwaters of the River Murray system; and to ensure that when the need is there in future years, the impetus will be there for governments to proceed. It is not a short term proposal. There is no way of knowing the time needed to study and produce the information that is required on which to base the proposal of a new dam, but one knows that it takes time to get the contracting governments to the River Murray Waters Agreement to accept the proposals that are put forward. One could easily envisage a period of 10, 15 or 20 years before this sort of project could become a reality. There is no time to be lost now in ensuring that preparations are made to meet the need when it obviously arises.

I call on the Government not only to look at this organisation and to look at the small scale schemes that it will be necessary to implement, but also to look at the major aspects of strategy to improve the quality of the River Murray and to proceed with planning for the future for a new dam dedicated not to extend the areas of irrigation but entirely, in the first instance, to the maintenance and improvement of the quality of water in the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss some of the points raised by my colleague the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), and I shall do so in a moment. I recall that many years ago an American magazine used to feature a nuclear clock on its masthead and showed at various times what the time was in minutes to midnight, depending on the height of tension around the world at the time. During the Cuban missile crisis, it was down to one minute to midnight. At other times it might have shown 10 minutes to midnight.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform the House and the nation tonight that for the River Murray system the time is one minute to midnight in terms of the environmental equations, the salinity problems, and the need to bring about a major breakthrough in liaison, co-ordination and control. I hope the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987 will in fact do that, but I share some reservations, as adequately expressed by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), when speaking elsewhere, and by other honourable members, who said that the infrastructure may not be good enough to do just that. I was pleased that the honourable member for Boothby, a South Australian par excellence and a former Premier of that State, saw fit to validate history by endorsing the major decision to build the Dartmouth Dam as an alternative to the Chowilla Dam, and to reflect on the many benefits that have flowed from that decision, particularly in terms of high quality water being made available to the River Murray system. According to the latest bulletin from the River Murray Commission, the storage capacity of the Dartmouth Dam was sitting right on 91 per cent at 18 November 1987. That is the highest level this massive dam has ever reached. It is very high quality, cold water.

I take this opportunity to say to the honourable member for Boothby that he should not be too anxious to promote the cause of more big dams upstream of the Murray River. There are environmental downsides to that equation. The upside is that it provides good quality, cleansing water to the Murray River. Both of the dam sites most favoured by the engineers at this stage would involve major clashes with the Kosciusko National Park. I refer to the Devil's Grip Gorge site upstream and the Murray Gates site upstream. One other site-the Jingellic site-is a massive site not far upstream from Albury and the existing Hume Weir. The wall of the Jingellic site would rise in the waters of Lake Hume near the Dora Dora Hotel. That site too has been assessed by engineers and others and found to have severe environmental problems should the project be proceeded with.

The era of building big dams to solve big problems, primarily at times of big elections, has passed this nation by. I do not rule out entirely the possibility of additional storage on the Murray River. But as the member representing the largest section of the Murray River-I represent the area from Mount Kosciusko, the source of the Murray River, through Khancoban, Albury, Corowa, Moama, Swan Hill and Murray Downs to Wentworth on the South Australia border-I put to the House that we need to think very carefully about further major storages being built on the Murray River system. We need to think very carefully about the economics of a water quality only storage facility. I certainly agree with the honourable member for Boothby that the building of a further storage facility which would open up massive areas of dry valley hinterland to additional irrigation is unlikely to be adopted and it would be very unwise to adopt it at least until we resolve some of the ongoing problems associated with salinity in the Murray Valley.

I should mention two additional matters to the House. Firstly, some year ago the relationship of the operation between Dartmouth Dam and Hume was out of kilter due to the delay in releasing waters from Dartmouth in time to cope for the end of summer and dry autumn seasons. Because of restrictions on the quantity of release that can be physically made available from Dartmouth to Hume, the whole system got out of kilter for a short period. There were major problems for irrigators as they sought to finish their rice and summer crops, and we hope that will not be repeated.

I have discussed this matter with the existing River Murray Commission. I have sought and obtained an assurance that it is monitoring daily the relationship between the level of Dartmouth, which is at present above 90 per cent, and the level of the Hume which is fast dropping below 75 per cent, to make sure that they do not get out of kilter, that the Commission will take account of the limited channel capacity between Dartmouth down the natural river system to the Hume and that irrigators not only in New South Wales and Victoria but also in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) will be adequately catered for in the latter part of what could be a very dry, hot summer and early dry autumn.

The second matter I should mention with regard to the salinity equation and the need for flushing clean waters is that Mr Ken Johnson, the Chief Executive of the River Murray Commission, suggested, in a formal bulletin issued on 19 November, that releases from the Dartmouth Dam this year could be required to commence as early as mid-December 1987. That has a lot of significance for South Australia because it would mean flushing clean water through the system, and the aeration necessary to take place to warm the Dartmouth Dam water before it can be released lessens the environmental impact of the freezing cold water. The process will be required to be commenced in the very near future. It is costly but it is a price we have to pay. Diesel generators driving air compressors will be utilised to warm that water ahead of its release to the irrigation system of the Murray Valley. The honourable member for Boothby and other honourable members have touched on the salinity question. The Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) in his second reading speech also did so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inadequately, though.

—I accept that the honourable member for Gippsland represents just a little part, but nevertheless a significant part, of the Murray Valley. I introduced him to that part of his electorate. He participated very constructively in Tumber Trek. He climbed Mount Kosciusko and Mount Townsend a couple of Januaries ago as a tourist promotion. As I said at the outset, the hands of the clock on salinity, as far as the Murray system is concerned, stand at about one minute to midnight. We have been very lucky over recent years that natural causes have brought about high river flows which have helped to ease electric conductivity (EC) counts particularly downstream of the entrance of the Barr Creek, downstream of Swan Hill, Mildura and beyond. I have to tell the House about brilliant schemes such as the Wakool salinity interception scheme. On the New South Wales side of the border some $40m plus has been spent and this wonderful scheme, on the face of it, has benefited 80 farmers or more. That salinity pondage is leaking to the south and west. It is leaking horrific amounts of salt water to the south and west and is adding to the underground problem of highly saline waters drifting back towards the outer branches of the Murray and ultimately back to the Murray. Worse still, it is also causing back pressure to the north and east which is degrading land in that area. On 1 December next, in company with my State colleague, the honourable member for Murray, Jim Small-he is an effective operator-I will be meeting with land holders to discuss the severe problems faced by primary producers in the immediate environs of that Wakool salinity storage scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: This leads me to address the question of leaky soils. Not so long ago it was revealed that about one-third of the rice crop of New South Wales was being grown on leaky soils. It was the classic situation, not a majority situation. When a farmer was asked to provide test boring samples of clay in his rice paddies he immediately went to the nearest dam bank and found a very good patch of clay with which to load up his sample so that he would get approval to grow rice on his land. The reality was, not so long ago, that one-third of the New South Wales rice crop was being grown on leaky soils. Therefore, it was leaching through to the salt deposits below that land, adding to the general water table problems especially to the south and west and exacerbating the danger for the valley system as a whole.

I recognise that the rice industry is a responsible industry. It is making valiant attempts to address this problem. If the New South Wales rice crop could from next year onwards cease to grow any rice whatsoever on leaky soils and if my colleagues and friends on the Victorian side of the border could, by one method or another, divert once and for all the Barr Creek salt deposits into the Murray Valley system, we would be a long way towards addressing the problems which affect South Australia and beyond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Victoria has far more than just Barr Creek.
—I realise that Barr Creek is only one of several aspects of the problem on the Victorian side of the border. It is a particularly notable one.
—Extension work is being undertaken, including a local program to reduce it considerably. It is part of a total control.

—I accept that the honourable member for Murray is correct in referring to the rectification which is taking place on the Barr Creek. But I do not apologise for mentioning the Barr Creek, and I do not apologise for mentioning the Wakool salinity problem. I realise that this is a sensitive problem but it is a serious one. I say to the House that I believe that the new Commission has a major challenge ahead if it is to overcome these problems. There is no guarantee that the new structure proposed under this legislation will automatically overcome those problems. The honourable member for Murray has correctly alluded to the bureaucratic aspects of the apparatus being created by this legislation. I assure my electors and my colleagues that I will be monitoring this legislation extremely closely to see whether it performs up to the criteria or objectives which are laid down, to see that it does not merely become a massive environmental intervention into the deliberations, management and operations of our vital Darling and Murray river systems and to see that genuine progress is made in arresting the salinity problems which are prevalent in the valley.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, and on a parochial note-but not one relating to any particular tributary of the Murray-I mention that the location of the headquarters of this new Commission is yet to be decided. The River Murray Commission headquarters are here in Canberra. There are some reasonable arguments as to why that is so. It allows for a neutral deliberation by the River Murray Commission with regard to its work, without its being unduly influenced by those electors who live at Echuca, Moama, Cohuna-

TALK.START.PARA: —Murray Bridge.

—Murray Bridge or wherever. I want to refer to the Minister the very reasonable suggestion that the headquarters be at the national growth centre. There are already a number of laboratory and other resources located at Albury-Wodonga which lend themselves to the support work of the new Darling-Murray Basin Commission headquarters. I hope that the Minister, reasonable person that he is, will give very careful consideration to the location of the new Basin Commission headquarters created by this legislation. I support the Bill. I particularly support the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Murray-despite everything. I hope that this new legislation and the new Commission will not become a bureaucratic monster, but will become a real performer in terms of the future of our great river systems of south eastern Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I think the speech which he has just concluded was a particularly valuable contribution to the debate. While I am at it, I must say, too, that I am a little disappointed in the speech which came from the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). Also, I hope that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), will not be too tough on the honourable member for Farrer for the comments which he made about Barr Creek, and I hope his temperature reduces.

SPEECH.PARA: The comment was made earlier that insufficient credit has been given to work that has been done in the past on mainly the Murray River system.
