It is pretty obvious that we need money for these sorts of things. On other occasions the honourable member for Murray would ask the Government to be extremely careful in the way in which it handles money. Once again, we have to look at a broader range of issues.

I want to pay tribute, as did my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), to a wonderful man who did a tremendous amount of work to draw this Parliament's attention to the problem of inland fresh water. I refer, of course, to the previous member for Hawker, Ralph Jacobi. Probably no person in the history of this Parliament has done more than Ralph to highlight the need to recognise the problems associated with, in particular, the waters of the Murray-Darling.

I think the legislation we are debating tonight will be received with great relief by a diverse range of groups throughout Australia. In particular, those who live within the Murray-Darling Basin will, I hope, say that it is about time the various governments concerned got their acts together to update the existing legislation. There is just no resource in this country that so defines the problem of this the driest country on earth than the waters and related land of the Murray-Darling Basin. What has been, from an historical standpoint, a question of water management has been handled co-operatively; but the total use of the land and the water resource has been neglected. In fact, many of the problems that we currently recognise in that Murray-Darling Basin exist because of the concentration on one of those resources alone.

How on earth could it have been possible to deal satisfactorily with the matter of water usage without at the same time recognising the vital inter-relationship between land usage and water usage in this vast region? That the problem has been so persistent is probably due to the complex competition within the area of the basin between vastly different interest groups. As I said before, the region covers more than a fifth of this continent-in excess of one million square kilometres. The area is about as large as a quarter of the land mass of continental Europe. At least in the review and the agreement in 1983 there has been some recognition of the need to draw debate towards water quality. I believe that once that move had been made it was a logical extension to look at the inter-relationship between water usage, water quality, land usage, and, if you like, land quality.

Considering that the Murray-Darling Basin production from all sources comes to $10 billion annually, the significance of land and water usage in the region to the economy of Australia cannot be underestimated. Just by way of elucidation, it is estimated that the effect of land usage throughout the system since Europeans first occupied the basin has left vast areas in a degraded state. Much of the area is either fragile or endangered by some form of salination. For example, it is estimated that one million hectares in Victoria alone has been affected by water erosion caused by cropping. Most of this lies within the zone of the Murray River Basin and a further 4.8 billion hectares has been affected by grazing. Most of this land also falls within the Murray Basin. A significant area of New South Wales is also affected by water and wind erosion.

For years concern has been expressed regarding the effects of the various forms of saline contamination of water and soils, but because of the limited legislative mechanisms the magnitude of the salvage operations has been blurred through saline seepage, saline scalds, dry land salting and irrigation salinity, and thousands of hectares of land have been either permanently or temporarily degraded.

I will use Victoria as an example; it is estimated that 45,000 hectares is affected to varying degrees by saline seepage alone. This occurs mainly in the foothills and associated plains of the north, central and north-east regions where clearing of the stabilising vegetation has taken place. What is frightening is that the damage to some areas is considered to be irreversible, at least in the short term. This, I think, highlights the point that was made by the honourable member for Farrer when he said that it is probably two minutes to midnight for the reclamation of the Murray-Darling Basin.

The remediation efforts that must be made will require intensive effort on the part of Federal, State and local governments and the farming communities. As well as gradually degrading large tracts of otherwise useful land, the gradual buildup of salt and other pollutants, such as phosphates and agricultural chemicals, will make it more and more difficult and more and more expensive for rural communities within the Murray-Darling Basin to purify the water and to make it reasonably potable.

There are a number of other problems related to land usage in the Murray-Darling Basin that makes a comprehensive understanding of the land and water characteristics of the zone an absolute imperative. It is to be hoped that the establishment of new arrangements for the River Murray Waters Agreement, as outlined in the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill, will pave the way for a much improved management regime for the entire area. As indicated earlier, the four governments concerned-the Federal Government, the New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments-have all agreed to legislate concurrently and in such a way that an institutional framework, agreed upon by all and intergovernmental in structure, will be established to facilitate and support State-based initiatives.

I think it is not exaggerating to state that stark evidence of degraded land and increased expenditure to maintain returns from both arable and pastoral activities have provided an inescapable logic for all concerned. It is on this base that the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council will be established. What is heartening is the evidence of a holistic approach to the problem of sound, efficient and co-ordinated management. The fact that all four governments will be represented in the Council by Ministers from the portfolios of water, land and environment testifies to the new understanding of the more comprehensive aspects of the total resources of the region. It is to the credit of the Labor governments in the three States and the Commonwealth that the new arrangements have been made.

It has also been recognised that the success of this new arrangement cannot be expected without the involvement of local communities in the decision making process. Likewise, any hope of success will necessitate the development of an informed population in this vast region. The provision within the Bill for the formalisation of a Community Advisory Committee is aimed at forging the communication link between the Council and the communities so integrally involved.

I note that the Minister has stressed that the Bill aims not just at providing information at the local level but also anticipates that local communities will come to accept considerable responsibility for ensuring the improvement of the resources of the basin. In fact, the Community Advisory Committee has been established since the end of 1986 under the Chairmanship of Professor John Burton. Considerable work has already been accomplished. A program of community workshops has been initiated with the first two being held in Echuca and Mildura. Obviously the work that must be done must be ongoing. Not only must degraded resources be reclaimed and areas of risk protected but also new management techniques must be developed and put in place.

It must be recognised that the use of the Murray-Darling resources has not always been made on an equitable basis. This was the point made by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). This applies particularly to the qualitative and quantitative aspects of water usage as well as the long term responsibilities that this generation has to future generations where resource management and utilisation are concerned. Those who live along the Murray downstream of the confluence of the Goulburn and Murray rivers are acutely aware of the quality of water for farming and domestic purposes. The farther downstream communities are located, the more concerned they become. It will be the responsibility of both Council and Advisory Committee to ensure that equity is built into all deliberations regarding resource usage.

There are many Bills that reach this House that can be claimed to be important for the future welfare of this country. However, I am convinced that this Bill is concerned with an issue of a most fundamental kind to the future prosperity of this nation. If we are not to follow the example of northern Africa we must come to place great importance on the significance of the Murray-Darling Basin. I commend the two reports which most honourable members would have seen, the Murray-Darling Basin Environment Resources Study-Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council and the technical report River Salinity, Waterlogging and Land Salinization-Towards an Integrated Management Study. I commend these reports to anybody in this country to read.

We have ample evidence of economic and environmental significance to the nation of this area and the irrevocable evidence of its vulnerability. It is not too late to put in place the appropriate management structures. This Bill provides a legislative trust for such measures. No one in his right might could advocate anything but the most wholehearted support for the measure. I certainly support the Bill. I do not support the amendment. I wish the two bodies great success in their enormously important task and I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I support the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill. As somebody who has had a genuine and lifelong involvement with the River Murray and its problems, the introduction of this legislation gives me real pleasure. I have often argued in this House and elsewhere that the two greatest environmental issues that Australia faces are soil degradation and water resources. It is of real concern to me that those two environmental issues, so important to our nation, seldom get mentioned in the city based national media and are so seldom part of the advocacy of some of the environmental groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Murray-Darling system is, I think, arguably Australia's greatest natural asset. I do not say that because it happens to run through my own electorate. One-seventh of the Australian land area is affected by the Murray-Darling Basin. One-third of the output from our natural resources sector comes from the Murray-Darling Basin. That basin supports some 25 per cent of our cattle and dairying industries, 75 per cent of our irrigated land, and 50 per cent of our sheep grazing and crop lands. For me as a South Australian it is an enormously important source of water for my State. It is often forgotten that during periods of extreme drought, South Australia can draw up to 80 per cent of its water from the River Murray, quite an incredible fact. Yet, in spite of the immense importance of the Murray-Darling system to this country, it still faces great significant problems despite the efforts in recent years by governments such as the Fraser Government whose work in this area has often gone unreported and unapplauded, although it did a great deal.

All these problems that the Murray-Darling Basin faces are in different ways inter-related, but the big loser from all of these problems is eventually my State of South Australia and, more specifically, my electorate, which includes the mouth of the River Murray. Therefore my constituents inevitably end up with everything that has been thrown into one of the longest river systems in the world.

I assure the House that all South Australian Liberal members of parliament will most certainly fight to ensure that our State gets a good deal in the whole issue of the future of the River Murray. That is why I observed that of the five members of the House of Representatives from the Liberal Party from South Australia, four are participating in this debate, and only one out of the eight Labor members from South Australia is participating-an interesting contrast.

The first of these great problems that have to be faced along the Murray River and in the Murray-Darling Basin is the problem of land use. In spite of the great deal of work that has been done by the primary producers and by governments at different levels, there is still a significant degree of overgrazing of semi-arid and arid pastoral areas in the basin. There is still over-cultivation of some crop lands and there are still inappropriate irrigation techniques being used. The result of all of this is a significant decline in soil structure, wind and water erosion, salinity, about which others have spoken at some length, and soil acidity. The new Murray- Darling Basin Ministerial Council, in its report which was referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), says that the mistakes in land use planning are now leading to a decline in annual production of some $220m. So we can see that there is always that close correlation between efficient and responsible land use and economic return.

These land use problems require urgent action, and that urgent action has, as its main theme, the co-ordination of land use, which is absolutely vital if we are to get solutions to those problems. We need a co-ordination of drought policies and we also need, let me emphasise, funding for soil conservation, something which is very low priority with this Government. In this financial year it is providing just $6m for the national soil conservation program, but it is providing to a body such as the Office of the Supervising Scientist $5m alone. Yet remember what I said at the beginning: soil degradation is one of the greatest environmental problems facing our nation.

The second major problem as far as the Murray-Darling system is concerned is the problem of water quality. Others have spoken of the growth of salinity and turbidity as the river continues to wend its way west. Salinity has always existed in the River Murray. It is nothing new and it was not brought there by European settlers. But the land use decisions since European settlement have seriously exacerbated the levels of salinity, and the loss of tree cover has also been a very major problem. In 1981 the levels of salinity in South Australia rose to record highs and it was a time of very great concern for all inhabitants of my State. Those problems have not returned since, largely because there have been good river flows. I say that by way of a warning, because that problem of salinity still remains a very serious one and, if we have a drought, that level of salinity will return. Action is necessary and the action must be co-ordinated. We need integrated catchment management throughout the basin, we need co-ordinated ground water management programs, we need co-ordinated surface water policies and we need co-ordinated waste water management. All of those things require serious and important co-ordination.

The third great problem of the Murray-Darling system is the need for protection of the natural ecosystem. The natural ecosystem in the Murray-Darling system has been the big loser over the past 200 years. Let us remember, by way of example, that there are some 7,000 discrete wetlands in the Murray-Darling system, which is an enormous number. But the natural ecosystem of the Murray-Darling has changed very dramatically since 1788. Some of the recreational and economic uses of the system have been extremely environmentally insensitive. Again, we need much better co-ordination of recreation and economic policies, and we need a significant improvement in the levels of research to ensure that the natural ecosystem of the Murray-Darling system is properly protected.

The fourth major problem, and it is a related problem, is the need for the protection of the natural flora and fauna of the system. The native vegetation in the Murray-Darling system is now some 50 per cent of the native vegetation present when European settlement occurred. Less than 9 per cent of native vegetation is left in the wheat and sheep belt. Ten plant species are now extinct and 37 are endangered; 20 mammal species are extinct and 16 are endangered; and 35 bird and reptile species are also endangered. Again, we need action. We need action quickly and that action has to be co-ordinated to ensure that we get effective conservation strategies and effective management plans.

Revegetation is vastly important in the Murray-Darling system, and is not spoken about often enough either in this House or in the national forums, particularly in the media. As others have said before, vegetation clearance has led to rising ground water, and that has brought about the problems of salinity, about which we have spoken so much. The national tree program should be more directed towards the Murray-Darling system, and I think it deserves significantly greater funding than it currently gets. If I could use language which is not exaggerated, I think it is pathetic that the national tree program in this country receives less than $1m per annum in funds. When we think of the hundreds of millions of dollars that are pumped into all sorts of schemes, it is simply incredible that the national tree program is apparently regarded by the Government as discretionary and not terribly important. Yet it is fundamental to the survival of the Murray-Darling system as an effective river system.

We do need effective action in all of those four areas that I have very briefly described. We have a long history of trying to address the problems of the Murray-Darling system, and everybody knows that. If we go back to the constitutional debates at the end of the last century, we will see that the South Australian statesmen were arguing vehemently for the Murray-Darling system, particularly for the River Murray itself, to be controlled at the national level. That is not something which is argued for particularly vehemently any more, and I will not comment too much on that. But certainly in the last century it was a cause celebre for the South Australian farmers of the Australian Constitution. They did pretty badly because, as the downstream States, we ended up with section 100 of the Constitution, which hands the whole thing, lock, stock and barrel, over to the States and ensures that the Commonwealth does not get too much of a look in. I suppose that is a problem for South Australia, although people from other States seem to think that is an appropriate solution. We fought in the last century, and I can tell the House that we will keep fighting, and I suspect it will be members from both sides of the House.

When I was elected to the Parliament I made a statement on 6 March 1985. It was one of the first Press releases I put out as a member of Parliament and it was at the time of the launching of the River Murray Interpretative Centre in the town of Goolwa in my electorate. I said in that Press release that I thought that, whilst the River Murray Commission, as it then stood, had done an excellent job, it should be replaced by a national co-ordinating authority for the whole of the Murray-Darling system. I received some criticism for making that statement. I would have to say that I regard that criticism as a little ill-informed. I am glad to say that this legislation that the Government has finally brought forward is-I would not be so vain as to suggest that it was based on my one Press release-coincidentally in line with what I was talking about back on 6 March 1985. Perhaps I am being too modest, but I suspect that the Government's initiative was pushed along largely by other sources.

Naturally, as somebody who has held those views for many years, I welcome the establishment of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission replacing the River Murray Commission, its Ministerial Council, which it must have, and also the Community Advisory Committee about which I have not time to speak. It is important to get direct community involvement in the management of the Murray-Darling system. It would be foolish to do anything other than that. The new arrangements, the new Commission and the new Council will have a broader geographical responsibility, and that is important. It is disappointing that the old Government decided not to become involved in this great enterprise. I hope that in future the Queensland Government will reconsider its position.

The legislation also provides for a broader scope. We are dealing not just with water quantity, which is where the River Murray Commission started off, or with water quality, in relation to which the Fraser Government expanded the role of the River Murray Commission, we are dealing also with the land and environmental matters of which I was speaking earlier. It is argued-it is certainly argued quite strongly on this side of the House-that these new arrangements are somewhat cumbersome, and that is true. In an ideal world it would be easy to say that they are too cumbersome and that we should streamline the arrangements and make them simpler. If only that were possible, but section 100 of the Constitution means that we can do little else but continue with cumbersome arrangements which involve all the States and the Commonwealth, and all the portfolios in the States and the Commonwealth which relate to the efficient management of the system. It is cumbersome, but unfortunately I see little alternative. I congratulate the Government on this initiative, and I am glad that it followed up my suggestion of March 1985

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the problems of salinity control and now wish to refer the House to the annual report of the River Murray Commission. I do not know the reason for the delay, but a report that is 16 months late runs the risk of becoming almost irrelevant. Let me quote from the report to emphasise the concerns of South Australians, and indeed of all Australians, about the rising salinity level of the River Murray waters and the action that is being taken. The Commission on page 18 of its report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is continuing to work towards the acceptance by Governments of a comprehensive Water Quality Management Plan and has adopted the following objective for salinity control.
It says that its objective is:

To support an economically, socially and environmentally acceptable package of works and measures comprising salt interception, dilution and land management (including the possible admission of drainage to the River Murray) which will result in the salinity of the River Murray, as measured at Morgan, being reduced so that, by 1995, it will be less than 800 EC for 95 per cent of the time.

Given that the World Health Organisation has determined that 830 electric conductivity (EC) units is the upper limit for human consumption and that Morgan is the start of the pipeline to Adelaide, I would have thought that the River Murray Commission's objective was a minimum requirement, not an objective to be worked towards. The Commission is saying that it wants no more than 800 EC units for 95 per cent of the time. That is only 30 EC units below the World Health Organisation's upper limit for human consumption. I regard that as a minimum requirement, especially when one examines the EC readings at Morgan as provided in the annual report. At page 49 one sees the monthly EC readings for 1985-86 at Morgan, which range from 1,110 EC units in July 1985 down to 510 in October, and rising again to 990 in June 1986. At present according to the River Murray Commission's annual report, the EC readings are far in excess of World Health Organisation recommendations, and far in excess of what it is aiming for as part of its objective for 1995, which is 800 EC units for 95 per cent of the time.

The problem is that South Australia is not its own master in these matters. Certainly we must ensure that we control the amount of saline water entering the system on our side of the border, but there is little that we can do about what happens in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria without the co-operation of those governments. I highlight the problem by again referring to the annual report of the River Murray Commission. In relation to salinity-and this is just one example of where the salinity is coming from-page 19 of the report states:
Barr Creek is the most significant single source of saline water in the River system.

In order to ensure that the honourable member for Murray does not get upset, I recognise that work is being done in relation to Barr Creek. But this is just one example of where saline water is entering the river system. The report goes on:

and, although flows from Barr Creek are generally low, they can affect salinity along the entire downstream length of the River Murray. In August, heavy rain across the south-eastern catchments of the Murray produced minor flooding, flushing a `slug' of highly saline water from Barr Creek into the Murray. As it moved downstream this `slug' produced the highest salinity recorded in the monitoring program at Euston (945 E.C. units compared with a previous maximum value of 514 E.C. units).

That just points out that whatever we do in South Australia we are susceptible to what takes place in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. Some work is being done-as the honourable member for Murray would want us to acknowledge and which I have acknowledged-and the River Murray Commission says that during 1985-86 the operation of salinity mitigation schemes resulted in an estimated 231,600 tonnes of salt being prevented from entering the River Murray. But even so, unacceptably high salinity levels are still being recorded. Therefore, action must be taken in the Murray-Darling Basin to ensure that we take care of this immensely valuable national resource.

There is growing frustration with the view that to expect all the State governments involved to co-operate in concert with the Commonwealth, to protect the interest of each other-sometimes to the disadvantage of or against their own individual interests-is a forlorn hope. Under our Constitution we have to seek a co-operative approach and frustration arises because more action is needed. Therefore, when the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, on 27 March this year issued a statement suggesting the problem was to be solved, he raised great expectations. He said:

The Federal Government and the Victorian, New South Wales and South Australian governments agreed in Melbourne today to create a Murray-Darling Basin Commission to combat salinity and environmental problems in South-East Australia.
He went on:

. . . the four government, three State agreement was `historic' and provided a framework to overcome the degradation of resources in the Basin, which was something that Governments had been trying and failing to do since Federation.

That all sounds great. But my fear is that the great expectations that Senator Evans raised will not be fulfilled. By looking at the legislation itself, we see that the new Commission will have no additional constitutional power. It will continue to exercise the traditional authority to regulate the flow and division of Murray River water between the three States. It will continue to exercise the authority or the more recent power given to it over water quality in the river and the advisory function of water quality in the State rivers flowing into the Murray. The stated purpose of the new arrangement encompassing the Murray-Darling Basin is to broaden the advisory role to include land, water and environment management in the basin and, hopefully, by the inclusion of the responsible Ministers and officials, obtain greater co-operation and co-ordination in the policies of each of the governments in relation to the region. I earnestly hope that it achieves its objectives. But I am less convinced that the Government understands that this should be amongst its highest priorities.

In particular, I note there is no commitment to additional finance to assist in the control of salinity, high water tables, drainage and so on. The new arrangement involves more State Ministers. Whether that will help or hinder decision making in this co-operative venture, we will have to wait and see. Certainly, the new arrangement appears to be extraordinarily bureaucratic. I believe that in the main, solutions to the problems-especially salinity-are known. It is more a matter of getting on with the job. Of course, that will need a commitment from State and Federal governments which has not been forthcoming to date. Until it is, the problem will not be resolved.

The previous coalition Government took the bull by the horns and made a commitment to improve our water resources under the national water resources program. The current Government has reduced spending in real terms on that commitment. In addition, in 1982-83 we had proposed a special bicentennial water program. That was also scrapped by the Labor Government. More Labor talk and legislation will not fix the problem. In particular, South Australia is reliant on action. We need action and we need it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We often hear comments from Opposition members in this House that the Government does not spend enough money on A or B. We often hear comments about problems with the Australian Constitution and its defects. The Constitution is a document which was framed by six Crown colonies prior to 1901 and is recognised by any intelligent Australian as having an enormous number of defects. All Australians recognise that in 1987 Australia is a Commonwealth, a nation, and no longer six Crown colonies. Yet whenever the Government comes forward and recognises the defects in the Constitution, the Opposition opposes every reasonable suggestion for constitutional reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we have heard complaints from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) about section 100 of the Constitution and the fact that it does not allow the Commonwealth-the Australian Parliament-the power to take the necessary legislative steps to control enormous problems in this country. Yet, if this Government tried to resolve the problems of section 100, what would this snivelling Opposition do? It would oppose it. It would not have the courage or the conviction of its own beliefs to stand up in front of the Australian people and say that the change was necessary. So Opposition members stand up in this Parliament and, as usual, find fault with the Constitution but, as usual, they lack the courage or the conviction of their beliefs to support rational constitutional change.

Then the honourable member for Barker said that the Government did not spend enough money. This statement came from a member of a party which likes to think it comprises economic rationalists. These are the people who intended to cut 16 per cent from Commonwealth expenditure at the last election, but at the same time promised to lower taxes. After saying that they would slash 16 per cent from Commonwealth expenditure, they tell us that we should increase expenditure on the Murray-Darling problems. They stand condemned by their own policies and by the nonsense that they speak so regularly in this House.

I have some personal knowledge of the Murray-Darling system. For seven years I lived on the banks of the Murray River in a little town called Cohuna in the Murray Valley. Cohuna is some 15 miles east of Kerang and some 38 miles west of a little town called Echuca.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were the mayor, weren't you?

—No, I never got to be mayor. I should have been, mind you. Had I been, the town would have been well served but I never had the chance. Two speakers tonight have spoken about the infamous-or the famous-Barr Creek. Barr Creek emanates from the Cohuna irrigation area. It flows from the dairy districts of Cohuna, its flood irrigation zones, back into the Murray River. It is a fascinating creek. Some years ago, long before flood irrigation was introduced, the Barr Creek was a lovely, meandering little river. It was renowned for its duck, quail and snipe habitats. Snipe is an endangered species today. They travel from Japan and breed in this country. Barr Creek, because of its undergrowth and its surrounding ecological systems, was well known as a breeding ground for Japanese snipe.

SPEECH.PARA: The creek was very good fishing. It was full of warm water fish unique to the Murray-Darling system-the callop, the cod, the bony bream, the grunter, the black bream-unusual fish dependent upon a very rare ecological system, the Murray-Darling system. The long-necked tortoise and the Murray River crayfish, found nowhere else in the world, bred there. This is what the Barr Creek used to be. Then along came the Victorian State Rivers and Water Supply Commission some years ago and said, `We have a problem in the Murray district. We are flooding all the farms with water from the Murray, which is creating a lot of salt. We need some system to get the salt away from the farms and back into the Murray River'. So they got their surveyors out who pegged little markers all along the old meandering Barr Creek and straightened it. They got rid of all the undergrowth, the rushes, the cumbungi-

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the creek?

—It is no longer a creek. It used to be a creek. It is now a salt water drain. There are no longer any fish in the Barr Creek. No longer do ducks or Japanese snipe breed on the Barr Creek. As I said, it is a straight, salt water drain. Not one bend is left in it. We did this as a society because we allowed to develop in Australia a system of flood irrigation, which we now know to be ecologically disastrous. At very subsidised prices we allow farmers to divert water from the Murray River and, by flood irrigation methods, to flood flat land. It is a most uneconomical method of providing water for agricultural purposes. Even with modern techniques, such as laser grading, which requires a less gradual slope on a paddock for the flood irrigation system to work, we nevertheless use probably less than 30 per cent of the water applied to the ground which is actively cost-effective in the production of crops or dairy products. The rest of the water simply runs across the land, goes back into the delta systems and then into the Murray system again. It is an enormously non-cost-effective means of providing water. But that is the system which previous governments have developed. It is still prominent in New South Wales. In the Colleambally, Griffith, Tongala, Shepparton and Cohuna districts our fruit and dairy producers and rice growers so often use their water in a non-cost-effective and ecologically dangerous way.

SPEECH.PARA: We get increased water tables by this method and produce, from what was once an inland ocean-the whole of Australia was once an inland ocean-great amounts of salt. With flood irrigation the salt flows back into the system. Areas like the Barr Creek become almost pure salt. What do we do with it? We put it back into the Murray River.

The honourable member for Barker apportions blame to Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. That is pretty weak. He forgot to mention that Renmark delivers nine tonnes of salt per day during the irrigation season into the Murray River. It is fair to say that that nine tonnes of salt is not the worst problem. If one looks at it analytically, Renmark is not the most salinity-producing irrigation area in Australia. But it does not help much when honourable members from South Australia say that it is our fault when South Australia has not yet resolved the problems of the Renmark irrigation system, and when the State Government of Victoria still, at subsidised rates--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is old know-all talking.

—I know a damned sight more about this subject than the honourable member, who comes from dry Queensland. The reality is that this country will not solve the salinity problems of the Murray River until such time as the State governments properly recognise their responsibilities and take proper measures to resolve the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, those bleating so loudly on my right are representative of the parties that created the problem. It was the National Party in Victoria which, in post-war years, said, `We need soldier settlement schemes'. It was the National Party in Victoria which cut up prime broadacre farm lands into soldier settlement blocks and put soldier settlers on them. It was the National Party which made uneconomic agricultural holdings dependent upon irrigation. It was the National Party which did all this in Victoria and, in fact, encouraged it in New South Wales. The result is that, since the National Party did this, to take the Shepparton area as an example, when I was a young man, some years ago now--
—A long time ago.

—It was a long time ago. I recall that around Shepparton we had hundreds of soldier settlers on blocks of no more than 10 acres. Of course, at the end of the post-war period, when all these 10-acre blocks became productive, we overproduced. At about the same time as we overproduced stone fruits, the British joined the European Economic Community. In those post-war years we found hundreds of farmers put on these little blocks by the National Party, dependent upon irrigation water and with no market for their product. If honourable members opposite want to bleat about the history of farming in this country, I will take them on day after day, because I know their history. They have done more damage to farmers in this country than any other party, and they stand condemned for what they have done to farmers. If they want to bleat in this House about what farmers are on about, I will take them on any day of the week. I know their history better than they do. The irrigation problems that they have caused by these close settlements are the problems this country faces today. Yet they still come into this House, forgetting their history and forgetting that their policies in the past in this country created irrigation districts which are no longer necessarily economically responsible-and they bleat. They do not know their own history, they do not know what they have done and they are ignorant.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, do you see what I mean? When one tells the truth in this place they are like a paddock full of ewes-they bleat. The problem of the irrigation system in this country will be improved by this legislation; there is no question about that. It is a step in the right direction and I am pleased that the Opposition, including members of the bleating National Party, is supporting it. They do know when somebody is doing the right thing, but they never know when they have done the wrong thing. I am pleased that they are supporting this legislation, but I still believe that we will not solve the problems of salinity in the Murray River until the State governments, whatever their political colours may be, take full responsibility for the low cost of irrigation waters, take responsibility for the historical past which has created flood irrigation districts of Australia and take responsibility for the fact that each State, be it South Australia, Queensland, Victoria or New South Wales, is individually creating the salt problem. The Commonwealth Government can only set forth the procedures to enable people to negotiate and solve the problems. It will be the States' responsibility. I hope and believe that it is a step in the right direction and I have great confidence that, in the future, this problem will be solved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I just listened to the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), and I have never before heard a speaker in this House sound so convincing but speak so much drivel. I must invite the honourable member for McEwen into the Murrumbidgee and Coleambally irrigation areas one day to address the farmer groups there and hear what they have to say about what he is trying to present to Parliament tonight. But enough of the honourable member for McEwen. I think we can discard what he said, because it is absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987 replaces the River Murray Commission with the Murray-Darling Basin Commission which, in addition to assuming the statutory responsibilities of the old commission, will play an advisory role to the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council on water, land and environmental matters in the Murray-Darling Basin, not covered in the 1982 River Murray Waters Agreement. The Commonwealth Government and the State governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia will each provide two commissioners to represent water, land and environmental interests. The Bill also establishes a Ministerial Council comprising three Ministers from each Government who are responsible for water, land and environmental policies. The previous ministerial arrangements were for water Ministers only.

The Bill being debated today also establishes a Community Advisory Committee made up of approximately 17 representatives of regional and national organisations which will bring together and present to the Ministerial Council community views on the management of the natural resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. I hope the Ministerial Council takes particular notice of this Committee's recommendations. It is important that co-operation between the Ministerial council and the Community Advisory Committee is practised. Given the fact that the Advisory Committee has no powers, and given the additional bureaucratic structure of the Commission, it will be very easy for the Ministerial Council and the standing Committee to ignore the concerns of the regional and national advisers.

An organisation of great standing that will have representation on the Advisory Council will be the Murray Valley League, which for many years has carried the battle to protect the environment of the Murray Valley almost alone. The point is very important as the landholders and the people of the Murray-Darling Basin who rely on the water are extremely concerned about the present and future water quality and land management practices in the basin.

One of the big problems hampering the revitalisation of the Murray-Darling Basin is associated with salinity, and many speakers have touched on that tonight. There is a very major salinity problem in some areas along both the Murray and the Darling. The severity of the problem is highlighted by the fact that 26 per cent of the total land area in the State-sponsored irrigation schemes in the Murray-Darling Basin-an area equivalent to about 65 per cent of the area actually irrigated-is affected by shallow water-tables. In addition, 10 per cent of the area actually irrigated is now salt affected.

It is estimated that, without intervention, in New South Wales, the area with shallow water-tables, will extend from about 200,000 hectares in 1985 to almost 300,000 hectares by 1995. This area is almost entirely in the riverina plains zone with the largest potential increase occurring in the Coleambally irrigation area.

Salinisation causes a reduction in productivity and reduces the variety of produce able to be grown. In areas of salinisation, farm enterprises are usually restricted to pasture-based enterprises and shallow-rooted annual crops. This has the effect of reducing a farmer's ability to change his crops in response to varying market conditions. There is, however, as with many problems Australia has faced over the years, a bright spot on the horizon through the good work of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Through its research, this organisation is working towards showing to those using the Murray-Darling River system-or, for that matter, any freshwater supply in Australia-a correct production management program on a substantial basis.

The main aim is to understand how to manage the catchment system so that it remains productive into the future. Unfortunately, in some cases these programs may mean the forgoing of short term profits in order to enable long term viability. This refers particularly to irrigation cropping systems such as rice. The CSIRO in Griffith and Albury, under the leadership of Dr David Mitchell, is carrying out invaluable research and is working in close liaison with the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and other State government departments.

The Fresh Water Resources Centre at Albury is examining ways of controlling and improving water quality that often owes its poor state to its use in irrigation areas. Unfortunately, the new legislation will not help this research because, as in many areas, the CSIRO is suffering the effect of funding cutbacks. One problem is the loss of staff and, although it is not crucial at the moment, the Government must be careful not to let staff numbers drop below those levels essential for the viability of the operation. The CSIRO has been asked to seek the support of the private sector but, unfortunately at present, the productive sector with which the CSIRO Fresh Water Research Centre is allied, is not particularly viable and is itself finding it difficult to survive.

As CSIRO scientists point out, if they do not succeed in their research and the Murray- Darling Basin is not managed correctly, no enterprise in the basin has a future. The river system is essential to life. With all the obvious concerns and long term implications of increasing salinisation, it is incredible that the River Murray Commission is to receive a new management structure and yet no extra finance to assist with improvements to the waters of the Murray- Darling Basin.

TALK.START.PARA: —No extra money?

—There will be no extra money. Many of the government-sponsored irrigation schemes of the Murray-Darling Basin were developed at the beginning of this century. Today we have an inefficient and inadequate irrigation infrastructure or, in some cases, lack of infrastructure, contributing significantly to the problems of river salinity, waterlogging and land salinisation and constraining more efficient water delivery and use.

SPEECH.PARA: Today there is a total of some 13,500 kilometres of supply channels and 7,000 kilometres of drainage channels to support State-sponsored irrigation in the basin but because of age, construction materials, the soils on which they were built, the design capacity and changing water demands, much of these are now assessed as being deficient in terms of their ability to supply current irrigation demands or to deliver or remove irrigation water efficiently and effectively. In total, 41 per cent of the supply channels are considered inadequate to varying degrees, the highest proportion being in New South Wales schemes. The major problems relate to the insufficient capacity of many existing supply systems to meet adequately today's irrigation demands and many irrigators therefore receive water on a roster system, which often cannot be tailored to actual crop needs.

Another major problem is in relation to leakage. Many supply and drainage channels leak. It has been estimated that in New South Wales some 25 per cent of ground water accessions are from channel seepage. In addition there are over 42,000 water control structures in the irrigation schemes in the basin, and about 12,000 are considered to be variously inadequate to some degree in terms of water capacity or excessive leakage. The constraints imposed by existing infrastructure, or a lack of infrastructure, will become more critical as irrigators strive to adjust to changing market conditions and governments try to introduce efficiency-motivated policies such as transferability of water entitlements. The limited capacity of many supply systems will prove an increasing constraint to more efficient irrigation water supply and use, and the lack of drainage infrastructure will increasingly add to major land degradation and losses in agricultural productivity.

The Fraser Government demonstrated some foresight in January 1983, when it announced a special water resources development. It was intended that the coalition would spend $70m per annum over five years as a bicentennial program aimed at accelerating the development of new water resource projects. These projects involved the construction of additional infrastructure and the upgrading of worn out or obsolete infrastructure. As history tells us, the coalition was defeated not long after that commitment was given and unfortunately for the Murray-Darling Basin, the current Federal Government never honoured the coalition's commitment. This commitment to water resource improvements was to be funded in part on a dollar for dollar basis by the States. But of course, in New South Wales the State Government regards the provision of water to users as a subsidy, as does the honourable member for McEwen. It talks about the user pays system and describes its July 1987 decision not to increase water charges as being a subsidy to irrigators, which is totally wrong.

All governments should charge for water on the basis of the cost of delivery and not for the actual resource, as water is a renewable commodity which enables the provision of cheap food for Australia, as well as providing export income for our nation. There is a general theme running through speeches given recently, particularly by some New South Wales and Victorian State Government bureaucrats. While not obvious to some they still point out that their Governments believe that the so-called user should pay. The user, of course, they regard as being the irrigators and they intend to price water in such a way that will, first, allow for capital works such as dams and storage works to be paid for by the irrigator; secondly, make the irrigator pay for the water, which is wrong because water is a renewable resource that does not belong to Government; and, thirdly, use the high cost of water as a means of reducing its use. What it is difficult to get through to the bureaucrats and politicians who push this line is that to increase the cost of water much more would destroy the viability of many irrigators who are presently providing relatively cheap food for the domestic and overseas markets.

In the area of on-farm works and measures, the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council has recommended the use of improved irrigation methods such as land forming and the recycling of surface drainage water in the Riverina Plain. These have the potential to reduce accessions to the ground water as well as reducing waterlogging and land salinisation. However, the report admits that the current economic situation facing many irrigators makes it difficult for new and improved irrigation techniques to be practised.

If the Government were fair dinkum, it would be providing a more generous write-off provision than it has. Recently the New South Wales Government changed the name of the former Water Conservation and Irrigation Commission which then became the Water Resources Commission to the Department of Water Resources. Close to home, in the Murrumbidgee and Coleambally irrigation areas, we find a concentration of irrigators growing rice and horticultural products. Because of the good management practices in that area, no salt enters the River Murray from the Murrumbidgee River.

The manager of the Department of Water Resources, Mr Mark Smyth, and his experienced staff carry out the often unsung but invaluable work of caring for the physical well-being of the vast Murrumbidgee and Coleambally Irrigation Areas. As a matter of fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, today one of those people who has been with the Department of Water Resources and its predecessors for 43 years, Mr Laurie Fletcher, retired from the Griffith office of the Department. I know all honourable members would wish him well in his retirement.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that some of my colleagues wish to speak, and although I have much more to say about the irrigation systems and this Bill, I shall conclude my speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Practically all the speakers who have contributed to this debate are closely involved with the River Murray because their electorates are in South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales. I am from New South Wales, but I am not directly involved so far as my electorate is concerned, but as an Australian I am very concerned about it.
—And a former Minister for Water Resources.

—I have had quite a lot to do with water resources in the New South Wales Parliament. I found it particularly interesting that the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) a moment ago referred to some early experiences. I can recall the time that he took me into the Wakool area and we saw people pumping salt water 1 1/2 times saltier than the sea into the River Murray because of an experiment that was approved by the Department of Water Resources at the time to reclaim land that was severely affected by salt. As the honourable member will recall, that was successful. We also went to see a farmer who had a one-year-old car in his garage, but the sump had rusted out of that vehicle. It was an arid zone, a very fertile part of Australia, but practically the whole of that district had gone out of production because of salinity.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, all Australians are worried about the situation in the Murray Basin generally. It is so essential to us as parliamentarians that we become involved. Of course, I have always been a very strong States righter and I respect the fact that the States themselves have been jealous about their water resources, their share of the water, the quality of the water, the drainage of their fields, and particularly of the production that comes from those fields. Since 1917 the three vital States have been closely associated with each other under the operation of the River Murray Commission. With the settlement of the European race in Australia and the agriculturalists who went into that very fertile part of Australia but who could not produce without an adequate water supply, the Commission was able, over a number of years, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) clearly outlined earlier, to develop that area and harness additional water resources as the need actually arose. That was essential. The Murray Basin generally grew as the demand for water by Australians grew.

I have been to India and observed, 1,000 miles from the coast, salt rising up through fertile land of almost 1,000 feet of alluvial soil. That was also because of irrigation over a very long period. The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) may criticise the fact that proper standards of agriculture have not been applied in irrigation areas, but farmers did not know that mistakes were being made; those farmers were not to blame. They were advised and encouraged to flood irrigate the land. In the future they may have to do the same thing, but we know more about drainage today. We know what the practices should be, and better farming methods must be used, and they will be used as the years go on.

I do not want to say much about the technical side of the Murray water resources and what is being done, but let me say this: I hope that over the year ahead, when we look at the need for water resources in Australia, State and Federal governments will join together to fund essential water development projects for the benefit of this nation. We have a great responsibility to feed the people of the world and to make it economic for our farmers to produce on their farms, and the only way in which they can do that is by being able to irrigate in all types of seasons to grow the crops that they wish grow. This is essential.

We must never criticise the Ord scheme. Maybe it was premature but is it not great to see us do something before time? The Ord scheme would certainly have succeeded and would have been producing crops if the growers had been able efficiently to market the product. The problem with the Ord scheme is that it is so far removed from the markets it would have to supply. It was good to see that scheme built because it was undertaken when costs were low. If we undertook the Ord scheme today it would cost at least $1,000m, whereas I suppose it cost only one-sixth or one-seventh of that amount. The scheme is there for the betterment of Australian people over the years to come. Mr Deputy Speaker, it nearly makes one cry, realising the benefit of irrigation, to see our water running out to sea in all the coastal streams around Australia when that water could be harnessed to do something positive to grow the crops and increase the viability of the farmers on the land today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even for urban use.

—Yes. These water schemes unify water supplies for farm lands and urban areas. I refer to Adelaide. In this debate we spoke about Whyalla and other areas that depend upon the Murray. If one flies up the Murray from the sea to the east one sees how large it is. There are small streams in my electorate that are as big as the Murray is at its mouth. As the honourable member for Farrer said earlier, it is one minute to midnight for the Murray and, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is one minute to 11 o'clock now, so I must conclude. We cannot afford to let this country of ours go to waste and not take advantage of these resources that we have. They were given to us by nature and they should be harnessed by us for the benefit of the people concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted to see the legislation before the Parliament. The Minister for Resources and I often agree on many things. We have talked about roads in the past; we are talking about water resources now; we will talk about the fishing industry this week. Practical things are being done and I will always be happy in this House to support very practical measures whether the Government or the Opposition brings them in. The Government will always have my support, my electors' support and, I am sure, the support of the National Party of Australia while it undertakes schemes that we believe will be to the benefit of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the 12 speakers who have participated in the debate. I think the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) finished on a very nice note, concord. It has been gratifying to hear the broad support that the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill has attracted from both sides of the House. The major point of concerns seems to be whether the Federal Government has gone far enough. Concern, moreover, has been focused in relation to salinity in the River Murray and related irrigation activity. It seems also from some of the comments that some honourable members have missed the essential thrust of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The River Murray Commission has effectively addressed river regulation. What we are now seeking to address is an integrated natural resource management in the basin as a whole. A number of speakers made the point about the size of the basin which is one-seventh of the area of this nation. Some two million people live there and some 61 local government bodies are located along the Murray. It is an enormous area, an enormous wealth producing section of our nation. We need to address the problems of the basin as a whole and how each problem relates to the other. We should not simply single out the river or the immediate use of the river as has been done on past occasions.

What we are doing through this legislation is providing a co-operative framework to enable a common approach to inter-active problems in resource management. The underlining theme of this is partnership. The basin's problems can be solved only by a mutually supporting program of activities at the Commonwealth, State, local government and community levels. I again make the point that one Federal Government, three State governments, 61 local government bodies and innumerable community groups are involved. The exercise is to bring all of those differing views and differing interests together, to bring them into harmony, to bring them to an approach towards management of the basin that really addresses the problem, not just directs itself to a section of the problem.

The point was made about providing more money. I repeat what I said the other night. The contributions from honourable members of the National Party of Australia particularly in debates after dinner call for more money to be spent. In the earlier part of the day there is always criticism that the Government is spending too much money, that the deficit is too high, that taxes should be reduced. We simply cannot have it both ways. It is a matter of making better use of the money that is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I opposed building a new dam.

—The honourable member for Farrer makes the point that he opposes the building of a new dam. I was not referring to the honourable member because he was not calling for additional money. However, I make that general point. More money is not the solution. The essential ingredient is better management. Management, not just money, is the answer to the problem we have. We are creating the opportunity to bring to bear improved management policies and strategies throughout the basin, not just along the area of the river. It is within those strategies that we will play an appropriate and responsible role as a Federal government, including in relation to finance. In partnership with the States and the basin community we will be better able to protect and to develop responsibly the crucial resources of the basin.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate a number of references were made-I add my recognition-to the tremendous amount of work that was done by the former honourable member for Hawker, our former colleague Ralph Jacobi. He did a tremendous amount of work and made representations on the problems of the Murray. If he were present this evening he would be very happy to see this legislation going through the Parliament. Much of the credit for it is due to him.

Reference was made to the cost of the Community Advisory Committee, particularly by my colleague the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), which is in the order of $50,000 in 1987-88 and it will be split four ways between the governments concerned. Reference was also made to a substantial new bureaucracy being established. I make the point that the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission will rely heavily for expertise on the Commonwealth and, in particular, the States. There will be no new bureaucracy and no expansion of the bureaucracy. The new institutional arrangements will facilitate and focus co-operative action.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the headquarters?

—I was coming to the headquarters. The honourable member proposed that they be located in Albury-Wodonga. The practice has been that governments have felt that Canberra is most convenient and is a central location within the basin. That has been the experience in the past. I share the points made by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) about soil degradation and water resources but I reject his criticism about not enough money being spent. He also criticised the national afforestation program. I make the point that that program did not exist under former conservative governments. It is a creation of this Government and it is being funded as we can afford it within the resources that responsible government allows at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference was made to the contribution of Queensland. Queensland will not be represented on the Commission; it is not participating. Queensland does send an observer to Standing Committee meetings, so there is an input to that extent and there is some contribution from it. For the record, I note that Queensland constitutes about a quarter of the total basin area and about 3 1/2 per cent of the water flow, so I suspect in some of the comments earlier there may have been a misunderstanding as to how much Queensland was contributing to the problem.

The tabling of the report was raised by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). The problem in tabling the Commission's report is that accounts of the Commission's activities in each State-and they are carried out by State authorities on behalf of the Commission-have to be audited by each State before they are passed to the Commonwealth for clearance. That process, in itself, takes a lot of time. I am advised that in the case of the 1985-86 report there were also some additional printing difficulties beyond the control of the River Murray Commission. Whilst the delay is understandable, it is not desirable. I will be looking at means of expediting the tabling of future reports of the Commission.

I conclude by referring to the amendment that has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), to the second reading motion. The first part of the amendment refers to recognition of previous governments and others. I make the point that this evening quite substantive recognition has been made of people and governments of the past which have contributed to this problem. I am sure that the honourable member does not suggest that we refer to each government and each individual since 1917. I think that goes without saying. Certainly, an amendment to the second reading motion is not needed to make that point. It is supported by honourable members that recognition is due to all those who have made a contribution.

The second part of the amendment refers to bureaucratic, administrative and consultative arrangements. The objective of the amending legislation that is before us is to achieve efficient action and co-ordination. The last part of the amendment is to the effect that we provide a firm commitment to finance the already known necessary remedial measures along the River Murray. I have covered that point in my explanation of the general financial arrangements. This Government will play its responsible role in the financing of whatever activities are needed. It is not simply a case of more money; it is more a case of better management of the basin and all its resources as a whole. The Government has no choice but to reject the amendment and commend the Bill to the House.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to place on record the need for a continuation of the Federal Government's involvement in the steel industry, either through the extension of the existing steel industry plan or through the establishment of a new steel industry plan mark 2. As honourable members will be aware, the city of Whyalla is located in my electorate. As a resident of that proud city, I am very concerned that its future as a steel producing centre may be under threat.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most concerned at the decision of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) to shed another 500 jobs at its steel plant in Whyalla over the next five years, and BHP's insistence that it wants no part of any steel industry plan after 1988. Why is this so when only 12 months ago BHP's group manager for information analysis, Mr Mark Pirola, was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying:
. . . that BHP's steel division has become the most profitable steel corporation in the world with the lowest global operating costs . . .

At the same time BHP's steel industry group managers admitted that the Federal Government's steel industry plan had provided a stable environment for investment. As late as February of this year, steel management at Port Kembla was reported in the Australian Financial Review as saying that the steel industry plan had added `timely impetus' to developments which had led to a 54 per cent profit rise for BHP's steel division in the previous financial year. Yet now we hear that BHP wants no further government involvement in the steel industry after the conclusion of the steel industry plan at the end of 1988.

No government involvement in the industry would mean that there could be no guarantees about job security in the industry-indeed, it seems that BHP cannot guarantee that it will remain in the steel industry. It appears that BHP does not consider that its steel group profit of $200m in the last financial year is a sufficient return on investment. Yet return on investment is a long term proposition. Perhaps some of the new larger shareholders in BHP have become too used to making huge profits in a matter of days from shuffling papers. They perhaps do not realise that it takes years to gain a reasonable return from investment in productive industry.

In 1984, the chief economist with John Lysaght (Australia) Ltd, J. N. Barber, pointed out that he thought that a five-year steel industry plan was too short. Speaking of the steel industry plan, he said:

. . . it runs for five years only, a comparatively short time for heavy industry with its large chunks of investment, and long lead times for the installation of plant and for earning a return on investment.
In 1982 the then Executive General Manager of BHP's steel division, Mr David Rice, said the following in relation to the time span required for a steel industry plan:

Due to the magnitude of the investments required and the time to plan, design, construct and bring on line new steelplant facilities some indication of ongoing support is essential before funds could be committed. For this reason a time span for assistance of the type specified of at least ten years would be required.
So even before the details of the plan had been finalised, BHP was arguing that any plan should last at least 10 years. Now, less than four years down the track, BHP wants an end to it.

Yet the achievements of the plan have been considerable: It has prevented forced retrenchments from the industry; it has kept BHP's steel division open and in profit, after massive losses in the early 1980s; it has increased productivity by 38 per cent; and, apart from problems in Port Kembla earlier this year, it has improved the industrial relations climate dramatically. In fact it has been in Whyalla where the tripartite nature of the plan has had its major successes. BHP Whyalla has received no benefit at all from the bounty measures in the plan; yet productivity has improved significantly in the past four years and industrial relations have been handled by both management and unions in a most responsible manner.

I wish at this point to pay tribute to the efforts of the Whyalla Trades and Labour Council, particularly Doug Elkins, John Watson, Geoff Buckland and the many other responsible unionists who have been to a great degree responsible for the excellent performance of the steel industry in Whyalla. BHP management in Whyalla should also be congratulated for its attitude toward industrial relations. It seems to me that the Whyalla experience should serve as a model for the national steel industry as a whole. I call on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and all Ministers to do all in their power to convince BHP of the necessity of the continuation of the steel industry plan.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 14 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the AGPS Publishing and Printing Procurement Office in The Hague, the Netherlands established.

(2) Does the Commonwealth have the power to regulate aviation practices in Australia through the Air Navigation Act.
(3) Do the International Civil Aviation Organisation's Standards and Recommended Procedures contain provisions to regulate the operation of airships.
(4) Do the existing Australian Air Navigation Regulations make provision for the regulation of safety, operational and environmental aspects of airships.
(5) What operational aspects of ballooning are presently controlled in Australia by Air Navigation Regulations or Air Navigation Orders.
(6) If regulations do not presently exist for the safety, operational and environmental aspects of airship operations, will such regulations be implemented; if so, when will this occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Yes. The standards and recommended practices prescribed by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) cover the operation of all aircraft. Airships are aircraft by definition in both the ICAO rules and the Air Navigation Act.
(4) The existing Air Navigation Regulations make provision for the regulation of safety, and operational aspects of all categories of aircraft, including airships.

With regard to environmental aspects the Air Navigation (Aircraft Noise) Regulations call up the application of ICAO Annex 16 requirements for the noise certification of aircraft. Currently the requirements specified in the Annex apply only to aeroplanes and helicopters.

(5) Because the Air Navigation Regulations primarily specify rules for the operation of powered aircraft, exemptions have been granted against many of the provisions of the Regulations in order to facilitate the operation of balloons and other non-powered aircraft. In addition, airworthiness requirements are specified in ANO 101.54 (certification) and 101.54 (maintenance), and Commercial Pilot Licence (Balloons) requirements are in ANO 40.7.

(6) As indicated in the above answer to part 4, regulations do exist for the safe operation of airships. With regard to environmental aspects, the noise criteria specified for aeroplanes and helicopters are being used in determining acceptable operating heights for airships.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the decision made to impose an assets test on unemployment benefits.
(2) Was any consideration given to the effect this would have on farmers and their spouses; if not, why not.
(3) If the effect on farmers and their spouses was considered, what conclusions were reached.
(4) When was a decision made to introduce hardship provisions and a taper for the assets test.
(5) Why was the decision made.
(6) Why were the hardship provisions and taper not introduced when the assets test on unemployment benefits was first announced.
(7) Were farming organisations consulted before the hardship provisions were drafted; if so, what was their contribution to the consultation.
(8) If farming organisations were not consulted, why not.
(9) Was the impact of the hardship provisions on the Rural Adjustment Scheme considered; if so, what conclusions were reached.
(10) If the impact on the Rural Adjustment Scheme was not considered, why not.
(11) Why will a statutory formula for deemed income under the hardship provisions be introduced.
(12) Why was the factor of 2.5% chosen.
(13) Was the actual income of farmers considered.
(14) What sum will this action save.
(15) How many pensioners will lose their pensions as a result of this interpretation of deemed income.
(16) Have the manuals on the hardship provisions been completed; if so, when were they (a) completed and (b) distributed to regional offices.
(17) If the manuals have not been completed and distributed, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (13) The decision to introduce an assets test on unemployment, sickness and special benefit for persons aged 25 years or more was made in the context of preparation of the 1987-88 Budget. It has long been accepted that the details of Cabinet deliberations are confidential.
(14) The introduction of the assets test to those forms of benefit is estimated to save $24.5m in a full year.
(16) and (17) Instructions for incorporation in the departmental manuals have been written. They will be distributed in the near future.
